paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter KENT, GLOUCESTER, and EDMUND$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$EDMUND
paragraphs.translated: KENT, GLOUCESTER, and EDMUND enter.$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$EDMUND

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I thought the king had more affected the Duke of Albany than Cornwall.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I thought the king preferred the Duke of Albany to the Duke of Cornwall.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$It did always seem so to us. But now in the division of the kingdom, it appears not which of the dukes he values most, for equalities are so weighed that curiosity in neither can make choice of either’s moiety.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$We used to think so too. But the way he’s divided the kingdom recently, nobody can tell which of the dukes he favors more. He’s split the kingdom so evenly that it’s impossible to see any indication of favoritism.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(indicating EDMUND) Is not this your son, my lord?$NEWLINE$(indicating$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$(pointing to EDMUND) Isn’t this your son, my lord?$NEWLINE$(pointing to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$His breeding, sir, hath been at my charge. I have so often blushed to acknowledge him that now I am brazed to it.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Yes, I’ve been responsible for his upbringing. I’ve had to acknowledge that he’s my son so many times that now I can do it without embarrassment.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I cannot conceive you.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I can’t conceive of what you mean.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Sir, this young fellow’s mother could, whereupon she grew round-wombed, and had indeed, sir, a son for her cradle ere she had a husband for her bed. Do you smell a fault?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$You can’t conceive? Well, this guy’s mother could conceive him all to well. She grew a big belly and had a baby for her crib before she had a husband for her bed. Do you smell something naughty?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I cannot wish the fault undone, the issue of it being so proper.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Well, I wouldn’t want to undo the naughtiness, since the boy turned out so well.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$But I have, sir, a son by order of law, some year older than this, who yet is no dearer in my account. Though this knave came something saucily to the world before he was sent for, yet was his mother fair, there was good sport at his making, and the whoreson must be acknowledged.—Do you know this noble gentleman, Edmund?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$But I have a legitimate son a few years older than this one, and I don’t love him any more than I love my bastard. Edmund may have snuck into the world a little before his time, but his mother was pretty, we had a fun time making him, and now I have to acknowledge the guy as my son.—Do you know this gentleman, Edmund?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$No, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$No, I don’t, my lord.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND) My lord of Kent. Remember him hereafter as my honorable friend.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND) This is Lord Kent. Remember him as my friend and an honorable man.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$My services to your lordship.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Very pleased to meet you, my lord.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I must love you and sue to know you better.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I look forward to getting to know you better.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Sir, I shall study deserving.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’ll try to make myself worth your knowledge.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He hath been out nine years, and away he shall again.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He’s been gone for nine years and he’s leaving again soon.

paragraphs.original: Sennet.
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets announce the arrival of King LEAR.$NEWLINE$LEAR

paragraphs.original: The king is coming.
paragraphs.translated: The king is coming.

paragraphs.original: Enter one bearing a coronet, then King LEAR, then the Dukes of CORNWALL and ALBANY, next GONERIL, REGAN, CORDELIA, and attendants$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$ALBANY$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$CORDELIA
paragraphs.translated: A man bearing a crown enters, followed by KING LEAR, the Dukes of CORNWALL and ALBANY, then GONERIL, REGAN, CORDELIA, and attendants.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$ALBANY$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$CORDELIA

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Attend the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Go escort the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I shall, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exit GLOUCESTERLEAR$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTERLEAR
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER exits.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Meantime we shall express our darker purpose.—$NEWLINE$Give me the map there.—Know that we have divided$NEWLINE$In three our kingdom, and ’tis our fast intent$NEWLINE$To shake all cares and business from our age,$NEWLINE$Conferring them on younger strengths while we$NEWLINE$Unburdened crawl toward death.—Our son of Cornwall,$NEWLINE$And you, our no less loving son of Albany,$NEWLINE$We have this hour a constant will to publish
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$In the meantime I’ll get down to my real business.—Hand me that map over there.—I hereby announce that I’ve divided my kingdom into three parts, which I’m handing over to the younger generation so I can enjoy a little rest and peace of mind in my old age.—Cornwall and Albany, my loving sons-in-law, I now want to announce publicly what each of my daughters will inherit, to avoid hostilities after I die. The two

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Our daughters' several dowers, that future strife$NEWLINE$May be prevented now.$NEWLINE$The two great princes, France and Burgundy,$NEWLINE$Great rivals in our youngest daughter’s love,$NEWLINE$Long in our court have made their amorous sojourn,$NEWLINE$And here are to be answered.—Tell me, my daughters,$NEWLINE$(Since now we will divest us both of rule,$NEWLINE$Interest of territory, cares of state)$NEWLINE$Which of you shall we say doth love us most$NEWLINE$That we our largest bounty may extend$NEWLINE$Where nature doth with merit challenge?—Goneril,$NEWLINE$Our eldest born, speak first.
paragraphs.translated: great princes of France and Burgundy, vying for the hand of my youngest Cordelia, have been at my court a long time and will soon have their answers.—My daughters, since I’m about to give up my throne and the worries that go along with it, tell me which one of you loves me most, so that I can give my largest gift to the one who deserves it most.—Goneril, my oldest daughter, you speak first.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Sir, I do love you more than words can wield the matter,$NEWLINE$Dearer than eyesight, space, and liberty,$NEWLINE$Beyond what can be valued, rich or rare,$NEWLINE$No less than life, with grace, health, beauty, honor,$NEWLINE$As much as child e'er loved or father found—$NEWLINE$A love that makes breath poor and speech unable.$NEWLINE$Beyond all manner of so much I love you.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Sir, I love you more than words can say. I love you more than eyesight, space, and freedom, beyond wealth or anything of value. I love you as much as life itself, and as much as status, health, beauty, or honor. I love you as much as any child has ever loved her father, with a love too deep to be spoken of. I love you more than any answer to the question “How much?”

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(aside) What shall Cordelia speak? Love, and be silent.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(to herself) What will I say? I can only love and be silent.$NEWLINE$(to herself)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Of all these bounds, even from this line to this,$NEWLINE$With shadowy forests and with champains riched,$NEWLINE$With plenteous rivers and wide-skirted meads,$NEWLINE$We make thee lady. To thine and Albany’s issue$NEWLINE$Be this perpetual.—What says our second daughter,$NEWLINE$Our dearest Regan, wife of Cornwall? Speak.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I give you all this land, from this line to that one—dense forests, fertile fields, rivers rich with fish, wide meadows. This land will belong to your and Albany’s children forever.—And now what does my second daughter Regan, the wife of Cornwall, have to say? Tell me.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Sir, I am made of that self mettle as my sister,$NEWLINE$And prize me at her worth. In my true heart,$NEWLINE$I find she names my very deed of love—$NEWLINE$Only she comes too short, that I profess
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Sir, I’m made of the same stuff as my sister and consider myself just as good as she is. She’s described my feelings of love for you precisely, but her description falls a little short of the truth. I reject completely any

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Myself an enemy to all other joys,$NEWLINE$Which the most precious square of sense possesses.$NEWLINE$And find I am alone felicitate$NEWLINE$In your dear highness' love.
paragraphs.translated: joy except my love for you, and I find that only your majesty’s love makes me happy.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(aside)     Then poor Cordelia!$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$And yet not so, since I am sure my love’s$NEWLINE$More ponderous than my tongue.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(to herself) Poor me, what am I going to say now? But I’m not poor in love—my love is bigger than my words are.$NEWLINE$(to herself)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$To thee and thine hereditary ever$NEWLINE$Remain this ample third of our fair kingdom,$NEWLINE$No less in space, validity, and pleasure$NEWLINE$Than that conferred on Goneril.—But now, our joy,$NEWLINE$Although our last and least, to whose young love$NEWLINE$The vines of France and milk of Burgundy$NEWLINE$Strive to be interessed. What can you say to draw$NEWLINE$A third more opulent than your sisters? Speak.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$You and your heirs hereby receive this large third of our lovely kingdom, no smaller in area or value than what I gave Goneril.—Now, you, my youngest daughter, my joy, courted by the rich rulers of France and Burgundy, what can you tell me that will make me give you a bigger part of my kingdom than I gave your sisters? Speak.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Nothing, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Nothing, my lord.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Nothing?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Nothing?

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Nothing.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Nothing.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$How? Nothing will come of nothing. Speak again.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Come on, “nothing” will get you nothing. Try again.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Unhappy that I am, I cannot heave$NEWLINE$My heart into my mouth. I love your majesty$NEWLINE$According to my bond, no more nor less.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$I’m unlucky. I don’t have a talent for putting my heart’s feelings into words. I love you as a child should love her father, neither more nor less.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$How, how, Cordelia? Mend your speech a little,$NEWLINE$Lest you may mar your fortunes.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$What are you saying, Cordelia? Revise your statement, or you may damage your inheritance.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Good my lord,$NEWLINE$You have begot me, bred me, loved me. I$NEWLINE$Return those duties back as are right fit—
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$My lord, you brought me up and loved me, and I’m giving back just as I should: I obey you, love you, and

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Obey you, love you, and most honor you.$NEWLINE$Why have my sisters husbands if they say$NEWLINE$They love you all? Haply when I shall wed$NEWLINE$That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry$NEWLINE$Half my love with him, half my care and duty.$NEWLINE$Sure, I shall never marry like my sisters,$NEWLINE$To love my father all.
paragraphs.translated: honor you. How can my sisters speak the truth when they say they love only you? Don’t they love their husbands too? Hopefully when I get married, I’ll give my husband half my love and half my sense of duty. I’m sure I’ll never get married in the way my sisters say they’re married, loving their father only.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$But goes thy heart with this?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$But do you mean what you’re saying?

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Ay, good my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$So young and so untender?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$So young and so cruel?

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$So young, my lord, and true.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$So young, my lord, and honest.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Let it be so. Thy truth then be thy dower.$NEWLINE$For by the sacred radiance of the sun,$NEWLINE$The mysteries of Hecate and the night,$NEWLINE$By all the operation of the orbs$NEWLINE$From whom we do exist and cease to be—$NEWLINE$Here I disclaim all my paternal care,$NEWLINE$Propinquity, and property of blood,$NEWLINE$And as a stranger to my heart and me$NEWLINE$Hold thee from this for ever. The barbarous Scythian,$NEWLINE$Or he that makes his generation messes$NEWLINE$To gorge his appetite, shall to my bosom$NEWLINE$Be as well neighbored, pitied, and relieved$NEWLINE$As thou my sometime daughter.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Then that’s the way it’ll be. The truth will be all the inheritance you get. I swear by the sacred sun, by the mysterious moon, and by all the planets that rule our lives, that I disown you now as my daughter. As of now, there are no family ties between us, and I consider you a stranger to me. Foreign savages who eat their own children for dinner will be as close to my heart as you, ex-daughter of mine.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Good my liege—
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$But sir—

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Peace, Kent.$NEWLINE$Come not between the dragon and his wrath.$NEWLINE$I loved her most and thought to set my rest$NEWLINE$On her kind nursery.—
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Be quiet, Kent. Don’t get in my way when I’m angry. I loved Cordelia most of all and planned to spend my old age with her taking care of me. (to CORDELIA) Go$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: (to CORDELIA)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Hence, and avoid my sight!—$NEWLINE$So be my grave my peace as here I give$NEWLINE$Her father’s heart from her.—Call France. Who stirs?$NEWLINE$Call Burgundy.—
paragraphs.translated: away! Get out of my sight!—I guess if she doesn’t love her father, then I’ll only have peace when I’m dead.—Call the King of France. Why is nobody doing anything? Call the Duke of Burgundy.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt several attendants
paragraphs.translated: Several attendants exit.

paragraphs.original: Cornwall and Albany,$NEWLINE$With my two daughters' dowers digest this third.$NEWLINE$Let pride, which she calls plainness, marry her.$NEWLINE$I do invest you jointly with my power,$NEWLINE$Preeminence, and all the large effects$NEWLINE$That troop with majesty. Ourself, by monthly course,$NEWLINE$With reservation of an hundred knights$NEWLINE$By you to be sustained, shall our abode$NEWLINE$Make with you by due turns. Only shall we retain$NEWLINE$The name, and all th' additions to a king.$NEWLINE$The sway, revenue, execution of the rest,$NEWLINE$Belovèd sons, be yours; which to confirm,$NEWLINE$This coronet part between you.$NEWLINE$(gives CORNWALL and ALBANY the coronet)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$the coronet)
paragraphs.translated: Cornwall and Albany, you and your wives can divide this last third of my kingdom between you. If she wants to be proud, or “honest,” as she calls it, she can just marry her own pride. I hereby grant to you two my crown and all the privileges that kingship brings. I’ll live one month with one of you, the next month with the other one. All I ask is that you provide me with a hundred knights for my own entourage. I’ll keep only the title of king, but you’ll have everything else: all the authority and income that come with kingship. To confirm all this, take this crown to share between yourselves. (he gives CORNWALL and ALBANY the crown)$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$the crown)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Royal Lear,$NEWLINE$Whom I have ever honored as my king,$NEWLINE$Loved as my father, as my master followed,$NEWLINE$As my great patron thought on in my prayers—
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$King Lear, I’ve always honored you as king, loved you as my father, obeyed you as my master, and thanked you in my prayers—

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$The bow is bent and drawn. Make from the shaft.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I’m furious and ready to snap. Stay away or else I’ll take my anger out on you.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Let it fall rather, though the fork invade$NEWLINE$The region of my heart. Be Kent unmannerly$NEWLINE$When Lear is mad. What wouldst thou do, old man?$NEWLINE$Think’st thou that duty shall have dread to speak$NEWLINE$When power to flattery bows? To plainness honor’s bound$NEWLINE$When majesty falls to folly. Reserve thy state,
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Let your anger fall on me then, even if its sharpness pierces my heart. Kent can speak rudely when Lear goes mad. What are you doing, old man? When powerful kings cave in to flatterers, do you think loyal men will be afraid to speak out against it? When a majestic king starts acting silly, then it’s my duty to be blunt.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And in thy best consideration check$NEWLINE$This hideous rashness. Answer my life my judgment,$NEWLINE$Thy youngest daughter does not love thee least,$NEWLINE$Nor are those empty-hearted whose low sound$NEWLINE$Reverbs no hollowness.
paragraphs.translated: Hold on to your crown and use your better judgment to rethink this rash decision. On my life I swear to you that your youngest daughter doesn’t love you least. A loud mouth often points to an empty heart, and just because she’s quiet doesn’t mean she’s unloving.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Kent, on thy life, no more.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Kent, if you want to stay alive, stop talking.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$My life I never held but as a pawn$NEWLINE$To wage against thy enemies, nor fear to lose it,$NEWLINE$Thy safety being motive.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I never considered my life as anything more than a chess pawn for you to play off against your enemies. I’m not afraid to lose it if it helps protect you.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Out of my sight!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Get out of my sight!

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$See better, Lear, and let me still remain$NEWLINE$The true blank of thine eye.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Learn to see better, Lear, and let me stay here where you can look to me for good advice.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Now, by Apollo—
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Now, I swear by Apollo…

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Now, by Apollo, King,$NEWLINE$Thou swear’st thy gods in vain.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$By Apollo, King, you’re taking the names of the gods in vain.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$O vassal! Miscreant!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Oh, you lowlife! Scum!

paragraphs.original: ALBANY, CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Dear sir, forbear!
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY, CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Please stop, sir.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Do, kill thy physician, and the fee bestow$NEWLINE$Upon thy foul disease. Revoke thy gift,$NEWLINE$Or whilst I can vent clamor from my throat,$NEWLINE$I’ll tell thee thou dost evil.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Sure, kill the doctor who’s trying to cure you and pay your disease. Take back your gift to Albany and Cornwall. If you don’t, then as long as I’m able to speak I’ll keep telling you you’ve done a bad, bad thing.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Hear me, recreant! On thine allegiance hear me.$NEWLINE$That thou hast sought to make us break our vows,$NEWLINE$Which we durst never yet, and with strained pride$NEWLINE$To come betwixt our sentence and our power,$NEWLINE$Which nor our nature nor our place can bear,
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Listen to me, you traitor. You’ll pay the price for trying to make me go back on the vow I made when I bequeathed my kingdom to them. I’ve never broken a vow yet. You tried to make me revise my judgment on my youngest daughter, disrespecting my power as

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Our potency made good, take thy reward:$NEWLINE$Five days we do allot thee for provision$NEWLINE$To shield thee from diseases of the world.$NEWLINE$And on the sixth to turn thy hated back$NEWLINE$Upon our kingdom. If on the next day following$NEWLINE$Thy banished trunk be found in our dominions,$NEWLINE$The moment is thy death. Away! By Jupiter,$NEWLINE$This shall not be revoked.
paragraphs.translated: king—which I can’t put up with either as a ruler or as a person. This is your punishment: I’ll give you five days to gather together what you need to survive, then on the sixth day you’ll leave this kingdom that hates you. If the day after that you’re found in my kingdom, you die. Now get out of here! I swear by Jupiter I’ll never revoke this punishment.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Why, fare thee well, King. Sith thus thou wilt appear,$NEWLINE$Freedom lives hence, and banishment is here.$NEWLINE$(to CORDELIA)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$The gods to their dear shelter take thee, maid,$NEWLINE$That justly think’st and hast most rightly said!$NEWLINE$(to REGAN and GONERIL)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And your large speeches may your deeds approve,$NEWLINE$That good effects may spring from words of love.—$NEWLINE$Thus Kent, O princes, bids you all adieu.$NEWLINE$He’ll shape his old course in a country new.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Farewell, King. If this is how you act, it’s clear that freedom has been banished from this kingdom.(to CORDELIA) I hope the gods will protect you, my dear girl, for thinking fairly and speaking correctly. (to REGAN and GONERIL) And you two, I hope your actions carry out your grand promises of love, so that big words can bring big results. Farewell to all of you. I’ll carry on my old life in a new land.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit KENT$NEWLINE$KENT
paragraphs.translated: KENT exits.$NEWLINE$KENT

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Enter GLOUCESTER with the King of FRANCE, the Duke of BURGUNDY, and attendants$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$FRANCE$NEWLINE$BURGUNDY
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. GLOUCESTER enters with the King of FRANCE, the Duke of BURGUNDY, and attendants.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$FRANCE$NEWLINE$BURGUNDY

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Here’s France and Burgundy, my noble lord.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Here are the rulers of France and Burgundy, my lord.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$My lord of Burgundy.$NEWLINE$We first address towards you, who with this king$NEWLINE$Hath rivaled for our daughter. What in the least$NEWLINE$Will you require in present dower with her$NEWLINE$Or cease your quest of love?
paragraphs.translated:
LEAR$NEWLINE$My lord the ruler of Burgundy, I’ll speak to you first. You’ve been competing with this king for my daughter. What’s the least that you will settle for as a
dowry?$NEWLINE$dowry?$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$Most royal majesty,$NEWLINE$I crave no more than hath your highness offered.$NEWLINE$Nor will you tender less.
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$Your highness, I want nothing more than what you’ve already offered. I know you’ll offer nothing less than that.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Right noble Burgundy,$NEWLINE$When she was dear to us we did hold her so,$NEWLINE$But now her price is fallen. Sir, there she stands.$NEWLINE$If aught within that little seeming substance,$NEWLINE$Or all of it, with our displeasure pieced$NEWLINE$And nothing more, may fitly like your grace,$NEWLINE$She’s there, and she is yours.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Burgundy, I valued her highly when I cared about her. But now her price has fallen. There she is, over there. If there’s anything you like about that worthless little thing, then go for it. She’s all yours. But what you see is what you get—her only dowry is my disapproval. There she is.

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$I know no answer.
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$I don’t know what to say.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Sir, will you, with those infirmities she owes—$NEWLINE$Unfriended, new adopted to our hate,$NEWLINE$Dowered with our curse and strangered with our oath—$NEWLINE$Take her or leave her?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$She’s got big flaws. She has no friends or protectors. I no longer love her. Her only dowry is my curse and banishment. So do you take her or leave her?

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$Pardon me, royal sir.$NEWLINE$Election makes not up in such conditions.
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$I’m sorry, sir, but nobody can make a choice like this in such circumstances.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Then leave her, sir, for by the power that made me,$NEWLINE$I tell you all her wealth.$NEWLINE$(to FRANCE)   For you, great King,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I would not from your love make such a stray$NEWLINE$To match you where I hate. Therefore beseech you$NEWLINE$T' avert your liking a more worthier way$NEWLINE$Than on a wretch whom Nature is ashamed$NEWLINE$Almost t' acknowledge hers.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Then leave her, sir. I swear to God she’s not worth anything more than what I told you. (to FRANCE) And as for you, great King of France, I’d never insult our friendship by encouraging you to marry a girl I hate. So I beg you to look around for a better match than this wretched creature that you can barely call human.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FRANCE$NEWLINE$This is most strange,$NEWLINE$That she that even but now was your best object—$NEWLINE$The argument of your praise, balm of your age,$NEWLINE$Most best, most dearest—should in this trice of time
paragraphs.translated: FRANCE$NEWLINE$This is very odd. Until very recently she was your favorite, the object of all your praise and the delight of your old age. It’s strange that someone so dear to you could do anything so horrible as to warrant this sudden

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Commit a thing so monstrous to dismantle$NEWLINE$So many folds of favor. Sure, her offense$NEWLINE$Must be of such unnatural degree$NEWLINE$That monsters it (or your fore-vouched affection$NEWLINE$Fall into taint), which to believe of her$NEWLINE$Must be a faith that reason without miracle$NEWLINE$Could never plant in me.
paragraphs.translated: hatred. Her crime must be extreme and monstrous, or else your earlier love for her wasn’t as true as it seemed. But it’d take a miracle to make me believe she could do anything that horrible.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) I yet beseech your majesty,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$If for I want that glib and oily art$NEWLINE$To speak and purpose not—since what I well intend,$NEWLINE$I’ll do ’t before I speak—that you make known$NEWLINE$It is no vicious blot, murder, or foulness,$NEWLINE$No unchaste action or dishonored step$NEWLINE$That hath deprived me of your grace and favor,$NEWLINE$But even for want of that for which I am richer:$NEWLINE$A still-soliciting eye and such a tongue$NEWLINE$As I am glad I have not, though not to have it$NEWLINE$Hath lost me in your liking.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) Please, your majesty, I don’t have a glib way with words and I only say what I mean. If I decide to do something, then I do it instead of talking about it. So I beg your majesty to let people know that it wasn’t because I did something atrocious$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$that I fell from your favor. I didn’t murder or commit any immoral or lustful act. I’m out of favor simply because I’m not a fortune-hunter and I don’t have a smooth way with words—and I’m a better person because of it, even though it has cost me your love.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Go to, go to. Better thou$NEWLINE$Hadst not been born than not t' have pleased me better.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Enough. It would’ve been better for you not to have been born at all than to displease me as you did.

paragraphs.original: FRANCE$NEWLINE$Is it no more but this—a tardiness in nature$NEWLINE$Which often leaves the history unspoke$NEWLINE$That it intends to do?—My lord of Burgundy,$NEWLINE$What say you to the lady? Love’s not love$NEWLINE$When it is mingled with regards that stands$NEWLINE$Aloof from th' entire point. Will you have her?$NEWLINE$She is herself a dowry.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCE$NEWLINE$You mean this is the whole problem, that she is shy and hasn’t said everything she means to say and do?—My lord of Burgundy, what do you have to say to this lady? Love’s not love when it gets mixed up with irrelevant outside matters. Will you marry her? She herself is as valuable as any dowry could ever be.

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$(to LEAR)    Royal King,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Give but that portion which yourself proposed,$NEWLINE$And here I take Cordelia by the hand,$NEWLINE$Duchess of Burgundy.
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) King, just give me the dowry you promised me, and I’ll make Cordelia the Duchess of Burgundy right away.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Nothing. I have sworn. I am firm.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, I’ll give nothing. I won’t budge on that.

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$(to CORDELIA) I am sorry then. You have so lost a father$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$That you must lose a husband.
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$(to CORDELIA) In that case, I’m sorry you have to lose me as a husband because you lost the king as a father.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Peace be with Burgundy.$NEWLINE$Since that respects and fortunes are his love,$NEWLINE$I shall not be his wife.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Peace to you, my lord of Burgundy. Since you love money and power so much, I won’t be your wife.

paragraphs.original: FRANCE$NEWLINE$Fairest Cordelia, that art most rich being poor,$NEWLINE$Most choice forsaken, and most loved despised!$NEWLINE$Thee and thy virtues here I seize upon,$NEWLINE$Be it lawful I take up what’s cast away.$NEWLINE$Gods, gods! 'Tis strange that from their cold’st neglect$NEWLINE$My love should kindle to inflamed respect.—$NEWLINE$Thy dowerless daughter, King, thrown to my chance,$NEWLINE$Is queen of us, of ours, and our fair France.$NEWLINE$Not all the dukes of waterish Burgundy$NEWLINE$Can buy this unprized precious maid of me.—$NEWLINE$Bid them farewell, Cordelia, though unkind.$NEWLINE$Thou losest here, a better where to find.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCE$NEWLINE$Beautiful Cordelia, you’re all the richer now that you’re poor. You’re more valuable now that you’re rejected and more loved now that you’re hated.$NEWLINE$I’ll take you and your wonderful virtues here and now, if it’s okay that I’m picking up what others have thrown away. It’s so strange that in neglecting you so cruelly, the gods have made me love you so dearly.—King, the daughter you’ve rejected is now mine, as Queen of France. No Duke of spineless Burgundy can take this treasure of a girl from me now.—Say goodbye to them, Cordelia, even though they’ve been unkind to you. You’ll find a much better place in France than what you’re giving up here.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Thou hast her, France. Let her be thine, for we$NEWLINE$Have no such daughter, nor shall ever see$NEWLINE$That face of hers again. (to CORDELIA) Therefore be gone$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Without our grace, our love, our benison.—$NEWLINE$Come, noble Burgundy.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$She’s yours, King of France. Take her. She’s no longer my daughter, and I’ll never see her face again. (to CORDELIA) So get out of here. Leave without any blessing or love from me.—Come with me, Burgundy.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Flourish
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but FRANCE, GONERIL, REGAN, and CORDELIA$NEWLINE$FRANCE$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$CORDELIA
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except FRANCE, GONERIL, REGAN, and CORDELIA.$NEWLINE$FRANCE$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$CORDELIA

paragraphs.original: FRANCE$NEWLINE$Bid farewell to your sisters.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCE$NEWLINE$Say goodbye to your sisters.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$The jewels of our father, with washed eyes$NEWLINE$Cordelia leaves you. I know you what you are,$NEWLINE$And like a sister am most loath to call$NEWLINE$Your faults as they are named. Love well our father.$NEWLINE$To your professèd bosoms I commit him.$NEWLINE$But yet, alas, stood I within his grace,$NEWLINE$I would prefer him to a better place.$NEWLINE$So farewell to you both.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Sisters, you whom our father loves so dearly, I leave you now with tears in my eyes. I know you for what you really are, but as your sister I’m reluctant to criticize you. Take good care of our father and show him the love that you have professed. I leave him in your care—but oh, if only I were still in his favor I could arrange for better care for him. Goodbye to you both.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Prescribe not us our duty.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Don’t tell us what our duty is.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Let your study$NEWLINE$Be to content your lord, who hath received you$NEWLINE$At fortune’s alms. You have obedience scanted,$NEWLINE$And well are worth the want that you have wanted.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$You should focus instead on pleasing your husband, who’s taken you in as an act of charity. You’ve failed to obey your father and you deserve to be deprived of everything that’s been taken away from you.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Time shall unfold what plighted cunning hides,$NEWLINE$Who covers faults at last with shame derides.$NEWLINE$Well may you prosper.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Time will tell what you’ve got up your sleeve. You can be deceitful in the short term, but eventually truth will come out. Have a good life.

paragraphs.original: FRANCE$NEWLINE$Come, my fair Cordelia.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCE$NEWLINE$Come with me, my dear Cordelia.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt FRANCE and CORDELIA$NEWLINE$FRANCE$NEWLINE$CORDELIA
paragraphs.translated: FRANCE and CORDELIA exit.$NEWLINE$FRANCE$NEWLINE$CORDELIA

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Sister, it is not a little I have to say of what most nearly appertains to us both. I think our father will hence tonight.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Sister, I have a lot to say about things that concern us both. I think that our father will leave here tonight.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$That’s most certain, and with you. Next month with us.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Yes, I’m sure he will—to stay with you. Next month he’ll stay with us.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$You see how full of changes his age is. The observation we have made of it hath not been little. He always loved our sister most, and with what poor judgment he hath now cast her off appears too grossly.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$He’s so flighty in his old age, as we keep noticing. He has always loved Cordelia best, and his bad judgment in disowning her now is obvious.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$'Tis the infirmity of his age. Yet he hath ever but slenderly known himself.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$He’s going senile. But then again he’s never really understood his own feelings very well.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$The best and soundest of his time hath been but rash. Then must we look from his age to receive not alone the imperfections of long-engrafted condition, but therewithal the unruly waywardness that infirm and choleric years bring with them.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Yes, he was hotheaded even in the prime of his life. Now that he’s old, we can expect to have to deal not only with his old character flaws, which have turned into deep-rooted habits, but also with the uncontrollable crabbiness that comes with old age.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Such unconstant starts are we like to have from him as this of Kent’s banishment.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$We’ll probably witness many more outbursts from him, like banishing Kent.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$There is further compliment of leave-taking between France and him. Pray you, let’s sit together. If our father carry authority with such dispositions as he bears, this last surrender of his will but offend us.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$There’s still the King of France’s farewell ceremony. Let’s put our heads together. If our father continues to use his authority as usual, then his recent abdication of the kingdom will just hurt us.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$We shall further think on ’t.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$We’ll have to think about it carefully.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$We must do something, and i' th' heat.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$We have to strike while the iron’s hot.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter EDMUND the bastard, with a letter$NEWLINE$EDMUND
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND enters with a letter.$NEWLINE$EDMUND

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Thou, nature, art my goddess. To thy law$NEWLINE$My services are bound. Wherefore should I$NEWLINE$Stand in the plague of custom and permit$NEWLINE$The curiosity of nations to deprive me$NEWLINE$For that I am some twelve or fourteen moonshines$NEWLINE$Lag of a brother? Why “bastard”? Wherefore “base”?$NEWLINE$When my dimensions are as well compact,$NEWLINE$My mind as generous, and my shape as true$NEWLINE$As honest madam’s issue? Why brand they us$NEWLINE$With “base,” with “baseness,” “bastardy,” “base,” “base”—$NEWLINE$Who in the lusty stealth of nature take$NEWLINE$More composition and fierce quality$NEWLINE$Than doth within a dull, stale, tirèd bed$NEWLINE$Go to th' creating a whole tribe of fops$NEWLINE$Got ’tween a sleep and wake? Well then,$NEWLINE$Legitimate Edgar, I must have your land.$NEWLINE$Our father’s love is to the bastard Edmund$NEWLINE$As to the legitimate.—Fine word, “legitimate”!—$NEWLINE$Well, my legitimate, if this letter speed$NEWLINE$And my invention thrive, Edmund the base$NEWLINE$Shall top th' legitimate. I grow, I prosper.$NEWLINE$Now, gods, stand up for bastards!
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I only worship what’s natural, not what’s manmade. Why should I let myself be tortured by manmade social customs that deprive me of my rights simply because I was born twelve or fourteen months later than my older brother? Why do they call me “bastard” and “lowlife” when I’m just as gifted in mind and body as legitimate children? Why do they call us bastards “lowlifes”? Always “lowlife,” “bastard,” “lowlife,” “lowlife.” At least we bastards were conceived in a moment of passionate lust rather than in a dull, tired marriage bed, where half-sleeping parents monotonously churn out a bunch of sissy kids. All right then, legitimate brother Edgar, I have to have your lands. Our father loves me just as much as the legitimate Edgar. What a nice word that is, “legitimate”! Well, my legitimate Edgar, if this letter works and my plan succeeds, Edmund the lowlife will beat the legitimate. Look out, I’m on my way up. Three cheers for bastards!

paragraphs.original: Enter GLOUCESTER EDMUND looks over his letter$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$EDMUND
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER enters. EDMUND looks over his letter.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$EDMUND

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Kent banished thus? And France in choler parted?$NEWLINE$And the king gone tonight, prescribed his power$NEWLINE$Confined to exhibition? All this done$NEWLINE$Upon the gad?—Edmund, how now? What news?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Kent’s been banished just like that? And the King of France gone in a huff? And King Lear’s abdicated his authority, making his kingship a ceremonial title only? All this so suddenly?—Edmund, what’s going on? What’s the news?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$(pocketing the letter) So please your lordship, none.$NEWLINE$(pocketing the letter)
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$(pocketing the letter) No news, my lord.$NEWLINE$(pocketing the letter)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Why so earnestly seek you to put up that letter?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Why are you hiding that letter?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I know no news, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I don’t have any news to report, my lord.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$What paper were you reading?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$What’s that paper you were reading?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Nothing, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$It’s nothing, my lord.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$No? What needed, then, that terrible dispatch of it into your pocket? The quality of nothing hath not such need to hide itself. Let’s see.—Come, if it be nothing, I shall not need spectacles.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$No? Then why did you have to stick it in your pocket in such a hurry? If it were nothing, you wouldn’t need to hide it. Let’s see it. Come on, if it’s nothing, I won’t need glasses to read it.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I beseech you, sir, pardon me. It is a letter from my brother that I have not all o'er-read. And for so much as I have perused, I find it not fit for your o'erlooking.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Please, sir, I beg you. It’s a letter from my brother that I haven’t finished reading yet. But judging from the bit I have read, it’s not fit for you to see.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Give me the letter, sir.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Give me that letter, sir.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I shall offend, either to detain or give it. The contents, as in part I understand them, are to blame.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Now I’ll offend you whether I give it to you or not. The problem is in what the letter says, as far as I can tell.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(taking the letter) Let’s see, let’s see.$NEWLINE$(taking the letter)
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(taking the letter) Let’s see, let’s see.$NEWLINE$(taking the letter)

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I hope, for my brother’s justification, he wrote this but as an essay or taste of my virtue.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I hope for my brother’s sake that he just wrote it to test my honor.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(reads) “This policy and reverence of age makes the world bitter to the best of our times, keeps our fortunes from us till our oldness cannot relish them. I begin to find an idle and fond bondage in the oppression of aged tyranny, who sways not as it hath power but as it is suffered.$NEWLINE$(reads)
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“The custom of respecting the elderly makes it hard for the young and healthy to live well, and keeps us without our inheritance until we are so old we can’t enjoy our happiness anyway. The power of the elderly is starting to feel like a silly and foolish slavery to me, and they only enjoy that power because we let them have it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Come to me, that of this I may speak more. If our father would sleep till I waked him, you should enjoy half his revenue forever, and live the beloved of your brother,$NEWLINE$Edgar.”$NEWLINE$Hum, conspiracy? “'Sleep till I wake him, you should enjoy half his revenue”—my son Edgar? Had he a hand to write this, a heart and brain to breed it in? When came this to you? Who brought it?
paragraphs.translated: Come talk to me about this. If our father were dead you’d receive half of his revenue forever, and you’d have my undying love,$NEWLINE$Edgar.”$NEWLINE$Hmm, what’s this, a conspiracy? “If our father were dead, you’d receive half of his revenue forever”—my son Edgar? How did he bring himself to write such a thing? How could he have even entertained these thoughts in his heart? How did you get this letter? Who delivered it?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$It was not brought me, my lord. There’s the cunning of it.$NEWLINE$I found it thrown in at the casement of my closet.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Nobody delivered it, my lord. That’s what’s clever about it. It was tossed into the window of my room.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$You know the character to be your brother’s?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$You’re sure the handwriting is your brother’s?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$If the matter were good, my lord, I durst swear it were his.$NEWLINE$But in respect of that, I would fain think it were not.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$If he’d written nice things, I’d swear yes right away. But as it stands, I wish I could believe it wasn’t.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$It is his.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$But it is his handwriting?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$It is his hand, my lord, but I hope his heart is not in the contents.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$It’s his handwriting, my lord, but I hope he didn’t mean what he wrote.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Has he never before sounded you in this business?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Has he ever tested out these ideas on you before?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Never, my lord. But I have heard him oft maintain it to be fit that, sons at perfect age and fathers declined, the father should be as ward to the son, and the son manage his revenue.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Never, my lord. But I’ve often heard him argue that when sons are at their prime and their fathers are declining, the sons should be their fathers' guardians and manage their fathers' money.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$O villain, villain! His very opinion in the letter! Abhorred villain! Unnatural, detested, brutish villain—worse than
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Oh, what a villain! That’s just what he said in the letter. Evil villain! Monstrous, hateful, bestial villain! Worse

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: brutish! Go, sirrah, seek him. I’ll apprehend him. Abominable villain! Where is he?
paragraphs.translated: than a beast! Go look for him. I’ll arrest him. Horrid villain! Where is he?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I do not well know, my lord. If it shall please you to suspend your indignation against my brother till you can derive from him better testimony of his intent, you shall run a certain course—where if you violently proceed against him, mistaking his purpose, it would make a great gap in your own honor and shake in pieces the heart of his obedience. I dare pawn down my life for him that he hath wrote this to feel my affection to your honor and to no other pretense of danger.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’m not sure, my lord. But it may be a good idea to restrain your rage until you find out exactly what he meant. If you go after him and then find out that you made a mistake, it would damage your reputation and greatly undermine his loyalty to you. I’ll bet my life that he only wrote this letter to gauge my love for you, and for no other reason.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Think you so?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Do you think so?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$If your honor judge it meet, I will place you where you shall hear us confer of this and by an auricular assurance have your satisfaction—and that without any further delay than this very evening.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$If you agree, I’ll hide you somewhere where you can eavesdrop on us talking about it, and hear how he feels with your own ears. You won’t have to wait longer than until tonight.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He cannot be such a monster—
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He can’t possibly be such a monster—

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Nor is not, sure.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$And I’m sure he isn’t.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$To his father, that so tenderly and entirely loves him. Heaven and earth! Edmund, seek him out, wind me into him, I pray you. Frame the business after your own wisdom. I would unstate myself to be in a due resolution.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$—toward his own father who loves him so completely. Oh, God! Edmund, go find him. Gain his confidence for me, please. Manage him however you think best. I’d give up my rank and fortune to be free from my doubts.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I will seek him, sir, presently, convey the business as I shall find means, and acquaint you withal.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’ll find him right away, sir, and carry out the business as well as I can. Then I’ll let you know what’s happening.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend no good to us. Though the wisdom of nature can reason it thus and thus, yet nature finds itself scourged by the sequent effects. Love cools, friendship falls off, brothers divide, in cities
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$These recent eclipses of the sun and moon don’t bode well for us. Though science can explain them away, disasters still come after eclipses. Love cools off, friendships break up, and brothers become enemies. Riots

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: mutinies, in countries discord, in palaces treason, and the bond cracked ’twixt son and father. This villain of mine comes under the prediction—there’s son against father. The king falls from bias of nature—there’s father against child. We have seen the best of our time. Machinations, hollowness, treachery, and all ruinous disorders follow us disquietly to our graves. Find out this villain, Edmund. It shall lose thee nothing. Do it carefully.—And the noble and true-hearted Kent banished, his offense honesty! 'Tis strange, strange.
paragraphs.translated: break out, civil war erupts, kings are betrayed, and the bond between father and son snaps. This wicked son of mine confirms the prediction —son against father. The king acts unnaturally—father against child. We’ve seen the best our age has to offer. Conspiracies, fakery, betrayal, and disorder are all that’s left until we die. Find out what this villainous Edgar is thinking, Edmund. You won’t lose any respect. Just do it carefully.—And to think that the noble and loyal Kent has been banished, for the crime of telling the truth! It’s strange, strange.

paragraphs.original: Exit GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER exits.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$This is the excellent foppery of the world that when we are sick in fortune—often the surfeit of our own behavior—we make guilty of our disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars, as if we were villains by necessity, fools by heavenly compulsion, knaves, thieves, and treachers by spherical predominance, drunkards, liars, and adulterers by an enforced obedience of planetary influence, and all that we are evil in by a divine thrusting-on. An admirable evasion of whoremaster man, to lay his goatish disposition to the charge of a star! My father compounded with my mother under the dragon’s tail and my nativity was under Ursa Major, so that it follows I am rough and lecherous. Fut, I should have been that I am, had the maidenliest star in the firmament twinkled on my bastardizing. Edgar—
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$This is a classic example of the idiocy of the world: when we’re down and out—often because of our own excesses —we put all the blame on the sun, the moon, and the stars, as if they forced us to be bad, or the heavens compelled us to be villainous or stupid. As if we become thieves and traitors according to astrological signs or obey planetary influences to become drunks, liars, and adulterers! As if some universal power pushed us into evil deeds! What a sneaky trick it is for lustful mankind to blame our horniness on some star! My father and mother coupled when the demonic moon was descending, and I was born under the Big Dipper, so it’s inevitable that I’m rude and oversexed. Christ! I would have been what I am even if the most virginal star in the heavens had twinkled at my conception. Edgar—

paragraphs.original: Enter EDGAR$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR enters.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: and pat on ’s cue he comes like the catastrophe of the old comedy. My cue is villainous melancholy, with a sigh like Tom o' Bedlam. Oh, these eclipses do portend these divisions! Fa, sol, la, mi.
paragraphs.translated: and, speak of the devil, here he comes, right on cue. I’ve got to play the role and sigh like a poor beggar.—Oh, these eclipses predict such disorder. Fa, sol, la, mi.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$How now, brother Edmund? What serious contemplation are you in?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Hello, brother Edmund. What are you thinking about so seriously?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I am thinking, brother, of a prediction I read this other day, what should follow these eclipses.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I was thinking about what an astrologer predicted the other day. He wrote about what these eclipses mean.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Do you busy yourself about that?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Are you spending your valuable time on that?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I promise you, the effects he writes of succeed unhappily — as of unnaturalness between the child and the parent, death, dearth, dissolutions of ancient amities, divisions in state, menaces and maledictions against king and nobles, needless diffidences, banishment of friends, dissipation of cohorts, nuptial breaches, and I know not what.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Oh, I assure you the things he writes about are wretched —things like divisions between parents and children, death, famine, broken friendships, political rebellion, treason against the king and noblemen, exiled friends, dissolved armies, adultery, and I don’t know what else.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$How long have you been a sectary astronomical?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$How long have you believed in astrology?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Come, come. When saw you my father last?
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Come on. When was the last time you saw my father?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Why, the night gone by.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Why, last night.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Spake you with him?
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Did you speak to him?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Ay, two hours together.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Yes, we talked for a couple of hours.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Parted you in good terms? Found you no displeasure in him by word or countenance?
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Did you leave on good terms? Did he express any dissatisfaction with you, either in his words or his face?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$None at all.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$No, none at all.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Bethink yourself wherein you may have offended him. And at my entreaty forbear his presence till some little time hath qualified the heat of his displeasure, which at this instant so rageth in him that with the mischief of your person it would scarcely allay.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Try to remember how you might have offended him, and try to avoid spending time with him until his anger has cooled a little. Right now he’s so angry that even if he harmed you physically, he’d still be raging.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Some villain hath done me wrong.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Some villain has told lies about me.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$That’s my fear. I pray you, have a continent forbearance till the speed of his rage goes slower. And as I say, retire with me to my lodging, from whence I will fitly bring you to hear my lord speak. Pray ye, go. There’s my key. If you do stir abroad, go armed.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$That’s what I’m afraid of. I suggest you lay low until his rage cools a little. In the meantime, come home with me, and when the time is right I’ll take you to talk to him. Please go. Here’s my key. If you go outside, arm yourself.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Armed, brother?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Arm myself?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Brother, I advise you to the best. Go armed. I am no honest man if there be any good meaning towards you. I have told you what I have seen and heard—but faintly, nothing like the image and horror of it. Pray you, away.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Brother, I’m giving you good advice. Arm yourself. I’d be a liar if I told you nobody wanted to hurt you. I’ve told you what I’ve seen and heard, but I’ve toned it down a lot. I’ve spared you you the full extent of the horror that threatens you. Now please go.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Shall I hear from you anon?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Will I hear from you soon?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I do serve you in this business.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’ll help you through this business.

paragraphs.original: Exit EDGAR$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR exits.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: A credulous father, and a brother noble—$NEWLINE$Whose nature is so far from doing harms$NEWLINE$That he suspects none, on whose foolish honesty$NEWLINE$My practices ride easy. I see the business.$NEWLINE$Let me, if not by birth, have lands by wit.$NEWLINE$All with me’s meet that I can fashion fit.
paragraphs.translated: A gullible father and a brother who’s so innocent that he can’t suspect anyone else of wanting to hurt him—these are the two fools I need for my plan to work. I know exactly how to proceed. If I can’t have an estate by birthright, then I’ll get it by being clever. Any trick that works is good for me.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter GONERIL and her steward OSWALD$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated:
GONERIL enters with her
steward, OSWALD.$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$steward$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Did my father strike my gentleman$NEWLINE$For chiding of his fool?
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Did my father hit one of my attendants for scolding his fool?

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Ay, madam.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Yes, ma'am.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$By day and night he wrongs me. Every hour$NEWLINE$He flashes into one gross crime or other$NEWLINE$That sets us all at odds. I’ll not endure it.$NEWLINE$His knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us$NEWLINE$On every trifle. When he returns from hunting,$NEWLINE$I will not speak with him. Say I am sick.$NEWLINE$If you come slack of former services,$NEWLINE$You shall do well. The fault of it I’ll answer.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$He constantly offends me. Every hour he comes out with some horrible new offense that puts us all on edge. I won’t stand for it. His knights are getting out of control, and he himself reprimands us about every little detail. When he comes back from hunting, I’m not going to speak to him. Tell him I’m sick. And if you’re not as attentive in serving him as you used to be, that’ll be good. I’ll take responsibility for it.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$He’s coming, madam. I hear him.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$He’s coming, ma'am. I hear him.

paragraphs.original: Hunting horns within
paragraphs.translated: Hunting horns play offstage.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Put on what weary negligence you please,$NEWLINE$You and your fellow servants. I’ll have it come to question.$NEWLINE$If he distaste it, let him to our sister,$NEWLINE$Whose mind and mine I know in that are one,$NEWLINE$Not to be overruled. Idle old man$NEWLINE$That still would manage those authorities$NEWLINE$That he hath given away! Now by my life,$NEWLINE$Old fools are babes again and must be used$NEWLINE$With checks as flatteries, when they are seen abused.$NEWLINE$Remember what I have said.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Be as lazy and neglectful as you like around him—you and the other servants. I want it to become an issue. If he doesn’t like it, he can go live with my sister. I know she feels the same way about him that I do, and she’ll stand her ground. That useless old man still thinks he can wield all the powers he’s given away. I swear, old fools become like babies again. You can’t just flatter them; you also have to discipline them when you see that they’re misguided. Remember what I’ve told you.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Very well, madam.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Very well, ma'am.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$And let his knights have colder looks among you.$NEWLINE$What grows of it, no matter. Advise your fellows so.$NEWLINE$I would breed from hence occasions, and I shall,$NEWLINE$That I may speak. I’ll write straight to my sister$NEWLINE$To hold my very course. Go, prepare for dinner.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$And make sure the servants are less friendly to his knights. Don’t worry about the consequences. Tell your men as much. I want this to provoke confrontations, so I can give him a piece of my mind. I’ll write to my sister and tell her my plans. Now go, set up for dinner.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit in opposite directions.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter KENT disguised$NEWLINE$KENT
paragraphs.translated: KENT enters in disguise.$NEWLINE$KENT

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$If but as well I other accents borrow,$NEWLINE$That can my speech diffuse, my good intent$NEWLINE$May carry through itself to that full issue$NEWLINE$For which I razed my likeness. Now, banished Kent,$NEWLINE$If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemned,$NEWLINE$So may it come thy master, whom thou lovest,$NEWLINE$Shall find thee full of labors.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$If I can disguise my voice as well as my appearance, then I’ll be able to carry out my plan perfectly. I was banished, but hopefully I can serve the very king who condemned me. I love my master, and he’ll find me very hard-working.

paragraphs.original: Horns within Enter LEAR with attendant knights$NEWLINE$LEAR
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play offstage. LEAR enters with his attendant knights.$NEWLINE$LEAR

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Let me not stay a jot for dinner. Go get it ready.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Don’t make me wait for dinner even a moment. Get it ready immediately.

paragraphs.original: Exit attendant
paragraphs.translated: An attendant exits.

paragraphs.original: (to KENT) How now, what art thou?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: (to KENT) Well now, who are you?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$A man, sir.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$A man, sir.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$What dost thou profess? What wouldst thou with us?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$What’s your profession? What do you want from me?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I do profess to be no less than I seem—to serve him truly that will put me in trust, to love him that is honest, to converse with him that is wise and says little, to fear judgment, to fight when I cannot choose, and to eat no fish.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I profess that I’m as good as I seem—I’ll faithfully serve a master who trusts me, love those who are honest, talk with those who are wise and don’t talk too much. I’m God-fearing, I fight if I must, and I don’t eat fish.$NEWLINE$I$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$What art thou?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$But who are you?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$A very honest-hearted fellow, and as poor as the king.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$An honest guy who’s as poor as the king.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$If thou beest as poor for a subject as he’s for a king, thou'rt poor enough. What wouldst thou?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$If you’re as poor a subject as he is a king, you definitely are poor. What do you want?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Service.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$To work as a servant.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Who wouldst thou serve?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Who do you want to work for?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$You.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$You.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Dost thou know me, fellow?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Do you know me?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$No, sir. But you have that in your countenance which I would fain call master.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$No, sir, but there’s something about your face that makes me want to serve you.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$What’s that?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$What do you see in my face?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Authority.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Authority.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$What services canst thou do?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$What work can you do?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I can keep honest counsel, ride, run, mar a curious tale in telling it, and deliver a plain message bluntly. That which ordinary men are fit for, I am qualified in. And the best of me is diligence.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I can be discreet in honorable matters, ride a horse, run, tell a good story badly, and deliver a plain message bluntly. I’m good at everything that ordinary men can do. The best thing about me is that I’m hardworking.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$How old art thou?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$How old are you?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Not so young, sir, to love a woman for singing, nor so old to dote on her for anything. I have years on my back forty- eight.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Not young enough to fall in love with a woman because she sings well, but not old enough to dote on a woman for any reason. I’m forty-eight.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Follow me. Thou shalt serve me. If I like thee no worse after dinner, I will not part from thee yet.—Dinner, ho, dinner! Where’s my knave, my fool?—Go you, and call my fool hither.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Follow me. You’ll work for me. If I still like you after dinner, I won’t send you away yet.—Hey, dinnertime! Dinner! Where’s my fool?—Go call my fool and have him come here.

paragraphs.original: Exit attendant
paragraphs.translated: An attendant exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter OSWALD the steward$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD enters.$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: You, you, sirrah, where’s my daughter?
paragraphs.translated: You, sir, where’s my daughter?

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$So please you—
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I beg your pardon, sir—

paragraphs.original: Exit OSWALD$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD exits.$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$What says the fellow there? Call the clotpoll back.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$What did that guy say? Call the numbskull back in here.

paragraphs.original: Exit FIRST KNIGHT$NEWLINE$FIRST KNIGHT
paragraphs.translated: The FIRST KNIGHT exits.$NEWLINE$FIRST KNIGHT

paragraphs.original: Where’s my fool, ho? I think the world’s asleep.
paragraphs.translated: Where’s my fool? You’d think everyone was asleep.

paragraphs.original: Enter FIRST KNIGHT$NEWLINE$FIRST KNIGHT
paragraphs.translated: The FIRST KNIGHT enters again.$NEWLINE$FIRST KNIGHT

paragraphs.original: How now? Where’s that mongrel?
paragraphs.translated: So what’s going on? Where’s that dog?

paragraphs.original: FIRST KNIGHT$NEWLINE$He says, my lord, your daughter is not well.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST KNIGHT$NEWLINE$He says your daughter’s not feeling well, my lord.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Why came not the slave back to me when I called him.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Why didn’t the jerk come back to me when I called him?

paragraphs.original: FIRST KNIGHT$NEWLINE$Sir, he answered me in the roundest manner he would not.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST KNIGHT$NEWLINE$Sir, he told me quite bluntly that he didn’t feel like it.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$He would not?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Didn’t feel like it?

paragraphs.original: FIRST KNIGHT$NEWLINE$My lord, I know not what the matter is, but to my judgment your highness is not entertained with that ceremonious affection as you were wont. There’s a great abatement of kindness appears as well in the general dependants as in the duke himself also, and your daughter.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST KNIGHT$NEWLINE$My lord, I don’t know what’s going on, but it seems to me that your highness isn’t being treated as politely as before. The servants, the duke, and your daughter all seem to be treating you less kindly.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Ha! Sayest thou so?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Huh! Do you really mean that?

paragraphs.original: FIRST KNIGHT$NEWLINE$I beseech you pardon me, my lord, if I be mistaken—for my duty cannot be silent when I think your highness wronged.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST KNIGHT$NEWLINE$Please forgive me if I’m mistaken, my lord—but I can’t keep quiet when I think you’re being insulted.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Thou but rememberest me of mine own conception. I have perceived a most faint neglect of late, which I have rather blamed as mine own jealous curiosity than as a very pretense and purpose of unkindness. I will look further into ’t. But where’s my fool? I have not seen him this two days.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, you’re just reminding me of something I’ve also noticed. I’ve felt neglected recently, but I decided that it was more likely that I was being hypersensitive than that they were intentionally unkind. I’ll look into it further. But where’s my fool? I haven’t seen him for two days.

paragraphs.original: FIRST KNIGHT$NEWLINE$Since my young lady’s going into France, sir, the fool hath much pined away.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST KNIGHT$NEWLINE$Ever since Cordelia left for France, sir, the fool has been depressed.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No more of that. I have noted it well. Go you and tell my daughter I would speak with her.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Let’s not talk about it. I’ve noticed it myself. Go and tell my daughter I want to speak with her.

paragraphs.original: Exit an attendant
paragraphs.translated: An attendant exits.

paragraphs.original: Go you, call hither my fool.
paragraphs.translated: And you, go call my fool.

paragraphs.original: Exit another attendant
paragraphs.translated: Another attendant exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter OSWALD$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD enters.$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: O you sir, you, come you hither, sir. Who am I, sir?
paragraphs.translated: You there, sir, come here please. Who am I, sir?

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$My lady’s father.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$The father of the lady of the house, sir.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$“My lady’s father”? My lord’s knave, your whoreson dog!$NEWLINE$You slave, you cur!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$“The father of the lady of the house”? You scoundrel! You lowlife son-of-a-bitch! You dog, you peasant!

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I am none of these, my lord. I beseech your pardon.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I’m sorry, sir, but I’m not any of those things.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Do you bandy looks with me, you rascal?$NEWLINE$(he strikes OSWALD)$NEWLINE$(he strikes$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Are you making faces at me, you scoundrel? (he hits OSWALD)$NEWLINE$(he hits$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I’ll not be strucken, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I won’t be hit, my lord.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(tripping OSWALD)$NEWLINE$(tripping$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Nor tripped neither, you base football player.
paragraphs.translated:
KENT$NEWLINE$(tripping OSWALD) Or tripped, you lowlife
football player?$NEWLINE$(tripping$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$football$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$(to KENT) I thank thee, fellow. Thou servest me, and I’ll love thee.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$(to KENT) Thank you, sir. You serve me well, and I’ll love you for it.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(to OSWALD) Come, sir, arise, away! I’ll teach you differences. Away, away. If you will measure your lubber’s length again, tarry. But away, go to. Have you wisdom? So.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$(to OSWALD) Come on, sir, get up and get out of here! I’ll teach you to respect your betters. If you want me to trip you again, then stick around. If not, get going. Go on. Do you know what’s good for you? There you go.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit OSWALD$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD exits.$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Now, my friendly knave, I thank thee.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Now, my friendly servant, thank you.

paragraphs.original: Enter FOOL$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated:
The
FOOL enters.$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: (gives KENT money) There’s earnest of thy service.$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$money)
paragraphs.translated: (giving KENT money) Here’s a token of my gratitude.$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$money)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Let me hire him too.—Here’s my coxcomb.$NEWLINE$(offers KENT his cap)$NEWLINE$(offers$NEWLINE$his cap)
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Wait, let me hire him too.—Here’s my fool’s cap, a token of my gratitude. (he offers KENT his cap)$NEWLINE$(he offers$NEWLINE$his cap)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$How now, my pretty knave? How dost thou?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Well hello, my good boy. How are you doing?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(to KENT) Sirrah, you were best take my coxcomb.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(to KENT) Guy, you’d better take my cap.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Why, Fool?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Why, Fool?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Why? For taking one’s part that’s out of favor. Nay, an thou canst not smile as the wind sits, thou'lt catch cold shortly. There, take my coxcomb. Why, this fellow has banished two on ’s daughters, and did the third a blessing against his will. If thou follow him, thou must needs wear my coxcomb.—How now, nuncle? Would I had two coxcombs and two daughters.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Why? For standing up for this unpopular king. No, if you can’t adjust to political changes, you’ll suffer for it. There, take my fool’s cap. This guy here has banished two of his daughters and blessed the third one without intending to. If you work for him, you’re a fool and should wear a fool’s cap.—So how’s it going, uncle? I wish I had two fool’s caps and two daughters.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Why, my boy?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Why, my boy?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$If I gave them all my living, I’d keep my coxcombs myself.$NEWLINE$There’s mine. Beg another of thy daughters.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$If I gave them all I own, I’d have two fool’s caps for myself. Here’s mine. Ask your daughters for another one.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Take heed, sirrah—the whip.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Watch out, boy—remember I can whip you.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Truth’s a dog that must to kennel. He must be whipped out, when Lady Brach may stand by th' fire and stink.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I get whipped like a dog for telling the truth, while Lady Bitch gets to stand around the fire and stink the place up with her false words.
