paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$A pestilent gall to me!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$A constant pain to me!

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Sirrah, I’ll teach thee a speech.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I’ll recite something for you, guy.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Do.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Yes, do that.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Mark it, nuncle.$NEWLINE$Have more than thou showest,$NEWLINE$Speak less than thou knowest,$NEWLINE$Lend less than thou owest,$NEWLINE$Ride more than thou goest,$NEWLINE$Learn more than thou trowest,$NEWLINE$Set less than thou throwest,$NEWLINE$Leave thy drink and thy whore$NEWLINE$And keep in-a-door,$NEWLINE$And thou shalt have more$NEWLINE$Than two tens to a score.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Listen up, uncle.$NEWLINE$Have more than you show,$NEWLINE$Speak less than you know,$NEWLINE$Lend less than you owe.$NEWLINE$Ride more than you walk,$NEWLINE$Don’t believe everything you hear,$NEWLINE$Don’t bet everything on one throw of the dice,$NEWLINE$Leave behind your booze and your whore,$NEWLINE$And stay indoors,$NEWLINE$And you’ll end up with more$NEWLINE$Than two tens to a twenty.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$This is nothing, Fool.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$That makes no sense, Fool. It’s nothing.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Then ’tis like the breath of an unfee’d lawyer. You gave me nothing for ’t.—Can you make no use of nothing, nuncle?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$In that case it’s like the words of an unpaid lawyer. You paid me nothing for it. Can’t you make any use of nothing, uncle?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Why no, boy. Nothing can be made out of nothing.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Why, no, boy. Nothing can be made out of nothing.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(to KENT) Prithee, tell him so much the rent of his land comes to. He will not believe a fool.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(to KENT) Please tell him that his income is nothing, now that he’s given his lands away. He won’t believe a fool.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$A bitter fool.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$You’re a bitter fool.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Dost thou know the difference, my boy, between a bitter fool and a sweet fool?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Do you know the difference, my boy, between a bitter fool and a sweet one?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, lad. Teach me.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, son. Tell me.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$That lord that counseled thee$NEWLINE$To give away thy land,$NEWLINE$Come place him here by me.$NEWLINE$Do thou for him stand.$NEWLINE$The sweet and bitter fool$NEWLINE$Will presently appear—$NEWLINE$The one in motley here,$NEWLINE$The other found out there.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Bring here$NEWLINE$The gentleman who advised you$NEWLINE$To give away your land.$NEWLINE$You can stand in his place.$NEWLINE$The sweet and bitter fool$NEWLINE$Will appear right away.$NEWLINE$The sweet fool in a fool’s costume—that’s me.$NEWLINE$The bitter one is the other one—that’s you.LEAR

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Dost thou call me fool, boy?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Are you calling me a fool, boy?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$All thy other titles thou hast given away that thou wast born with.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well, you’ve given away all your other rightful titles. The title of “fool” is the only one left.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$This is not altogether fool, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Kent$NEWLINE$This isn’t entirely a joke, your highness.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, faith, lords and great men will not let me. If I had a monopoly out, they would have part on ’t. And ladies too— they will not let me have all fool to myself; they’ll be snatching. Give me an egg, nuncle, and I’ll give thee two crowns.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$No. I wish I could be a complete joker—but so many lords and important men are also playing fools that I can’t have a monopoly on it. Ladies too—they’re always snatching away my role as the biggest fool.—Uncle, give me an egg, and I’ll give you two crowns.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$What two crowns shall they be?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Which two crowns would those be?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Why—after I have cut the egg i' th' middle and eat up the meat—the two crowns of the egg. When thou clovest thy crown i' th' middle, and gavest away both parts, thou borest thy ass o' th' back o'er the dirt. Thou hadst little wit in thy bald crown when thou gavest thy golden one away. If I speak like myself in this, let him be whipped that first finds it so.$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Fools had ne'er less wit in a year,$NEWLINE$Fools had ne'er less wit in a year,$NEWLINE$For wise men are grown foppish.$NEWLINE$For wise men are grown foppish.$NEWLINE$They know not how their wits to wear,$NEWLINE$They know not how their wits to wear,$NEWLINE$Their manners are so apish.$NEWLINE$Their manners are so apish.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Well, when I cut the egg in half and eat the whites, the yolk will be in two parts like two golden crowns. When you cut your own crown and kingdom in half and gave away both parts, you were as foolish as the old man in the old story who carries his donkey on his back instead of letting the donkey carry him. You didn’t have much brains inside the bald crown of your head when you gave away the gold crown of your kingdom. If I’m telling the truth like a fool in saying all this, whip the first person who thinks I sound foolish.$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$Fools have had a hard time this year.$NEWLINE$Fools have had a hard time this year.$NEWLINE$They’ve been displaced by wise men who’ve grown foolish.$NEWLINE$They’ve been displaced by wise men who’ve grown foolish.$NEWLINE$These men no longer know how to use their brains,$NEWLINE$These men no longer know how to use their brains,$NEWLINE$And they don’t know how to behave except by foolishly imitating others.$NEWLINE$And they don’t know how to behave except by foolishly imitating others.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$When were you wont to be so full of songs, sirrah?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$When did you become so fond of singing, boy?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$I have used it, nuncle, ever since thou madest thy daughters thy mothers. For when thou gavest them the rod, and put’st down thine own breeches,$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Then they for sudden joy did weep$NEWLINE$Then they for sudden joy did weep$NEWLINE$And I for sorrow sung,$NEWLINE$And I for sorrow sung,$NEWLINE$That such a king should play bo-peep$NEWLINE$That such a king should play bo-peep$NEWLINE$And go the fools among.$NEWLINE$And go the fools among.$NEWLINE$Prithee, nuncle, keep a schoolmaster that can teach thy fool to lie. I would fain learn to lie.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I’ve been singing ever since you made your daughters into your mothers by giving them all your power. That’s when you gave them the spanking paddle and pulled your pants down,$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$Then your daughters wept for joy,$NEWLINE$Then your daughters wept for joy,$NEWLINE$And I sang in sadness,$NEWLINE$And I sang in sadness,$NEWLINE$Seeing such a king become$NEWLINE$Seeing such a king become$NEWLINE$A child and a fool.$NEWLINE$A child and a fool.$NEWLINE$Please, uncle, hire a teacher who can teach your fool to lie. I want to learn how to lie.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$An you lie, sirrah, we’ll have you whipped.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$If you lie, boy, we’ll have you whipped.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are. They’ll have me whipped for speaking true, thou'lt have me whipped for lying, and sometimes I am whipped for holding my peace. I had rather be any kind o' thing than a fool. And yet I would not be thee, nuncle. Thou hast pared thy wit o' both sides and left nothing i' th' middle. Here comes one o' the parings.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I’m amazed how similar you and your daughters are. They want to whip me for telling the truth, you want to whip me for lying, and sometimes I’m even whipped for keeping quiet. I’d rather be anything besides a fool. And yet I wouldn’t want to be you, uncle. When you gave away pieces of your kingdom, it’s as if you cut off pieces on both sides of your brain and left nothing in the middle. Here comes the owner of one piece.

paragraphs.original: Enter GONERIL$NEWLINE$GONERIL
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL enters.$NEWLINE$GONERIL

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$How now, daughter? What makes that frontlet on?$NEWLINE$Methinks you are too much of late i' th' frown.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$What’s going on, daughter? Why are you frowning like that? I think you’ve been frowning too much recently.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) Thou wast a pretty fellow when thou hadst no need to care for her frowning. Now thou art an O without a figure. I am better than thou art now. I am a fool. Thou art nothing.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL) Yes, forsooth, I will hold my tongue. So your face bids me, though you say nothing. Mum, mum,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$He that keeps nor crust nor crumb,$NEWLINE$Weary of all, shall want some.$NEWLINE$(indicates LEAR) That’s a shelled peascod.$NEWLINE$(indicates$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) You were better off when you didn’t have to care whether she frowned or not. Now you’re a big zero, with no digit in front of it to give it value. I’m better than you are—I’m a fool and you’re nothing.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL) Yes, I promise I’ll shut up. That’s what you’re telling me with that expression on your face, even though you don’t say anything. Mum, mum,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$The man who gives away his crust and his crumbs$NEWLINE$Will discover that he needs some crumbs back.$NEWLINE$(pointing at LEAR) That guy is an empty pea pod.$NEWLINE$(pointing at$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) Not only, sir, this your all-licensed fool,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$But other of your insolent retinue$NEWLINE$Do hourly carp and quarrel, breaking forth$NEWLINE$In rank and not-to-be-endurèd riots. Sir,$NEWLINE$I had thought by making this well known unto you$NEWLINE$To have found a safe redress, but now grow fearful$NEWLINE$By what yourself too late have spoke and done$NEWLINE$That you protect this course and put it on$NEWLINE$By your allowance—which if you should, the fault$NEWLINE$Would not ’scape censure, nor the redresses sleep$NEWLINE$Which in the tender of a wholesome weal$NEWLINE$Might in their working do you that offense,
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) It’s not just your fool here who can say whatever he wants, but your whole obnoxious entourage keeps whining and arguing, bursting out in intolerably vicious riots. Sir, I thought you could put an end to all this if I told you about it. But judging by what you’ve said and done recently, I’m worried that you don’t mind this chaos, and even approve of it. If that’s true, it’s shameful. I realize that restraining your knights$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Which else were shame, that then necessity$NEWLINE$Will call discreet proceeding.
paragraphs.translated: will damage your reputation with them—and under ordinary circumstances it would be unfortunate to have them see you as an ogre. However, this is an extreme situation, and it’s more important to control it than to worry about how you’ll look.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$For you know, nuncle,$NEWLINE$The hedge-sparrow fed the cuckoo so long,$NEWLINE$That it’s had it head bit off by it young.$NEWLINE$So out went the candle and we were left darkling.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$You know, uncle,$NEWLINE$A sparrow once raised a cuckoo in its nest$NEWLINE$Until the cuckoo grew up and bit the sparrow’s head off.$NEWLINE$So the candle went out and now we’re all in the dark.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Are you our daughter?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Are you my daughter?

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Come, sir,$NEWLINE$I would you would make use of that good wisdom$NEWLINE$Whereof I know you are fraught, and put away$NEWLINE$These dispositions that of late transform you$NEWLINE$From what you rightly are.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Come on, sir. I know you’re very wise, and I wish you would use some of that wisdom to snap out of this mood you’ve been in lately and be your true self again.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$May not an ass know when the cart draws the horse?$NEWLINE$Whoop, Jug! I love thee.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Even an idiot knows when the normal order has been inverted and the cart is pulling the horse. Whoo-hoo, honey, I love you!

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Does any here know me? Why, this is not Lear.$NEWLINE$Doth Lear walk thus? Speak thus? Where are his eyes?$NEWLINE$Either his notion weakens, or his discernings$NEWLINE$Are lethargied. Ha, sleeping or waking?$NEWLINE$Sure, ’tis not so.$NEWLINE$Who is it that can tell me who I am?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Does anyone here know who I am? I’m not Lear. Does Lear walk and talk like this? Where are his eyes? Either his mind is losing its grip or his judgment is screwy.—Hey, am I awake? I don’t think so. Who can tell me who I am?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Lear’s shadow.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$You’re Lear’s shadow.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$I would learn that. For by the marks$NEWLINE$Of sovereignty, knowledge, and reason,$NEWLINE$I should be false persuaded I had daughters.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I’d like to find out who I am, since the obvious signs around me wrongly indicate that I’ve got daughters.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Which they will make an obedient father.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Daughters who can make you obey them.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL) Your name, fair gentlewoman?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL) What’s your name, my dear lady?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$This admiration, sir, is much o' th' savor$NEWLINE$Of other your new pranks. I do beseech you$NEWLINE$To understand my purposes aright.$NEWLINE$As you are old and reverend, should be wise.$NEWLINE$Here do you keep a hundred knights and squires,$NEWLINE$Men so disordered, so debauched and bold$NEWLINE$That this our court, infected with their manners,$NEWLINE$Shows like a riotous inn. Epicurism and lust$NEWLINE$Make it more like a tavern or a brothel$NEWLINE$Than a graced palace. The shame itself doth speak$NEWLINE$For instant remedy. Be then desired$NEWLINE$By her that else will take the thing she begs,$NEWLINE$A little to disquantity your train,$NEWLINE$And the remainder that shall still depend$NEWLINE$To be such men as may besort your age,$NEWLINE$Which know themselves and you.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$This fake astonishment of yours is just like your other pranks. I’m asking you to understand my point of view. Since you’re old and respected, you should be wise. But you’re keeping a hundred knights here who are so disorderly, vulgar, and obnoxious that our noble court is starting to look like a noisy cheap hotel. They’re such oversexed gluttons that I feel like we’re living in a pub or a whorehouse rather than a respectable palace. It’s shameful, and we have to make some changes right away. Please, as a favor to me—and if you don’t do it for me, I’ll do it myself—reduce the number of your knights a little. Keep the ones who are older, like you, and who act their age.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Darkness and devils!$NEWLINE$Saddle my horses. Call my train together.—$NEWLINE$Degenerate bastard, I’ll not trouble thee.$NEWLINE$Yet have I left a daughter.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Hell and damnation! Saddle up my horses. Call my knights together.$NEWLINE$I won’t bother you any more, you monstrous bastard. You’re not really my daughter, but I still have one daughter left.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$You strike my people, and your disordered rabble$NEWLINE$Make servants of their betters.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$You hit my servants, and your disorderly mob of knights treat their superiors like servants.

paragraphs.original: Enter ALBANY$NEWLINE$ALBANY
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY enters.$NEWLINE$ALBANY

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Woe that too late repents!—$NEWLINE$(to ALBANY)     O sir, are you come?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Is it your will? Speak, sir.—Prepare my horses.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$You’ll be sorry later, but it’ll be too late. (to ALBANY) Oh, sir, are you here now? You decided to come? Answer me, sir. (to attendants) Get my horses ready.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to attendants)

paragraphs.original: Exit attendant
paragraphs.translated: An attendant exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Ingratitude, thou marble-hearted fiend,$NEWLINE$More hideous when thou show’st thee in a child$NEWLINE$Than the sea monster.
paragraphs.translated: Ingratitude is always hideous, but an ungrateful child is uglier than a sea monster!

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Pray, sir, be patient.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Please, sir, be patient.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL)   Detested kite, thou liest!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$My train are men of choice and rarest parts$NEWLINE$That all particulars of duty know$NEWLINE$And in the most exact regard support$NEWLINE$The worships of their name. O most small fault,$NEWLINE$How ugly didst thou in Cordelia show,$NEWLINE$Which like an engine wrenched my frame of nature$NEWLINE$From the fixed place, drew from heart all love,$NEWLINE$And added to the gall! O Lear, Lear, Lear!$NEWLINE$(strikes his head)$NEWLINE$(strikes his head)$NEWLINE$Beat at this gate that let thy folly in$NEWLINE$And thy dear judgment out!—Go, go, my people.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL) You disgusting vulture, you’re a liar! My knights are the finest men who can attend a king, and they meticulously uphold their reputation. Oh, how ugly did Cordelia’s small flaw appear! And now Cordelia’s small flaw has bent me completely out of shape and sucked all the love out of my heart. Oh, Lear, Lear, Lear! (he hits himself on the head) Let me beat this portal that let my good sense out and my foolishness in!— Go, go, people.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(he hits himself on the head)

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$My lord, I am guiltless, as I am ignorant,$NEWLINE$Of what hath moved you.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$My lord, I have no idea what’s upset you, but whatever it is, I had nothing to do with it.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$It may be so, my lord.$NEWLINE$Hear, Nature, hear, dear goddess, hear!$NEWLINE$Suspend thy purpose if thou didst intend$NEWLINE$To make this creature fruitful.$NEWLINE$Into her womb convey sterility.$NEWLINE$Dry up in her the organs of increase,$NEWLINE$And from her derogate body never spring$NEWLINE$A babe to honor her. If she must teem,$NEWLINE$Create her child of spleen, that it may live$NEWLINE$And be a thwart disnatured torment to her.$NEWLINE$Let it stamp wrinkles in her brow of youth,$NEWLINE$With cadent tears fret channels in her cheeks,
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$That may be true, my lord. Ah, dear Nature, my goddess, listen to me! Change your plans if you ever intended for this woman to have children. Make her sterile and dry up her womb so that no baby will ever come out of her body and honor her. If she must give birth, make her child a bad seed who will torment her, give her a forehead wrinkled with worry, make her cry until her cheeks are sunken.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Turn all her mother’s pains and benefits$NEWLINE$To laughter and contempt, that she may feel—$NEWLINE$That she may feel$NEWLINE$How sharper than a serpent’s tooth it is$NEWLINE$To have a thankless child.—Away, away!
paragraphs.translated: Let it be a wicked child who mocks the mother who cares for it. Make my daughter feel—make her feel how an ungrateful child hurts worse than a snakebite.—Now let’s leave. Go!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LEAR, FOOL, KENT, FIRST KNIGHT and the other attendants$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$FIRST KNIGHT
paragraphs.translated: LEAR, the FOOL, KENT, FIRST KNIGHT, and attendant knights exit.$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$FIRST KNIGHT

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Now gods that we adore, whereof comes this?
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Dear gods in heaven, what’s the reason for this?

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Never afflict yourself to know more of it,$NEWLINE$But let his disposition have that scope$NEWLINE$That dotage gives it.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Don’t even bother to ask the reasons. Just let him rant and rave. He’s senile.

paragraphs.original: Enter LEAR and FOOL$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: LEAR enters with the FOOL.$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$What, fifty of my followers at a clap?$NEWLINE$Within a fortnight?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$What, fifty of my knights dismissed all at once? In only two weeks?

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$What’s the matter, sir?
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$What are you talking about, sir?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$I’ll tell thee.$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL) Life and death! I am ashamed$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$That thou hast power to shake my manhood thus,$NEWLINE$That these hot tears which break from me perforce$NEWLINE$Should make thee worth them. Blasts and fogs upon thee!$NEWLINE$Th' untented woundings of a father’s curse$NEWLINE$Pierce every sense about thee! Old fond eyes,$NEWLINE$Beweep this cause again, I’ll pluck ye out
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you. (to GONERIL) I’m ashamed that you have the power to upset me like this, as though you’re worth the tears you’re making me shed. Damn you! May you feel every pain a father’s curse can bring! If I cry again because of you, I’ll rip my eyes out of their sockets and throw them and their wet tears down to moisten the earth. Has it come to this? Then so be it. I have one more daughter who I’m sure is kind. When$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And cast you, with the waters that you loose,$NEWLINE$To temper clay. Yea, is ’t come to this?$NEWLINE$Ha? Let it be so. I have another daughter,$NEWLINE$Who I am sure is kind and comfortable.$NEWLINE$When she shall hear this of thee, with her nails$NEWLINE$She’ll flay thy wolvish visage. Thou shalt find$NEWLINE$That I’ll resume the shape which thou dost think$NEWLINE$I have cast off for ever. Thou shalt, I warrant thee.
paragraphs.translated: she hears what you’ve done to me, she’ll tear up your wolflike face with her fingernails. And then you’ll see that despite what you thought, I’ll be as powerful as I was before. You’ll see, I promise you.

paragraphs.original: Exit LEAR$NEWLINE$LEAR
paragraphs.translated: LEAR exits.$NEWLINE$LEAR

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Do you mark that, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Did you hear that?

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$I cannot be so partial, Goneril,$NEWLINE$To the great love I bear you—
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Goneril, you know how much I love you, but still I have to say—

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Pray you, content.$NEWLINE$Come, sire, no more.—What, Oswald, ho!$NEWLINE$(to FOOL) You, sir, more knave than fool, after your master.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Shush, please. Come, sir, no more.—Oswald, come here! (to FOOL) And you, sir, you’re more of a rascal than a fool. Go follow your master.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Nuncle Lear, nuncle Lear, tarry and take the fool with thee.$NEWLINE$A fox when one has caught her$NEWLINE$And such a daughter$NEWLINE$Should sure to the slaughter,$NEWLINE$If my cap would buy a halter.$NEWLINE$So the fool follows after.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Uncle Lear, uncle Lear, wait. Take your fool with you.$NEWLINE$A fox you’ve trapped$NEWLINE$And such a daughter$NEWLINE$Should both be slaughtered,$NEWLINE$If my fool’s cap is worth a rope to bind them.$NEWLINE$So the fool follows you.

paragraphs.original: Exit FOOL$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: The FOOL exits.$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$This man hath had good counsel—a hundred knights!$NEWLINE$'Tis politic and safe to let him keep$NEWLINE$At point a hundred knights, yes, that on every dream,$NEWLINE$Each buzz, each fancy, each complaint, dislike,$NEWLINE$He may enguard his dotage with their powers$NEWLINE$And hold our lives in mercy?—Oswald, I say!
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$My father can’t think straight—a hundred knights! Just imagine the risk we run in letting him keep a hundred knights around! He could use them to strong-arm us into bowing to every little whim of his, and keep us at his mercy.—Oswald, where are you?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Well, you may fear too far.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$You may be exaggerating the risks.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Safer than trust too far.$NEWLINE$Let me still take away the harms I fear,$NEWLINE$Not fear still to be taken. I know his heart.$NEWLINE$What he hath uttered I have writ my sister.$NEWLINE$If she sustain him and his hundred knights$NEWLINE$When I have showed th' unfitness—
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$That’s better than exaggerating our trust. It’s always better to get rid of what you’re scared of than to be afraid. I know how his mind works. I’ve written to my sister telling her everything he’s said. If she welcomes him and his hundred knights after I’ve shown how inappropriately he’s behaved—

paragraphs.original: Enter OSWALD the steward$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD enters.$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Here, madam.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Here, ma'am.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$How now, Oswald?$NEWLINE$What, have you writ that letter to my sister?
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Well, Oswald? Have you written that letter to my sister yet?

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Ay, madam.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Yes, ma'am.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Take you some company, and away to horse.$NEWLINE$Inform her full of my particular fear,$NEWLINE$And thereto add such reasons of your own$NEWLINE$As may compact it more. Get you gone$NEWLINE$And hasten your return.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Take some men and horses and go to her. Tell her everything that worries me. Add details of your own to back up what I’m saying. Now go, and hurry back.

paragraphs.original: Exit OSWALD$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD exits.$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: No, no, my lord,$NEWLINE$Though I condemn not, yet under pardon$NEWLINE$You are much more attasked for want of wisdom$NEWLINE$Than praised for harmful mildness.
paragraphs.translated: No, no, my husband, I’m not angry that you urge me to deal more gently with my father. But you’re showing a lack of wisdom that that is much more noticeable than your tenderness toward him.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$How far your eyes may pierce I cannot tell.$NEWLINE$Striving to better, oft we mar what’s well.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Maybe you know more than I do. But people often screw things up trying to make them better.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Nay, then—
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$No, not at all—

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Well, well, th' event.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$All right, all right. Time will tell.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LEAR, KENT disguised, and FOOL$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: LEAR enters with KENT in disguise, and the FOOL.$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$(to KENT, giving him letters) Go you before to Gloucester with these letters. Acquaint my daughter no further with anything you know than comes from her demand out of the letter. If your diligence be not speedy, I shall be there afore you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$, giving him letters)
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$(to KENT, giving him letters) Go ahead of us and deliver these letters to the Earl of Gloucester. Answer my daughter’s questions about the letter, but don’t tell her anything else you know. If you’re not quick enough, I’ll get there before you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$, giving him letters)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I will not sleep, my lord, till I have delivered your letter.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I won’t sleep until I’ve delivered your letter, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exit KENT$NEWLINE$KENT
paragraphs.translated: KENT exits.$NEWLINE$KENT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$If a man’s brains were in ’s heels, were ’t not in danger of kibes?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$If a man’s brain were in his feet, wouldn’t it be susceptible to frostbite?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Ay, boy.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Yes, boy.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Then, I prithee, be merry. Thy wit shall ne'er go slipshod.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$In that case, cheer up. Your brains won’t need slippers to protect them from frostbite, since your brains aren’t in your feet—if they were you wouldn’t take this useless journey to see Regan.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Ha, ha, ha!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Ha, ha, ha!

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Shalt see thy other daughter will use thee kindly. For though she’s as like this as a crab’s like an apple, yet I can tell what I can tell.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Your other daughter Regan will treat you kindly, you’ll see. Even though she’s as similar to Goneril as one crabapple is like another, still… I know what I know.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Why, what canst thou tell, my boy?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$And what do you know, boy?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$She will taste as like this as a crab does to a crab. Thou canst tell why one’s nose stands i' th' middle on ’s face?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I know that Regan will taste just like Goneril—both of them sour crabapples. Do you know why the nose is in the middle of a person’s face?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$No.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Why, to keep one’s eyes of either side ’s nose, that what a man cannot smell out, he may spy into.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Why, to keep the eyes on the sides, so that you can see anything that you can’t sniff out.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$I did her wrong—
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I was wrong to her—

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Canst tell how an oyster makes his shell?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Do you know how an oyster makes its shell?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$No.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Nor I neither. But I can tell why a snail has a house.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Me neither. But I know why a snail carries its house on its back.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Why?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Why?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Why, to put ’s head in—not to give it away to his daughters and leave his horns without a case.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$So that he always has a roof over his head. He can’t give his house away to his daughters, leaving himself without shelter.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$I will forget my nature. So kind a father!—Be my horses ready?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I want to forget what I am. Such a kind father!—Are my horses ready?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Thy asses are gone about 'em. The reason why the seven stars are no more than seven is a pretty reason.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Your attendant asses are getting the horses ready. There’s a nice reason why the constellation Pleiades has only seven stars in it.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Because they are not eight?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Because it doesn’t have eight?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Yes indeed. Thou wouldst make a good fool.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$That’s right. You’d make a good fool.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$To take ’t again perforce— Monster ingratitude!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I could take back my crown by force—What outrageous ingratitude!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$If thou wert my fool, nuncle, I’d have thee beaten for being old before thy time.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$If you were my fool, uncle, I’d have you beaten for getting old before your time.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$How’s that?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$How’s that?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst been wise.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$You’re not supposed to get old until you’re wise.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$O, let me not be mad, not mad, sweet heaven!$NEWLINE$I would not be mad.$NEWLINE$Keep me in temper. I would not be mad.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Oh, dear God, don’t let me go mad! Keep me balanced and sane. I don’t want to go mad.

paragraphs.original: Enter a GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated: A GENTLEMAN enters.$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN

paragraphs.original: How now? Are the horses ready?
paragraphs.translated: So, are the horses ready?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Ready, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$They’re ready, my lord.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Come, boy.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Come on, boy.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LEAR and GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated: LEAR and the GENTLEMAN exit.$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$She that’s a maid now and laughs at my departure,$NEWLINE$Shall not be a maid long unless things be cut shorter.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(speaking to the audience) Any girl who laughs because I’m going with the king is too foolish to remain a virgin very long.$NEWLINE$(speaking to the audience)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter EDMUND the bastard and CURAN, severally$NEWLINE$EDMUND$NEWLINE$CURAN
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND and CURAN enter from different directions.$NEWLINE$EDMUND$NEWLINE$CURAN

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Save thee, Curan.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Hello, Curan.

paragraphs.original: CURAN$NEWLINE$And you, sir. I have been with your father and given him notice that the Duke of Cornwall and Regan his duchess will be here with him this night.
paragraphs.translated: CURAN$NEWLINE$Hello, sir. I just saw your father the Lord Gloucester and notified him that the Duke of Cornwall and his wife Regan will stay with him here tonight.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$How comes that?
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Why is that?

paragraphs.original: CURAN$NEWLINE$Nay, I know not. You have heard of the news abroad?— I mean the whispered ones, for they are yet but ear-kissing arguments.
paragraphs.translated: CURAN$NEWLINE$I don’t know. Have you heard the latest news?—I mean the whispered rumors, since that’s all they are at this point.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Not I. Pray you, what are they?
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$No, I haven’t. What’s going on?

paragraphs.original: CURAN$NEWLINE$Have you heard of no likely wars toward ’twixt the two$NEWLINE$Dukes of Cornwall and Albany?
paragraphs.translated: CURAN$NEWLINE$You haven’t heard of the war brewing between the Dukes of Cornwall and Albany?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Not a word.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Not a word.

paragraphs.original: CURAN$NEWLINE$You may do then in time. Fare you well, sir.
paragraphs.translated: CURAN$NEWLINE$You may hear about it soon. Goodbye, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit CURAN$NEWLINE$CURAN
paragraphs.translated: CURAN exits.$NEWLINE$CURAN

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$The duke be here tonight? The better—best!$NEWLINE$This weaves itself perforce into my business.$NEWLINE$My father hath set guard to take my brother.$NEWLINE$And I have one thing, of a queasy question,$NEWLINE$Which I must act. Briefness and fortune, work!—$NEWLINE$Brother, a word. Descend, brother, I say.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$The duke will be here tonight? All the better—in fact it’s the best that could happen. His arrival fits perfectly into my plan. My father’s ready to arrest my brother, and I have one risky thing to do. Fast work and a little luck are all I need.—Brother, could I have a word with you? Come down, brother.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter EDGAR$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR enters.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: My father watches. O sir, fly this place.$NEWLINE$Intelligence is given where you are hid.$NEWLINE$You have now the good advantage of the night.$NEWLINE$Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwall aught?$NEWLINE$He’s coming hither—now, i' th' night, i' th' haste,$NEWLINE$And Regan with him. Have you nothing said$NEWLINE$Upon his party 'gainst the Duke of Albany?$NEWLINE$Advise yourself.
paragraphs.translated: Father is on the lookout. Get out of here quickly! It has leaked out that you’re hiding here. If you leave now, you can take advantage of the darkness and sneak away. You haven’t said anything against the Duke of Cornwall, have you? He’s rushing on his way here right now, and Regan’s with him. Have you said anything against Cornwall or Albany? Think about it.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I am sure on ’t, not a word.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I’m sure of it. I haven’t said a word.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I hear my father coming. Pardon me.$NEWLINE$In cunning I must draw my sword upon you.$NEWLINE$Draw. Seem to defend yourself. Now quit you well.—$NEWLINE$(loudly) Yield! Come before my father. Light, ho! Here!$NEWLINE$(loudly)$NEWLINE$(aside to Edgar) Fly, brother, fly.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(loudly)$NEWLINE$(loudly)$NEWLINE$Torches, torches!$NEWLINE$(aside to Edgar) So, farewell.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I hear my father coming. Forgive me. I have to pretend to threaten you with my sword. Draw your sword too, as if you’re defending yourself. Be convincing. (loudly) Give up! Go see my father.—Bring in some light!(speaking so that only EDGAR can hear) Run, brother. (loudly) Torches, bring in the torches! (speaking so that only EDGAR can hear) Goodbye, then.$NEWLINE$(loudly)$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)$NEWLINE$(loudly)$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: Exit EDGAR$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR exits.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: Some blood drawn on me would beget opinion.$NEWLINE$Of my more fierce endeavor.$NEWLINE$(cuts his own arm)$NEWLINE$(cuts his own arm)$NEWLINE$I have seen drunkards$NEWLINE$Do more than this in sport.—Father, father!—$NEWLINE$Stop, stop!—No help?
paragraphs.translated: If I had some blood on me it would look like I’d fought more fiercely. (he cuts his own arm) I’ve seen drunk men do worse than this just fooling around.—Father, father!—Stop, stop!—Won’t anyone help me?$NEWLINE$(he cuts his own arm)

paragraphs.original: Enter GLOUCESTER and servants with torches$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER enters along with servants carrying torches.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Now Edmund, where’s the villain?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Edmund, where’s your wicked brother?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Here stood he in the dark, his sharp sword out,$NEWLINE$Mumbling of wicked charms, conjuring the moon$NEWLINE$To stand ’s auspicious mistress—
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$He was standing here in the dark with his sword pointing at me. He was mumbling some black magic spells, appealing to the moon to help him in his evil plans—

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$But where is he?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$But where is he?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Look, sir, I bleed.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Look, sir, I’m bleeding.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Where is the villain, Edmund?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Where is the villain, Edmund?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Fled this way, sir, when by no means he could—
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$He ran out that way, sir, when he couldn’t—

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Pursue him, ho! Go after.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Follow him, now! Go.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt some servants
paragraphs.translated: Some servants exit.

paragraphs.original: “By no means” what?
paragraphs.translated: When he couldn’t what?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Persuade me to the murder of your lordship,$NEWLINE$But that I told him the revenging gods$NEWLINE$'Gainst parricides did all the thunder bend,$NEWLINE$Spoke with how manifold and strong a bond$NEWLINE$The child was bound to th' father. Sir, in fine,$NEWLINE$Seeing how loathly opposite I stood$NEWLINE$To his unnatural purpose, in fell motion,$NEWLINE$With his preparèd sword he charges home$NEWLINE$My unprovided body, latched mine arm.$NEWLINE$And when he saw my best alarumed spirits,$NEWLINE$Bold in the quarrel’s right, roused to the encounter,$NEWLINE$Or whether ghasted by the noise I made,$NEWLINE$Full suddenly he fled.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$When he couldn’t persuade me to kill you. I told him that the gods hate men who kill their fathers and unleash all their thunder on them, and that the bond between father and child was sacred. In short, when I told him how firmly opposed I was to his hideous plan, he pulled out his sword and lunged at my defenseless body, cutting my arm. Bolstered by righteousness, I prepared to fight, and when he saw my excitement—or perhaps because my shouting scared him—he ran away suddenly.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Let him fly far.$NEWLINE$Not in this land shall he remain uncaught.$NEWLINE$And found—dispatch. The noble duke my master,$NEWLINE$My worthy arch and patron, comes tonight.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Let him run far away. If he stays in this country he’ll be found. And if he’s caught, he’ll be executed. The Duke of Cornwall, my master and patron, is arriving tonight. On his authority I’ll proclaim that whoever finds Edgar and helps bring the murderous coward to

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: By his authority I will proclaim it$NEWLINE$That he which finds him shall deserve our thanks,$NEWLINE$Bringing the murderous coward to the stake.$NEWLINE$He that conceals him, death.
paragraphs.translated: justice will be rewarded. Whoever helps Edgar hide will die.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$When I dissuaded him from his intent,$NEWLINE$And found him pight to do it, with cursed speech$NEWLINE$I threatened to discover him. He replied,$NEWLINE$“Thou unpossessing bastard! Dost thou think$NEWLINE$If I would stand against thee, would the reposal$NEWLINE$Of any trust, virtue, or worth in thee$NEWLINE$Make thy words faithed? No. What I should deny—$NEWLINE$As this I would, ay, though thou didst produce$NEWLINE$My very character—I’d turn it all$NEWLINE$To thy suggestion, plot, and damnèd practice.$NEWLINE$And thou must make a dullard of the world,$NEWLINE$If they not thought the profits of my death$NEWLINE$Were very pregnant and potential spirits$NEWLINE$To make thee seek it.”
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$After I urged him not to kill you, I saw that he was still determined to do it. Enraged, I threatened to expose him. He answered, “You penniless bastard! Do you really think that if it came down to my word against yours, anyone would believe you? No. I’d deny whatever evidence you had against me—even if it were in my own handwriting—and turn it all into evidence against you and your plans for treachery. And you must think people are stupid if you believe they wouldn’t realize all the motives you have for trying to kill me.”

paragraphs.original: Tucket within
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play offstage.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$O strange and fastened villain!$NEWLINE$Would he deny his letter, said he? I never got him.—$NEWLINE$Hark, the duke’s trumpets. I know not why he comes.$NEWLINE$All ports I’ll bar. The villain shall not ’scape.$NEWLINE$The duke must grant me that. Besides, his picture$NEWLINE$I will send far and near, that all the kingdom$NEWLINE$May have the due note of him.—And of my land,$NEWLINE$Loyal and natural boy, I’ll work the means$NEWLINE$To make thee capable.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Oh, how monstrously evil! He said he would deny that he wrote his letter? He cannot truly be my son.—Listen. The duke’s trumpets. I don’t know why he’s come here. I’ll forbid all ships from leaving our harbors. The villain won’t escape. The duke will agree with me on that. And I’ll send his picture everywhere so that the whole kingdom will know what he looks like.—And as for you, my loyal and true son, I’ll find some way to make you my heir.

paragraphs.original: Enter the Duke of CORNWALL, REGAN, and attendants$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$REGAN
paragraphs.translated: The Duke of CORNWALL enters with REGAN and attendants.$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$REGAN

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$How now, my noble friend? Since I came hither,$NEWLINE$Which I can call but now, I have heard strange news.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$How are you, my friend? Ever since I arrived here, just now, I’ve been hearing strange rumors.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$If it be true, all vengeance comes too short$NEWLINE$Which can pursue th' offender. How dost, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$If they’re true, no punishment is harsh enough for the criminal. How are you, my lord?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$O madam, my old heart is cracked, it’s cracked.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Oh, madam, my old heart is broken, broken.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$What, did my father’s godson seek your life?—$NEWLINE$He whom my father named, your Edgar?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Did my father’s godson try to kill you? The one whom my father named, your son Edgar?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$O, lady, lady, shame would have it hid.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Oh, my lady, I’m ashamed to admit it.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Was he not companion with the riotous knights$NEWLINE$That tend upon my father?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Wasn’t he friends with all those brawling knights who serve my father?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I know not, madam. 'Tis too bad, too bad.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I don’t know, madam. Oh, it’s too terrible.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Yes, madam, he was of that consort.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$To answer your question, ma'am—yes, he was friendly with those knights.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$No marvel then, though he were ill affected.$NEWLINE$'Tis they have put him on the old man’s death,$NEWLINE$To have th' expense and spoil of his revenues.$NEWLINE$I have this present evening from my sister$NEWLINE$Been well informed of them—and with such cautions$NEWLINE$That if they come to sojourn at my house$NEWLINE$I’ll not be there.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Then it’s no surprise they had a bad influence on him. They probably put him up to killing old man Gloucester to get his money. Tonight I received a letter from my sister telling me all about them—and warning me not be at home in case they come to stay at my house.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Nor I, assure thee, Regan.—$NEWLINE$Edmund, I hear that you have shown your father$NEWLINE$A childlike office.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$And I won’t be there either.—Edmund, I’m told you’ve acted like a true son to your father.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$It was my duty, sir.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I just did my duty, sir.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He did bewray his practice, and received$NEWLINE$This hurt you see striving to apprehend him.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He exposed Edgar’s murderous plot, and was wounded, as you see there, when trying to apprehend him.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Is he pursued?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Are your men searching for him?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Ay, my good lord.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$If he be taken, he shall never more$NEWLINE$Be feared of doing harm. Make your own purpose$NEWLINE$How in my strength you please.—For you, Edmund,$NEWLINE$Whose virtue and obedience doth this instant$NEWLINE$So much commend itself, you shall be ours.$NEWLINE$Natures of such deep trust we shall much need.$NEWLINE$You we first seize on.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$If he’s caught, he’ll never make trouble for anyone again. Feel free to use my authority however you wish in order to apprehend him.—As for you, Edmund, you’ve been so loyal and virtuous throughout this whole business. I’d like you to work for me. I need people as trustworthy as you.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I shall serve you, sir,$NEWLINE$Truly, however else.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’ll always be loyal to you, sir.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to CORNWALL) For him I thank your grace.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to cornwall) Thank you, my lord, for your kindness to Edmund.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$You know not why we came to visit you—
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$You don’t know why we came to visit you—

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Thus out of season, threading dark-eyed night.$NEWLINE$Occasions, noble Gloucester, of some poise,$NEWLINE$Wherein we must have use of your advice:$NEWLINE$Our father he hath writ, so hath our sister,$NEWLINE$Of differences, which I least thought it fit$NEWLINE$To answer from our home. The several messengers$NEWLINE$From hence attend dispatch. Our good old friend,$NEWLINE$Lay comforts to your bosom, and bestow$NEWLINE$Your needful counsel to our business,$NEWLINE$Which craves the instant use.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Yes, and so unexpectedly, at night. There are some important matters we need your advice on, Gloucester. My father and my sister have both recently written to me about arguments between them. I realized it would be inconvenient to answer them from home, especially since the king may be on his way there. Their messengers are ready, waiting to deliver our response in these matters. So please, old friend, give us some good advice. We need it desperately and immediately.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I serve you, madam.$NEWLINE$Your graces are right welcome.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I’m at your service, madam. Both of you are very welcome here.

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter KENT disguised and OSWALD the steward, severally$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: KENT enters in disguise. OSWALD enters from elsewhere.$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Good dawning to thee, friend. Art of this house?
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Good morning to you, friend. Do you work in this house?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Ay.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Yes, I do.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Where may we set our horses?
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Where should we stable our horses?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I' th' mire.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$In the mud.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Prithee, if thou lovest me, tell me.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Please, sir, be kind to me and tell me.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I love thee not.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I won’t be kind to you.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Why, then, I care not for thee.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$In that case, I don’t much care for you either.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$If I had thee in Lipsbury pinfold, I would make thee care for me.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$If I could get my hands on you, I’d make you care.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Why dost thou use me thus? I know thee not.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Why are you talking to me like this? I don’t even know you.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Fellow, I know thee.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Ah, but I know you.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$What dost thou know me for?
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Who am I then?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$A knave, a rascal, an eater of broken meats; a base, proud, shallow, beggarly, three-suited, hundred-pound, filthy, worsted-stocking knave; a lily-livered, action-taking knave; a whoreson, glass-gazing, super-serviceable finical rogue; one-trunk-inheriting slave; one that wouldst be a bawd in way of good service; and art nothing but the composition of a knave, beggar, coward, pander, and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch; one whom I will beat into clamorous whining if thou deniest the least syllable of thy addition.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$You’re a lowlife, a rascal who eats leftover scraps. You’re an ignoble, arrogant, shallow, vulgar, pretentious, conceited, filthy third-rate servant who thinks he’s something special. You’re a cowardly lawyer-loving bastard; a vain, brown-nosing, prissy scoundrel who’d pimp himself out to advance his career; a bag lady. You’re nothing but a lowlife, a beggar, a coward, and a pimp, the son and heir of a mutt bitch. I’ll beat you until you whine and cry if you deny the least bit of this.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Why, what a monstrous fellow art thou, thus to rail on one that is neither known of thee nor knows thee!
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$What an ogre you are to slander someone you don’t know, and who doesn’t know you!

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$What a brazen-faced varlet art thou to deny thou knowest me! Is it two days ago since I tripped up thy heels and beat thee before the king? Draw, you rogue, for though it be night yet the moon shines. I’ll make a sop o' th' moonshine of you. (draws his sword) Draw, you whoreson cullionly barber-monger, draw!$NEWLINE$(draws his sword)
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$What a shameless jerk you are to pretend you don’t know me! It was just two days ago that I tripped you and beat you up in front of the king. Draw your sword, scoundrel. It may be nighttime, but there’s enough moonlight to fight by. I’ll make ground beef out of you. (he draws his sword) Draw, you affected, preening son of a bitch! Draw your sword!$NEWLINE$(he draws his sword)

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Away! I have nothing to do with thee.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Get away from me! I’ve got nothing to do with you.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Draw, you rascal. You come with letters against the king and take Vanity the puppet’s part against the royalty of her father. Draw, you rogue, or I’ll so carbonado your shanks. Draw, you rascal! Come your ways.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Draw your sword, you jerk! You come here with letters against the king, and you take his conceited daughter’s side against his royal highness. Draw your sword, scoundrel, or I’ll slice your thighs like flank steak. Draw your sword! Come on!

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Help, ho! Murder! Help!
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Help! Murderer! Help!

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Strike, you slave. Stand, rogue. Stand, you neat slave, strike! (strikes OSWALD)$NEWLINE$(strikes$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Fight, peasant. Don’t run away, scoundrel. Stand and fight, you overdressed servant, fight! (he hits OSWALD)$NEWLINE$(he hits$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Help, ho! Murder, murder!
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Help! Murder, murder!

paragraphs.original: Enter EDMUND the bastard with his rapier drawn, the Duke of CORNWALL, the Duchess REGAN, GLOUCESTER, and servants$NEWLINE$EDMUND$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND enters with his sword drawn, followed by the Duke of CORNWALL, the Duchess REGAN, GLOUCESTER, and servants.$NEWLINE$EDMUND$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$How now? What’s the matter? Part.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$What’s going on here? Get away from each other.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND) With you, goodman boy, if you please. Come,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I’ll flesh ye. Come on, young master.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND) Well, kid, let’s see you fight. Come on, I’ll show you how.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Weapons, arms? What’s the matter here?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$You have weapons? What’s going on here?

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Keep peace, upon your lives.$NEWLINE$He dies that strikes again. What is the matter?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Stop it, I order you. The next person to strike again dies. What’s going on here?

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$The messengers from our sister and the king.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$These are the messengers from my sister and the king.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$What is your difference? Speak.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$What are you fighting about? Tell me.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I am scarce in breath, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I’m out of breath, sir.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$No marvel, you have so bestirred your valor. You cowardly rascal, nature disclaims in thee. A tailor made thee.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$No wonder, with all your exertions, you cowardly rascal. You’re not worth being called a man. The only thing manly about you are your clothes. A tailor made you.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Thou art a strange fellow. A tailor make a man?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$That’s an odd thing to say. How can a tailor make a person?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Ay, a tailor, sir. A stone-cutter or painter could not have made him so ill though they had been but two years o' th' trade.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Definitely a tailor, sir. A sculptor or a painter couldn’t have screwed him up as bad as that, even as an apprentice.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Speak yet. How grew your quarrel?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$But tell me what you’re fighting about.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$This ancient ruffian, sir, whose life I have spared at suit of his gray beard—
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$This old ruffian here, whom I didn’t kill because he’s so old—

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Thou whoreson zed, thou unnecessary letter!—My lord, if you will give me leave, I will tread this unbolted villain into mortar and daub the wall of a jakes with him.—Spare my gray beard, you wagtail?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$You useless bastard—you’re like the letter “z,” a totally unnecessary addition to the alphabet.—My lord, please let me grind this lumpy lowlife into a powder and use it to plaster up the bathroom walls.—You didn’t kill me because I’m so old, you fawning dog?

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Peace, sirrah!$NEWLINE$You beastly knave, know you no reverence?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Calm down. Don’t you have any manners, you savage?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Yes, sir, but anger hath a privilege.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Yes, sir, but not when I’m enraged.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Why art thou angry?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Why are you enraged?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$That such a slave as this should wear a sword,$NEWLINE$Who wears no honesty. Such smiling rogues as these,$NEWLINE$Like rats, oft bite the holy cords atwain$NEWLINE$Which are too intrinse t' unloose, smooth every passion$NEWLINE$That in the natures of their lords rebel,$NEWLINE$Bring oil to fire, snow to the colder moods;$NEWLINE$Renege, affirm, and turn their halcyon beaks$NEWLINE$With every gale and vary of their masters,$NEWLINE$Knowing naught, like dogs, but following.—$NEWLINE$A plague upon your epileptic visage!$NEWLINE$Smile you my speeches as I were a fool?$NEWLINE$Goose, an I had you upon Sarum plain,$NEWLINE$I’d drive ye cackling home to Camelot.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I’m angry that a dishonorable lowlife like this wears a sword like a gentleman. Smiling swindlers such as he undo the sacred bonds that unite people together, and only encourage the unreasonable passions of their masters. They foster both rage and apathy. They say “Yes” and “No,” turning their noses whichever way the wind blows without taking a firm stance on anything. They blindly follow their masters' impulses, like dogs.—Damn your ugly stinking face! Are you laughing at what I say, as if I were a fool? If I had my way with you right now, I’d send you to back to where you came from.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Why, art thou mad, old fellow?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Are you insane, old man?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to KENT)      How fell you out?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Say that.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to KENT) What did you start quarreling over? Just tell us.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$No contraries hold more antipathy$NEWLINE$Than I and such a knave.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I couldn’t hate that jerk over there any more than I do.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Why dost thou call him “knave”? What’s his offense?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Why are you calling him a jerk? What did he do to you?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$His countenance likes me not.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I don’t like his face.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$No more perchance does mine, nor his, nor hers.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$But maybe you don’t like mine, or his, or hers either.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Sir, ’tis my occupation to be plain.$NEWLINE$I have seen better faces in my time$NEWLINE$Than stands on any shoulder that I see$NEWLINE$Before me at this instant.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I’m used to telling the truth, sir, and I have to say that I’ve seen better faces than those I see here.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$This is some fellow,$NEWLINE$Who, having been praised for bluntness, doth affect$NEWLINE$A saucy roughness and constrains the garb$NEWLINE$Quite from his nature. He cannot flatter, he.$NEWLINE$An honest mind and plain, he must speak truth.$NEWLINE$An they will take it, so. If not, he’s plain.$NEWLINE$These kind of knaves I know, which in this plainness$NEWLINE$Harbor more craft and more corrupter ends$NEWLINE$Than twenty silly-ducking observants$NEWLINE$That stretch their duties nicely.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$This is a guy who’s been praised for his honest bluntness, and who now insolently pretends to be plainspoken and twists the natural meanings of words. No flattery for him, no sir! He’s honest, he’s got to speak the truth. If people take what he says, fine. If not, he’s got truth on his side! I know his type. He’s sneaky behind all his so-called bluntness, sneakier than twenty brown-nosing bootlickers who only tell you what you want to hear.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Sir, in good faith, or in sincere verity,$NEWLINE$Under th' allowance of your great aspect,$NEWLINE$Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire$NEWLINE$On flickering Phoebus' front—
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Dearest, kindest, most honorable sir, may I say, with your esteemed approval, which is lit up by the illuminating radiance of the sun-god Phoebus, that—

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$What mean’st by this?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$What do you mean by that?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$To go out of my dialect, which you discommend so much. I know, sir, I am no flatterer. He that beguiled you in a plain accent was a plain knave, which for my part I will not be, though I should win your displeasure to entreat me to ’t.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I tried to stop speaking plainly, since you dislike plain speech so much. Sir, I know I’m not a flatterer. The guy who tricked you with plain language was just a plain crook—which I’m not, however much I may displease you by not being one.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$(to OSWALD) What was th' offense you gave him?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$(to OSWALD) How did you offend him?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I never gave him any.$NEWLINE$It pleased the king his master very late$NEWLINE$To strike at me upon his misconstruction$NEWLINE$When he, conjunct and flattering his displeasure,$NEWLINE$Tripped me behind; being down, insulted, railed,$NEWLINE$And put upon him such a deal of man$NEWLINE$That worthied him, got praises of the king$NEWLINE$For him attempting who was self-subdued.$NEWLINE$And in the fleshment of this dread exploit$NEWLINE$Drew on me here again.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I never offended him at all. Recently, the king hit me because of a misunderstanding. This man took sides with the king and tripped me. When I was down on the ground he insulted me, and then started acting tough to seem courageous in front of the king. The king praised him, even though I had never offered any resistance at all. Now he pulled out his sword on me again, still riled up from our first encounter.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$None of these rogues and cowards$NEWLINE$But Ajax is their fool.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$These cowards manage to make fools of brave men.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Fetch forth the stocks, ho!—$NEWLINE$You stubborn ancient knave, you reverend braggart,$NEWLINE$We’ll teach you.
paragraphs.translated:
CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Bring out the
stocks !—We’ll teach you, you stubborn old bastard, you arrogant show-off.$NEWLINE$stocks$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Sir, I am too old to learn.$NEWLINE$Call not your stocks for me. I serve the king,$NEWLINE$On whose employment I was sent to you.$NEWLINE$You shall do small respect, show too bold malice$NEWLINE$Against the grace and person of my master,$NEWLINE$Stocking his messenger.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Sir, I’m too old to be taught anything. Don’t put me in the stocks. I serve the king, who sent me here. If you put me in the stocks you’ll insult him both as a king and as a man.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Fetch forth the stocks!$NEWLINE$As I have life and honor, there shall he sit till noon.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Bring out the stocks! I swear on my life and honor, he’ll sit here in the stocks until noon.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Till noon? Till night, my lord, and all night too.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Only until noon, my lord? No, the whole day, and all night too.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Why, madam, if I were your father’s dog,$NEWLINE$You should not use me so.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Ma'am, you wouldn’t treat me like this if I were your father’s dog.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Sir, being his knave, I will.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$But since you’re his scoundrel servant, I will.

paragraphs.original: Stocks brought out
paragraphs.translated: The stocks are brought out.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$This is a fellow of the selfsame color$NEWLINE$Our sister speaks of.—Come, bring away the stocks!
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$This guy is exactly the kind of person your sister warned us about.—Come on, bring in the stocks, now!

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Let me beseech your grace not to do so.$NEWLINE$His fault is much, and the good king his master$NEWLINE$Will check him for ’t. Your purposed low correction$NEWLINE$Is such as basest and contemned’st wretches$NEWLINE$For pilferings and most common trespasses$NEWLINE$Are punished with.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I beg you not to do this, my lord. He’s done wrong, and his master the king will punish him for it. But the kind

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The king his master needs must take it ill,$NEWLINE$That he, so slightly valued in his messenger,$NEWLINE$Should have him thus restrained.
paragraphs.translated: of punishment you propose is more suited to petty shoplifters than to royal attendants.$NEWLINE$The king will be offended to find out that his messenger is so badly treated.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$I’ll answer that.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$I’ll take responsibility for that.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$My sister may receive it much more worse$NEWLINE$To have her gentleman abused, assaulted$NEWLINE$For following her affairs.—Put in his legs.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$My sister would be much more offended to have her trusted messenger abused and assaulted just for carrying out her orders.—Put his legs in the stocks.

paragraphs.original: KENT is put in the stocks$NEWLINE$KENT
paragraphs.translated: KENT is put in the stocks.$NEWLINE$KENT

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$(to GLOUCESTER) Come, my good lord, away.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$(to GLOUCESTER) Let’s go, my lord.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER and KENT$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$KENT
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except GLOUCESTER and KENT.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$KENT

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I am sorry for thee, friend. 'Tis the duke’s pleasure,$NEWLINE$Whose disposition, all the world well knows,$NEWLINE$Will not be rubbed nor stopped. I’ll entreat for thee.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I’m sorry, my friend. The duke always gets it his way, and everyone knows you can’t budge him once he’s made up his mind. I’ll try talking to him again.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Pray you do not, sir. I have watched and traveled hard.$NEWLINE$Some time I shall sleep out. The rest I’ll whistle.$NEWLINE$A good man’s fortune may grow out at heels.$NEWLINE$Give you good morrow.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Please don’t, sir. I’ve been up for a long time and have done a lot of traveling recently. This punishment will be a good chance to catch up on my sleep. The rest of the time I’ll whistle to entertain myself. Even good men have bad luck. Have a good morning.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$The duke’s to blame in this. 'Twill be ill taken.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$It’s wrong for the duke to do this. The king will be angry with him.

paragraphs.original: Exit GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER exits.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Good King, that must approve the common saw,$NEWLINE$Thou out of heaven’s benediction comest$NEWLINE$To the warm sun.$NEWLINE$(takes out a letter)$NEWLINE$(takes out a letter)$NEWLINE$Approach, thou beacon to this underglobe,$NEWLINE$That by thy comfortable beams I may$NEWLINE$Peruse this letter. Nothing almost sees miracles$NEWLINE$But misery. I know ’tis from Cordelia,$NEWLINE$Who hath most fortunately been informed$NEWLINE$Of my obscurèd course and (reads the letter) “shall find time$NEWLINE$(reads the letter)$NEWLINE$From this enormous state, seeking to give$NEWLINE$Losses their remedies.” All weary and o'erwatched,$NEWLINE$Take vantage, heavy eyes, not to behold$NEWLINE$This shameful lodging.$NEWLINE$Fortune, good night. Smile once more. Turn thy wheel.$NEWLINE$(sleeps)$NEWLINE$(sleeps)
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Oh, good King Lear, you’re proving that, just as they say, everything goes from good to bad. (he takes out a letter) Rise and shine, sun, so I can read this letter. Only those who are truly miserable see miracles. I know this letter is from Cordelia, who knows that I’m serving the king in disguise. (looking at the letter) She says that she will have time, now that she’s away from the monstrous conditions here, to find a way to fix things. I’m exhausted. I’ve been awake too long. This fatigue gives me an excuse to shut my eyes so I can’t see myself humiliated in the stocks. Good night, Lady Luck. Smile and spin your wheel of fortune again. (he sleeps)$NEWLINE$(he takes out a letter)$NEWLINE$(looking at the letter)$NEWLINE$(he sleeps)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter EDGAR$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR enters.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I heard myself proclaimed,$NEWLINE$And by the happy hollow of a tree$NEWLINE$Escaped the hunt. No port is free, no place$NEWLINE$That guard and most unusual vigilance$NEWLINE$Does not attend my taking. Whiles I may ’scape,$NEWLINE$I will preserve myself, and am bethought$NEWLINE$To take the basest and most poorest shape$NEWLINE$That ever penury in contempt of man$NEWLINE$Brought near to beast. My face I’ll grime with filth,$NEWLINE$Blanket my loins, elf all my hair in knots,$NEWLINE$And with presented nakedness outface$NEWLINE$The winds and persecutions of the sky.$NEWLINE$The country gives me proof and precedent$NEWLINE$Of Bedlam beggars, who with roaring voices$NEWLINE$Strike in their numbed and mortified bare arms$NEWLINE$Pins, wooden pricks, nails, sprigs of rosemary,$NEWLINE$And with this horrible object from low farms,$NEWLINE$Poor pelting villages, sheepcotes, and mills,$NEWLINE$Sometime with lunatic bans, sometime with prayers,$NEWLINE$Enforce their charity. “Poor Turlygod!” “Poor Tom!”—$NEWLINE$That’s something yet. Edgar I nothing am.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I heard myself declared an outlaw and escaped capture by hiding in the trunk of a hollow tree. Every town and port is crawling with henchmen on the lookout, waiting to capture me. But I’ll survive while I can. I’ve decided to disguise myself as the lowliest and rattiest beggar that mankind has ever seen. I’ll smear my face with filth, put on a loincloth, make my hair matted and tangled, and face the bad weather wearing almost nothing. I’ve seen beggars out of insane asylums who stick pins and nails into their numb arms. They pray or roar lunatic curses, horrifying farmers and villagers into giving them alms. “Poor crazy Tom!” they call themselves. Well, at least that’s something. As Edgar, I’m nothing at all.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KENT in the stocks Enter LEAR, FOOL, and GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated: KENT is in the stocks. LEAR enters with the FOOL and the GENTLEMAN.$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$'Tis strange that they should so depart from home,$NEWLINE$And not send back my messenger.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$It’s strange that Regan and her husband left their house without sending back my messenger.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$As I learned,$NEWLINE$The night before there was no purpose in them$NEWLINE$Of this remove.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$According to what I heard, they had no travel plans as of last night.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(to LEAR)    Hail to thee, noble master!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) Hail, noble master!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Ha! Makest thou this shame thy pastime?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$What’s this? Are you sitting around in this humiliation to amuse yourself?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$No, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$No, my lord.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Ha, ha! Look, he wears cruel garters. Horses are tied by the heads, dogs and bears by the neck, monkeys by the loins, and men by the legs. When a man’s overlusty at legs, then he wears wooden nether-stocks.
