paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Ha, ha! That’s a nasty garter belt. You tie up horses by their heads, dogs and bears by their necks, monkeys by their waists, and humans by their legs. When a person’s prone to wanderlust, he has to wear wooden socks, like a chastity belt around his ankles.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$(to KENT) What’s he that hath so much thy place mistook$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$To set thee here?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$(to KENT) Who could have misunderstood your assigment so completely as to lock you up like this?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$It is both he and she:$NEWLINE$Your son and daughter.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Your daughter and son-in-law.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$No.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Yes.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Yes.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, I say.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I’m telling you “No.”

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I say “Yea.”
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$And I’m telling you “Yes.”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, no, they would not.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, no, they wouldn’t.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Yes, they have.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Yes, they have.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$By Jupiter, I swear “No.”
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$By the god Jupiter above, I swear “No.”

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$By Juno, I swear “Ay.”
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$By Jupiter’s wife Juno, I swear “Yes.”

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$They durst not do ’t.$NEWLINE$They could not, would not do ’t. 'Tis worse than murder$NEWLINE$To do upon respect such violent outrage.$NEWLINE$Resolve me with all modest haste which way$NEWLINE$Thou mightst deserve or they impose this usage,$NEWLINE$Coming from us.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$They wouldn’t dare. They couldn’t, they wouldn’t. It’s worse than murder to humiliate a king’s messenger like this. Tell me as quickly and clearly as you can what you did to deserve this punishment, or what made them think they could inflict it on you.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$My lord, when at their home$NEWLINE$I did commend your highness' letters to them.$NEWLINE$Ere I was risen from the place that showed$NEWLINE$My duty kneeling, came there a reeking post,$NEWLINE$Stewed in his haste, half breathless, panting forth$NEWLINE$From Goneril his mistress salutations,$NEWLINE$Delivered letters spite of intermission,$NEWLINE$Which presently they read, on whose contents$NEWLINE$They summoned up their meiny, straight took horse,$NEWLINE$Commanded me to follow and attend$NEWLINE$The leisure of their answer, gave me cold looks.$NEWLINE$And meeting here the other messenger,$NEWLINE$Whose welcome I perceived had poisoned mine—$NEWLINE$Being the very fellow which of late$NEWLINE$Displayed so saucily against your highness—$NEWLINE$Having more man than wit about me, drew.$NEWLINE$He raised the house with loud and coward cries.$NEWLINE$Your son and daughter found this trespass worth$NEWLINE$The shame which here it suffers.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$My lord, when I arrived at their home I gave them your letter. Before I had a chance to get up from my respectful kneeling position, Goneril’s messenger arrived, stinky, sweaty, and out of breath. He interrupted me, spouted out greetings from her, and delivered her letter, which they opened immediately. After reading it, they gathered their entourage together and got on their horses to go. They glared at me and ordered me to follow them and wait for their answer. After we arrived here, I ran into that other messenger who made them give me the cold shoulder—the very same guy who was so rude to you, King. I admit it was foolish to draw my sword on him, but I had to act like a man. He woke up the whole house with his loud and cowardly screams. That’s why your daughter and son-in-law are punishing me shamefully.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Winter’s not gone yet, if the wild geese fly that way.$NEWLINE$Fathers that wear rags$NEWLINE$Do make their children blind.$NEWLINE$But fathers that bear bags$NEWLINE$Shall see their children kind.$NEWLINE$Fortune, that arrant whore,$NEWLINE$Ne'er turns the key to th' poor.$NEWLINE$But for all this thou shalt have as many dolors for thy daughters as thou canst tell in a year.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$This story bodes more stormy weather.$NEWLINE$Fathers who wear rags$NEWLINE$Make their children neglect them.$NEWLINE$But fathers who are rich$NEWLINE$Make their children kind.$NEWLINE$Lady Luck is a fickle whore$NEWLINE$And never gives the poor a break.$NEWLINE$But despite all this, your daughters will give you a lot of money—or do I mean pain?—in the coming year.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$O, how this mother swells up toward my heart!$NEWLINE$Hysterica passio, down, thou climbing sorrow.$NEWLINE$Thy element’s below.—Where is this daughter?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I’m getting hysterical. I feel my stomach squeezing up against my heart. Calm down, you belong lower down!—Where is this daughter of mine?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$With the earl, sir, here within.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Inside, sir, with the earl.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Follow me not. Stay here.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Don’t follow me. Stay here.

paragraphs.original: Exit LEAR$NEWLINE$LEAR
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Made you no more offense but what you speak of?
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$You didn’t do anything else to earn this punishment?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$None.$NEWLINE$How chance the king comes with so small a train?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Nothing. Tell me, why did the king arrive with such a small entourage?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$An thou hadst been set i' th' stocks for that question, thou’dst well deserved it.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$If they’d put you in the stocks for asking that question, you would’ve deserved it.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Why, Fool?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Why, Fool?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$We’ll set thee to school to an ant to teach thee there’s no laboring i' th' winter. All that follow their noses are led by their eyes but blind men, and there’s not a nose among twenty but can smell him that’s stinking. Let go thy hold when a great wheel runs down a hill, lest it break thy neck with following it.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$You need to learn what ants know well about winter—there’s no point in slaving away if there’s no hope for profit. Serving the king will get you nowhere. Everyone can see that, and even blind men can smell the stench of his misery now. When you see a huge wheel rolling down a hill, you shouldn’t try to hold on to it or it’ll break your neck.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: But the great one that goes up the hill, let him draw thee after. When a wise man gives thee better counsel, give me mine again. I would have none but knaves follow it since a fool gives it.$NEWLINE$That sir which serves and seeks for gain,$NEWLINE$And follows but for form,$NEWLINE$Will pack when it begins to rain$NEWLINE$And leave thee in the storm.$NEWLINE$But I will tarry. The fool will stay.$NEWLINE$And let the wise man fly.$NEWLINE$The knave turns fool that runs away;$NEWLINE$The fool, no knave, perdie.
paragraphs.translated: But if you see a wheel going uphill, latch on for the ride. And when a wise man gives you better advice than I just did, give me my advice back again. I only want idiots following my advice, the advice of a fool.$NEWLINE$The gentleman who serves you only for profit$NEWLINE$And is only superficially loyal to you$NEWLINE$Will take off when it starts to rain$NEWLINE$And leave you alone in the storm.$NEWLINE$But I’ll linger. The fool will stay.$NEWLINE$And let the wise man run away.$NEWLINE$The servant who runs away is a fool.$NEWLINE$But this fool is no scoundrel, by God.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Where learned you this, Fool?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Where did you learn that song, Fool?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Not i' th' stocks, fool.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Not in the stocks, fool.

paragraphs.original: Enter LEAR and GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: LEAR and GLOUCESTER enter.$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Deny to speak with me? They are sick? They are weary?$NEWLINE$They have traveled all the night?—mere fetches, ay!$NEWLINE$The images of revolt and flying off.$NEWLINE$Fetch me a better answer.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$How can they refuse to speak with me? How can they say that they’re sick or exhausted or that they have$NEWLINE$traveled all night!? They’re playing with me. These are tricks. This is rebellion. Go ask them again and make them see me this time.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$My dear lord,$NEWLINE$You know the fiery quality of the duke,$NEWLINE$How unremoveable and fixed he is$NEWLINE$In his own course.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$My dear lord, you know how passionately stubborn the duke is. He never changes his mind.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Vengeance, plague, death, confusion!$NEWLINE$“Fiery”? What “quality”? Why, Gloucester, Gloucester,$NEWLINE$I’d speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Hell! Damn it all to hell! “Passionately”? What “passion”? Gloucester, Gloucester, I want to speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Well, my good lord, I have informed them so.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$My lord, I informed them as much.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$“Informed them”? Dost thou understand me, man?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$“Informed them”? Do you understand what I’m saying, man?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Ay, my good lord.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$The king would speak with Cornwall. The dear father$NEWLINE$Would with his daughter speak, commands, tends service.$NEWLINE$Are they “informed” of this? My breath and blood!$NEWLINE$“Fiery”? The “fiery” duke? Tell the hot duke that Lear—$NEWLINE$No, but not yet. Maybe he is not well.$NEWLINE$Infirmity doth still neglect all office$NEWLINE$Whereto our health is bound. We are not ourselves$NEWLINE$When nature, being oppressed, commands the mind$NEWLINE$To suffer with the body. I’ll forbear,$NEWLINE$And am fallen out with my more headier will$NEWLINE$To take the indisposed and sickly fit$NEWLINE$For the sound man.$NEWLINE$(notices KENT again)$NEWLINE$(notices$NEWLINE$again)$NEWLINE$Death on my state! Wherefore$NEWLINE$Should he sit here? This act persuades me$NEWLINE$That this remotion of the duke and her$NEWLINE$Is practice only. Give me my servant forth.$NEWLINE$Go tell the duke and ’s wife I’d speak with them—$NEWLINE$Now, presently. Bid them come forth and hear me,$NEWLINE$Or at their chamber door I’ll beat the drum$NEWLINE$Till it cry sleep to death.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$The king wants to speak with Cornwall. The father wants to speak with his daughter. He orders them—he begs them. Did you inform them of that? This is unbelievable! “Passionate”? The “passionate” duke? Tell the hot-headed duke that I… But no, not yet. Maybe he’s not feeling well. When we’re ill we can’t carry out our duties as well as when we’re healthy. When our bodies are out of order, our minds can’t function properly. I’ll hold off, and subdue my impulsive temper, which makes me judge a sick man as if he were well. (he notices KENT again) A curse on my royal power! Why should he sit here like this? The fact that they punished him convinces me that Regan and the duke are avoiding me on purpose. I want my servant released. Go tell the duke and his wife I’ll speak to them right now, at once. Tell them to come here and hear me out, or else I’ll beat a drum at their bedroom door until they can’t sleep any more.$NEWLINE$(he notices$NEWLINE$again)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I would have all well betwixt you.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I just want everything to be all right between you.

paragraphs.original: Exit GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER exits.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$O me, my heart, my rising heart! But down.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Oh, my heart, my heart is rising into my throat! Stay down, heart.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Cry to it, nuncle, as the cockney did to the eels when she put 'em i' th' paste alive. She knapped 'em o' th' coxcombs with a stick and cried, “Down, wantons, down!” 'Twas her brother that, in pure kindness to his horse, buttered his hay.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL$NEWLINE$That’s right, uncle, talk to your heart, like the
housewife who yelled at the eels she was putting in her pie. She hit 'em on the head with a stick and shouted, “Down, you naughty things, down!” That was the woman whose brother wanted to be nice to his
horse, and buttered its hay.$NEWLINE$housewife$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$horse$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter the Duke of CORNWALL, REGAN, GLOUCESTER, and servants$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: The Duke of CORNWALL, REGAN, and GLOUCESTER enter with their servants.$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Good morrow to you both.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Good morning to you both.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Hail to your grace.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Hail to your majesty.

paragraphs.original: KENT here set at liberty$NEWLINE$KENT
paragraphs.translated: KENT is set free.$NEWLINE$KENT

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$I am glad to see your highness.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$I’m glad to see your highness.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Regan, I think you are. I know what reason$NEWLINE$I have to think so: if thou shouldst not be glad,$NEWLINE$I would divorce me from thy mother’s tomb,$NEWLINE$Sepulchring an adultress.$NEWLINE$(to KENT)     Oh, are you free?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Some other time for that.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I believe you are, Regan. You know why I think so? Because if you weren’t glad, I’d divorce your dead mother, because I’d know she cheated on me. Any true daughter of mine would definitely be glad to see me. (to KENT) Oh, are you free? We’ll talk about it later.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit KENT$NEWLINE$KENT
paragraphs.translated: KENT exits.$NEWLINE$KENT

paragraphs.original: Belovèd Regan,$NEWLINE$Thy sister’s naught. O Regan, she hath tied$NEWLINE$Sharp-toothed unkindness, like a vulture, here.$NEWLINE$(indicates his heart)$NEWLINE$(indicates his heart)$NEWLINE$I can scarce speak to thee. Thou'lt not believe$NEWLINE$With how depraved a quality— O Regan!
paragraphs.translated: My dear Regan, your sister’s not worth anything. Oh, Regan, she’s torn me apart with unkindness, like a vulture, right here. (points to his heart) I can hardly speak. You’ll never believe how monstrously—oh, Regan!$NEWLINE$(points to his heart)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$I pray you, sir, take patience. I have hope$NEWLINE$You less know how to value her desert$NEWLINE$Than she to scant her duty.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Calm down, sir, please. I hope there’s been a misunderstanding. It’s more likely that you don’t know how to appreciate her than that she’d ever fail in her duties as a daughter.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Say, how is that?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$How do you mean?

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$I cannot think my sister in the least$NEWLINE$Would fail her obligation. If, sir, perchance$NEWLINE$She have restrained the riots of your followers,$NEWLINE$'Tis on such ground and to such wholesome end$NEWLINE$As clears her from all blame.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$I can’t believe my sister would neglect her obligations in any way. If she restrained your rowdy knights, she had such a good reason that you can’t blame her for it.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$My curses on her!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I curse her.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$O sir, you are old.$NEWLINE$Nature in you stands on the very verge$NEWLINE$Of his confine. You should be ruled and led$NEWLINE$By some discretion that discerns your state$NEWLINE$Better than you yourself. Therefore I pray you$NEWLINE$That to our sister you do make return.$NEWLINE$Say you have wronged her, sir.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Sir, you’re old. Your life is stretched to its limit. You should let others take care of you and submit to people who know better than you do what’s good for you. Please go back to Goneril’s house. Admit you were wrong.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Ask her forgiveness?$NEWLINE$Do you but mark how this becomes the house?—$NEWLINE$(kneels) “Dear daughter, I confess that I am old.$NEWLINE$(kneels)$NEWLINE$Age is unnecessary. On my knees I beg$NEWLINE$That you’ll vouchsafe me raiment, bed, and food.”
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Apologize? Do you think this kind of thing is appropriate for the royal family? (he kneels) “Dear daughter, I admit I’m old. Old people are useless. I’m begging you, on my knees, to give me food, clothes, and a bed.”$NEWLINE$(he kneels)

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Good sir, no more. These are unsightly tricks.$NEWLINE$Return you to my sister.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$No more, please. These are ugly antics. Go back to my sister’s.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$(rising)     Never, Regan.$NEWLINE$(rising)$NEWLINE$She hath abated me of half my train,$NEWLINE$Looked black upon me, struck me with her tongue,$NEWLINE$Most serpentlike, upon the very heart.$NEWLINE$All the stored vengeances of heaven fall$NEWLINE$On her ingrateful top! Strike her young bones,$NEWLINE$You taking airs, with lameness!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$(getting up) Never, Regan. She’s sent away half my knights, glared at me, and aimed her venomous insults straight at my heart. She and her ingratitude can go to hell! I hope she gets sick and becomes lame!$NEWLINE$(getting up)

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Fie, sir, fie!
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Shush, sir, please!

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$You nimble lightnings, dart your blinding flames$NEWLINE$Into her scornful eyes! Infect her beauty,$NEWLINE$You fen-sucked fogs drawn by the powerful sun,$NEWLINE$To fall and blister!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I hope lightning strikes her in the eyes! I hope poisonous swampy fog covers her face and ruins her complexion!

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$O the blessed gods!$NEWLINE$So will you wish on me when the rash mood is on.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Oh, dear gods! That’s how you’ll talk about me when you’re in this mood.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, Regan, thou shalt never have my curse.$NEWLINE$Thy tender-hafted nature shall not give$NEWLINE$Thee o'er to harshness. Her eyes are fierce, but thine$NEWLINE$Do comfort and not burn. 'Tis not in thee$NEWLINE$To grudge my pleasures, to cut off my train,$NEWLINE$To bandy hasty words, to scant my sizes,$NEWLINE$And in conclusion to oppose the bolt$NEWLINE$Against my coming in. Thou better know’st$NEWLINE$The offices of nature, bond of childhood,$NEWLINE$Effects of courtesy, dues of gratitude.$NEWLINE$Thy half o' th' kingdom hast thou not forgot,$NEWLINE$Wherein I thee endowed.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, Regan. I’ll never curse you. You’re so gentle, you’d never be harsh like her. Her eyes are vicious, but yours are comforting. You’d never deny me my pleasures, downsize my entourage, insult me thoughtlessly, reduce my allowance, or lock me out of the house. You know better than she does how important the duties of a child to a parent are, and the responsibilities that come from gratitude. You haven’t forgotten the half of a kingdom I gave you.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Good sir, to the purpose.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Sir, let’s get to the point.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Who put my man i' th' stocks?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Who put my messenger in the stocks?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Tucket within
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play offstage.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$What trumpet’s that?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$What’s that trumpet?

paragraphs.original: Enter OSWALD the steward$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD enters.$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$I know ’t—my sister’s. This approves her letter$NEWLINE$That she would soon be here. (to OSWALD)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Is your lady come?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$I know it. It’s my sister’s. She’ll be here soon, just like her letter said. (to OSWALD) Has my sister arrived?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$This is a slave whose easy borrowed pride$NEWLINE$Dwells in the fickle grace of her he follows.—$NEWLINE$Out, varlet, from my sight!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$This is a lowlife who basks in the reflection of the fading glory of the woman he works for.—Get out of my sight, scoundrel!

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$What means your grace?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$What do you mean, your highness?

paragraphs.original: Enter GONERIL$NEWLINE$GONERIL
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL enters.$NEWLINE$GONERIL

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Who stocked my servant? Regan, I have good hope$NEWLINE$Thou didst not know on ’t.—Who comes here? O heavens,$NEWLINE$If you do love old men, if your sweet sway$NEWLINE$Allow obedience, if yourselves are old,$NEWLINE$Make it your cause. Send down, and take my part!$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL) Art not ashamed to look upon this beard?—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$O Regan, wilt thou take her by the hand?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Who put my servant in the stocks? Regan, I hope you didn’t know anything about that.—Ah, who’s this? Dear gods, if you love old men like me, if you believe in obedience, if you yourselves are old, then please send me down some help! (to GONERIL) Aren’t you ashamed to look at me after the way you’ve treated me in my old age?—Oh, Regan, are you taking her by the hand?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Why not by th' hand, sir? How have I offended?$NEWLINE$All’s not offense that indiscretion finds$NEWLINE$And dotage terms so.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Why shouldn’t she take my hand, father? How exactly have I offended you? Just because a senile man with poor judgment calls something an insult doesn’t necessarily mean it is one.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$O sides, you are too tough.$NEWLINE$Will you yet hold?—How came my man i' th' stocks?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Oh, how can the sides of my body hold in my grieving heart?—How did my messenger wind up in the stocks?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$I set him there, sir, but his own disorders$NEWLINE$Deserved much less advancement.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$I sent him there, sir, but his crimes deserved a worse punishment.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$You! Did you?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$You! You did it?

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$I pray you, father, being weak, seem so.$NEWLINE$If till the expiration of your month,$NEWLINE$You will return and sojourn with my sister,$NEWLINE$Dismissing half your train, come then to me.$NEWLINE$I am now from home, and out of that provision$NEWLINE$Which shall be needful for your entertainment.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Please, father, since you’re weak, act like it. Get rid of half your knights and go back to spend the rest of your month with my sister. Afterward, you can stay with me. Right now I’m away from home and I can’t provide you with proper care.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Return to her, and fifty men dismissed?$NEWLINE$No, rather I abjure all roofs, and choose$NEWLINE$To be a comrade with the wolf and owl—$NEWLINE$To wage against the enmity o' th' air—$NEWLINE$Necessity’s sharp pinch! Return with her?$NEWLINE$Why, the hot-blooded France that dowerless took$NEWLINE$Our youngest born—I could as well be brought$NEWLINE$To knee his throne, and, squirelike, pension beg$NEWLINE$To keep base life afoot. Return with her?$NEWLINE$Persuade me rather to be slave and sumpter$NEWLINE$To this detested groom. (indicates OSWALD)$NEWLINE$(indicates$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Go back with her? Send away fifty of my knights? No. I’d rather renounce living in a house, and wander in the open air in the hardships of poverty, as a friend of the wolf and the owl. Go back with her? I might as well go before the King of France, who took my youngest daughter without a dowry, kneel before his throne, and beg him to give me a tiny pension to stay alive. Go back with her? I’d rather be a slave or a packhorse for this hateful stablehand here. (he points to OSWALD)$NEWLINE$(he points to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$At your choice, sir.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$As you wish, sir.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Now, I prithee, daughter, do not make me mad.$NEWLINE$I will not trouble thee, my child. Farewell.$NEWLINE$We’ll no more meet, no more see one another.$NEWLINE$But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my daughter—$NEWLINE$Or rather a disease that’s in my flesh,$NEWLINE$Which I must needs call mine. Thou art a boil,$NEWLINE$A plague-sore or embossèd carbuncle$NEWLINE$In my corrupted blood. But I’ll not chide thee.$NEWLINE$Let shame come when it will. I do not call it.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I beg you, daughter, don’t make me crazy. I won’t bother you. We’ll never see each other again. But you’re still my child, my flesh and blood—or rather you’re a disease in my flesh, a disease I still have to call my own. You’re a pustule, a sore, a tumor digesting my bloodline. But I’ll stop rebuking you. You’ll feel shame when the time is right, and I don’t urge you to be ashamed now. I won’t beg the gods to punish you, or caution you to fear their judgment. Become a better

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I do not bid the thunder-bearer shoot,$NEWLINE$Nor tell tales of thee to high-judging Jove.$NEWLINE$Mend when thou canst. Be better at thy leisure.$NEWLINE$I can be patient. I can stay with Regan,$NEWLINE$I and my hundred knights.
paragraphs.translated: person when you’re ready, if you’re inclined. I’ll wait patiently. Meanwhile I’ll stay with Regan with my hundred knights.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Not altogether so, sir.$NEWLINE$I looked not for you yet, nor am provided$NEWLINE$For your fit welcome. Give ear, sir, to my sister.$NEWLINE$For those that mingle reason with your passion$NEWLINE$Must be content to think you old, and so—$NEWLINE$But she knows what she does.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$It’s not quite that simple. I wasn’t expecting you, and I’m not ready to receive you. Please hear what Goneril is saying. We’re trying to be reasonable while you’re so upset, and we understand that you’re old, and… But Goneril knows what she’s doing.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Is this well spoken now?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Do you mean what you’ve just said?

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$I dare avouch it, sir. What, fifty followers?$NEWLINE$Is it not well? What should you need of more—$NEWLINE$Yea, or so many—sith that both charge and danger$NEWLINE$Speak 'gainst so great a number? How, in one house,$NEWLINE$Should many people under two commands$NEWLINE$Hold amity? 'Tis hard; almost impossible.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Yes, I do. Isn’t fifty knights enough for you? Why would you need more than that? Or even that many. Fifty knights are expensive to maintain, and there’s always a risk they’ll rebel. How could so many people, under two masters, get along under one roof? It would be hard, almost impossible.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Why might not you, my lord, receive attendance$NEWLINE$From those that she calls servants, or from mine?
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Why couldn’t you be attended by my servants, or by Regan’s?

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Why not, my lord? If then they chanced to slack you,$NEWLINE$We could control them. If you will come to me—$NEWLINE$For now I spy a danger—I entreat you$NEWLINE$To bring but five and twenty. To no more$NEWLINE$Will I give place or notice.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Yes, why not, my lord? Then if they’re negligent, we could control them. Now that I think about the danger of these knights, if you come to stay with me, please bring no more than twenty-five of them with you. I won’t lodge any more than that under my roof.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$I gave you all—
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I gave you everything—

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$And in good time you gave it.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$And it was about time too.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Made you my guardians, my depositaries,$NEWLINE$But kept a reservation to be followed$NEWLINE$With such a number. What, must I come to you$NEWLINE$With five and twenty, Regan? Said you so?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I made you de facto rulers of my kingdom on condition that I could keep a hundred knights of my own. Why should I now have to make do with only twenty-five? Regan, is that what you said?

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$And speak ’t again, my lord. No more with me.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Yes, I’ll say it again, my lord. No more than twenty-five.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Those wicked creatures yet do look well favored$NEWLINE$When others are more wicked. Not being the worst$NEWLINE$Stands in some rank of praise.$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL) I’ll go with thee.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thy fifty yet doth double five and twenty,$NEWLINE$And thou art twice her love.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Bad people start to look better in comparison with worse people. Not being the worst daughter deserves some praise, I guess. (to GONERIL) I’ll go stay with you, then. Your fifty is twice her twenty-five, so you must love me twice as much as she does.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Hear me, my lord.$NEWLINE$What need you five and twenty, ten, or five$NEWLINE$To follow in a house where twice so many$NEWLINE$Have a command to tend you?
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Hear me out, my lord. Why do you need twenty-five knights, or ten, or even five, when you’re staying in a house with a staff of double that at your service?

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$What need one?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Why do you need even one?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$O, reason not the need! Our basest beggars$NEWLINE$Are in the poorest thing superfluous.$NEWLINE$Allow not nature more than nature needs,$NEWLINE$Man’s life’s as cheap as beast’s. Thou art a lady.$NEWLINE$If only to go warm were gorgeous,$NEWLINE$Why, nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear’st,$NEWLINE$Which scarcely keeps thee warm. But, for true need—$NEWLINE$You heavens, give me that patience, patience I need.$NEWLINE$You see me here, you gods, a poor old man,$NEWLINE$As full of grief as age, wretched in both.$NEWLINE$If it be you that stir these daughters' hearts$NEWLINE$Against their father, fool me not so much$NEWLINE$To bear it tamely. Touch me with noble anger.$NEWLINE$And let not women’s weapons, water drops,$NEWLINE$Stain my man’s cheeks! No, you unnatural hags,
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Oh, don’t ask me why I “need” them! Even the poorest beggars have some meager possessions they don’t really “need.” If you allow people no more than what they absolutely need to survive, then a human life is no better than an animal’s. You’re a well-dressed lady. If you dressed only to stay warm, you wouldn’t need these gorgeous clothes you’re wearing—which don’t keep you warm at all. If you want to talk about true needs, what I really need is patience. Oh, gods, give me patience! You see me here, gods, a grieving old man, as wretched in his grief as he is in his old age. If you’re the ones setting my daughters against me, don’t let me be foolish enough to take it lying down. Give me noble anger, and don’t let any womanly tears fall down my

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I will have such revenges on you both$NEWLINE$That all the world shall—I will do such things—$NEWLINE$What they are yet I know not, but they shall be$NEWLINE$The terrors of the earth. You think I’ll weep?$NEWLINE$No, I’ll not weep.
paragraphs.translated: man’s cheeks. No, you monstrous hags, I’ll get revenge on you both that will make the whole world… I will do such things—I don’t know what I’ll do exactly, but it’ll be devastating. You expect me to cry? Well, I won’t.

paragraphs.original: Storm and tempest
paragraphs.translated: A storm breaks out.

paragraphs.original: I have full cause of weeping, but this heart$NEWLINE$Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws,$NEWLINE$Or ere I’ll weep.—O Fool, I shall go mad!
paragraphs.translated: I have a good reason to cry, but my heart will splinter into a hundred thousand pieces before I let myself cry.—Oh, Fool, I’ll go mad!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LEAR, GENTLEMAN, FOOL, and GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: King LEAR, the GENTLEMAN, and the FOOL exit with GLOUCESTER.$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Let us withdraw. 'Twill be a storm.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Let’s go inside. There’s going to be a storm.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$This house is little. The old man and his people$NEWLINE$Cannot be well bestowed.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$This is a small house. There’s no room for the old man and his followers.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$'Tis his own blame. Hath put himself from rest,$NEWLINE$And must needs taste his folly.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$It’s his fault that he’s all worked up like this. He has to pay the price for his foolish actions.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$For his particular I’ll receive him gladly,$NEWLINE$But not one follower.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$I’ll be happy to keep him in my house, but not a single knight.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$So am I purposed.$NEWLINE$Where is my lord of Gloucester?
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$That’s what I intend to do too. Where is Gloucester?

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Followed the old man forth. He is returned.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$He followed the old man. Here he comes back.

paragraphs.original: Enter GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER returns.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$The king is in high rage.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$The king is enraged.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Whither is he going?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Where’s he going?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He calls to horse, but will I know not whither.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He has called for his horse, but I don’t know where he’s headed.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$'Tis best to give him way. He leads himself.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$It’s best just to let him go. He won’t listen to anyone’s advice.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(to GLOUCESTER) My lord, entreat him by no means to stay.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(to GLOUCESTER) My lord, don’t try to persuade him to stay.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Alack, the night comes on, and the high winds$NEWLINE$Do sorely ruffle. For many miles about$NEWLINE$There’s scarce a bush.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Ah, but it’s getting dark, and the winds are strong and stormy. There’s hardly a bush for miles around. He’ll have no shelter.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$O sir, to wilful men,$NEWLINE$The injuries that they themselves procure$NEWLINE$Must be their schoolmasters. Shut up your doors.$NEWLINE$He is attended with a desperate train.$NEWLINE$And what they may incense him to, being apt$NEWLINE$To have his ear abused, wisdom bids fear.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Oh, sir, impetuous people learn their lessons from the consequences of their foolish actions. Lock the doors. His attendants are desperate, violent men. I’m afraid of what they might encourage him to do, considering the state he’s in.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Shut up your doors, my lord. 'Tis a wild night.$NEWLINE$My Regan counsels well. Come out o' th' storm.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Lock the doors, my lord. It’s a wild night. Regan gives good advice. Come in out of the storm.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Storm still Enter KENT disguised and GENTLEMAN, severally$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated: The storm continues to rage. KENT enters in disguise. The GENTLEMAN enters from a different direction.$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Who’s there, besides foul weather?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Who’s there, aside from this foul weather?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$One minded like the weather, most unquietly.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Someone whose mood is as foul as the weather, very troubled.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I know you. Where’s the king?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I know you. Where’s the king?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Contending with the fretful elements.$NEWLINE$Bids the winds blow the earth into the sea$NEWLINE$Or swell the curlèd water 'bove the main,$NEWLINE$That things might change or cease. Tears his white hair,$NEWLINE$Which the impetuous blasts, with eyeless rage,$NEWLINE$Catch in their fury and make nothing of.$NEWLINE$Strives in his little world of man to outscorn$NEWLINE$The to-and-fro–conflicting wind and rain.$NEWLINE$This night—wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch,$NEWLINE$The lion and the belly-pinchèd wolf$NEWLINE$Keep their fur dry—unbonneted he runs,$NEWLINE$And bids what will take all.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Struggling with the wind and rain. He’s shouting at the wind to blow the earth into the sea, or make the sea flood the earth—he wants to see the world return to primal chaos. He keeps tearing out his white hair, which the blindly raging winds catch up and blow away into nothingness. Small but brave in his surroundings, he’s trying to stand up against the wind and rain blowing back and forth. He’s running bareheaded, calling for the end of the world, out there on a night like this, when even savage animals ravenous with hunger crawl under cover and hide.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$But who is with him?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$But who’s with him?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$None but the fool, who labors to outjest$NEWLINE$His heart-struck injuries.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Nobody but the fool, who’s trying to soothe the wounds in the king’s heart with jokes.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Sir, I do know you,$NEWLINE$And dare upon the warrant of my note$NEWLINE$Commend a dear thing to you. There is division,$NEWLINE$Although as yet the face of it be covered$NEWLINE$With mutual cunning, ’twixt Albany and Cornwall,$NEWLINE$Who have—as who have not that their great stars$NEWLINE$Throned and set high?—servants, who seem no less,$NEWLINE$Which are to France the spies and speculations$NEWLINE$Intelligent of our state. What hath been seen,$NEWLINE$Either in snuffs and packings of the dukes,$NEWLINE$Or the hard rein which both of them hath borne$NEWLINE$Against the old kind king, or something deeper,$NEWLINE$Whereof perchance these are but furnishings—$NEWLINE$But true it is. From France there comes a power$NEWLINE$Into this scattered kingdom, who already,$NEWLINE$Wise in our negligence, have secret feet$NEWLINE$In some of our best ports and are at point$NEWLINE$To show their open banner. Now to you.$NEWLINE$If on my credit you dare build so far$NEWLINE$To make your speed to Dover, you shall find$NEWLINE$Some that will thank you, making just report$NEWLINE$Of how unnatural and bemadding sorrow$NEWLINE$The king hath cause to plain.$NEWLINE$I am a gentleman of blood and breeding,$NEWLINE$And from some knowledge and assurance offer$NEWLINE$This office to you.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Sir, I know you, and I trust you enough to share something very important with you. There’s a feud between Albany and Cornwall, although they’ve been clever enough to hide it thus far. Like other powerful rulers, they have servants who are actually French spies in disguise. These spies have noticed something, perhaps in the squabbles between Albany and Cornwall, or in the tough line both of them have taken against the good old king, or perhaps in some deeper matter at the root of both of these problems—The point is that the King of France has sent troops into our divided kingdom. Some French agents are already at work in our main ports and are on the verge of declaring open war. Now this is where you come in. If you trust me enough to hurry to Dover, you’ll earn the gratitude of many people when you fairly report the monstrous and maddening extent of the king’s suffering. I’m a nobleman, and I know what I’m doing in assigning this job to you.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$I will talk further with you.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Let’s discuss it some more.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(giving GENTLEMAN a purse and a ring)$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$a purse and a ring)$NEWLINE$No, do not.$NEWLINE$For confirmation that I am much more$NEWLINE$Than my outwall, open this purse and take$NEWLINE$What it contains. If you shall see Cordelia—$NEWLINE$As fear not but you shall—show her this ring.$NEWLINE$And she will tell you who that fellow is$NEWLINE$That yet you do not know. Fie on this storm!$NEWLINE$I will go seek the king.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$(giving the GENTLEMAN a purse and a ring) No, there’s no need. To assure you that I am a nobleman in disguise, here is some money. If you see Cordelia—as I’m sure you will—show her this ring. She’ll tell you who I am. Damn this storm! I’ll go find the king.$NEWLINE$(giving the$NEWLINE$a purse and a ring)

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Give me your hand. Have you no more to say?
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Let me shake your hand. Do you have anything else to tell me?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Few words, but to effect more than all yet:$NEWLINE$That when we have found the king—in which your pain$NEWLINE$That way; I’ll this—he that first lights on him$NEWLINE$Holla the other.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Only a few more words, but they’re the most important. Let me go this way, and you go that way. When one of us finds the king, he’ll call out to the other one.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit in opposite directions.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Storm still Enter LEAR and FOOL$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: The storm continues. LEAR and the FOOL enter.$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! Rage, blow!$NEWLINE$You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout$NEWLINE$Till you have drenched our steeples, drowned the cocks!$NEWLINE$You sulfurous and thought-executing fires,$NEWLINE$Vaunt-couriers of oak-cleaving thunderbolts,$NEWLINE$Singe my white head! And thou, all-shaking thunder,$NEWLINE$Smite flat the thick rotundity o' th' world,$NEWLINE$Crack nature’s molds, all germens spill at once$NEWLINE$That make ingrateful man!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Blow, winds! Blow until your cheeks crack! Rage on, blow! Let tornadoes spew water until the steeples of our churches and the weathervanes are all drowned. Let quick sulfurous lightning, strong enough to split enormous trees, singe the white hair on my head. Let thunder flatten the spherical world, crack open all the molds from which nature forms human beings, and spill all the seeds from which ungrateful humans grow!

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$O nuncle, court holy water in a dry house is better than this rainwater out o' door. Good nuncle, in, and ask thy daughters blessing. Here’s a night pities neither wise man nor fool.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Oh, uncle, it’s better to smile and flatter indoors where it’s dry than get soaked out here. Please, uncle, let’s go in and ask your daughters to forgive you. This storm has no pity for either wise men or fools.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Rumble thy bellyful! Spit, fire! Spout, rain!$NEWLINE$Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire are my daughters.$NEWLINE$I tax not you, you elements, with unkindness.$NEWLINE$I never gave you kingdom, called you children.$NEWLINE$You owe me no subscription. Why then, let fall$NEWLINE$Your horrible pleasure. Here I stand, your slave—$NEWLINE$A poor, infirm, weak, and despised old man.$NEWLINE$But yet I call you servile ministers,$NEWLINE$That will with two pernicious daughters joined$NEWLINE$Your high engendered battles 'gainst a head$NEWLINE$So old and white as this. Oh, ho! 'Tis foul.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Let thunder rumble! Let lightning spit fire! Let the rain spray! The rain, the wind, the thunder and lightning are not my daughters. Nature, I don’t accuse your weather of unkindness. I never gave you a kingdom or raised you as my child, and you don’t owe me any obedience. So go ahead and have your terrifying fun. Here I am, your slave—a poor, sick, weak, hated old man. But I can still accuse you of kowtowing, taking my daughters' side against me, ancient as I am. Oh, it’s foul!

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$He that has a house to put ’s head in has a good headpiece.$NEWLINE$The codpiece that will house
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Anyone who has a house to cover his head has a good head on his shoulders.$NEWLINE$The guy who finds a place to put his penis$NEWLINE$Before he has a house of his own$NEWLINE$Will wind up dirt poor and covered with lice

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Before the head has any—$NEWLINE$The head and he shall louse.$NEWLINE$So beggars marry many.$NEWLINE$The man that makes his toe$NEWLINE$What he his heart should make$NEWLINE$Shall of a corn cry woe,$NEWLINE$And turn his sleep to wake.$NEWLINE$For there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths$NEWLINE$in a glass.
paragraphs.translated: With a crowd of slut daughters to add to the slut wife.$NEWLINE$The man who kicks away$NEWLINE$The person he should love$NEWLINE$Will bring himself pain$NEWLINE$And sleepless nights.$NEWLINE$For there never was a pretty woman who didn’t like to preen in the mirror.

paragraphs.original: Enter KENT disguised$NEWLINE$KENT
paragraphs.translated: KENT enters in disguise.$NEWLINE$KENT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, I will be the pattern of all patience.$NEWLINE$I will say nothing.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, I’ll be patient. I won’t say a word.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Who’s there?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Who’s there?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Marry, here’s grace and a codpiece—that’s a wise man and a fool.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$A wise man and a fool.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) Alas, sir, are you here? Things that love night$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Love not such nights as these. The wrathful skies$NEWLINE$Gallow the very wanderers of the dark$NEWLINE$And make them keep their caves. Snce I was man,$NEWLINE$Such sheets of fire, such bursts of horrid thunder,$NEWLINE$Such groans of roaring wind and rain I never$NEWLINE$Remember to have heard. Man’s nature cannot carry$NEWLINE$Th' affliction nor the fear.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) Ah, sir, you’re here? Even creatures of the night aren’t out tonight in this storm. The angry skies terrify the animals that usually prowl in the dark, making them stay in their caves. Never in my life have I heard such horrible blasts of thunder, such a roaring downpour, such groaning winds. It’s too trying and terrifying for humans to bear.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Let the great gods$NEWLINE$That keep this dreadful pudder o'er our heads$NEWLINE$Find out their enemies now. Tremble, thou wretch$NEWLINE$That hast within thee undivulgèd crimes$NEWLINE$Unwhipped of justice. Hide thee, thou bloody hand,$NEWLINE$Thou perjured, and thou simular man of virtue
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Let the gods who stirred up this dreadful storm bring their enemies to light. Any wretched person who has committed secret crimes and escaped justice should tremble in fear now. Better hide now, you murderers, you perjurers, you incest-practicing people who pretend to be virtuous. Tremble and shake, villain, for secretly plotting against human lives. Let all your bottled-up crimes come flooding out at last, as you beg for

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: That art incestuous. Caitiff, to pieces shake,$NEWLINE$That under covert and convenient seeming$NEWLINE$Hast practiced on man’s life. Close pent-up guilts,$NEWLINE$Rive your concealing continents and cry$NEWLINE$These dreadful summoners grace. I am a man$NEWLINE$More sinned against than sinning.
paragraphs.translated: mercy from the gods who summon these terrifying winds and thunderbolts. Other people have sinned against me more than I have sinned against them.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Alack, bareheaded?$NEWLINE$Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel.$NEWLINE$Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest.$NEWLINE$Repose you there, while I to this hard house—$NEWLINE$More harder than the stones whereof ’tis raised,$NEWLINE$Which even but now, demanding after you,$NEWLINE$Denied me to come in—return, and force$NEWLINE$Their scanted courtesy.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Why, you’re not even wearing a hat? My lord, there’s a hut nearby. It will give you some protection from this storm. Rest there while I go back to the unfriendly house where your sisters are staying, and ask them for help. They are harder than the stones the house is made of. Just now, when I asked them if they knew where you were, they wouldn’t let me in. But I’ll go back and force them to be polite.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$My wits begin to turn.—$NEWLINE$(to FOOL)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Come on, my boy. How dost, my boy? Art cold?$NEWLINE$I am cold myself.$NEWLINE$(to KENT)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Where is this straw, my fellow?$NEWLINE$The art of our necessities is strange$NEWLINE$That can make vile things precious. Come, your hovel.$NEWLINE$Poor fool and knave, I have one part in my heart$NEWLINE$That’s sorry yet for thee.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I’m starting to lose my mind. (to the FOOL) Come on, my boy. How are you? Are you cold? I’m cold myself. (to KENT) Where’s this hut, man? Odd how when you’re desperate, even shoddy things like this hut can seem precious. Show me where that hut is. Poor fool, part of me still feels sorry for you.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$He that has and a little tiny wit—$NEWLINE$He that has and a little tiny wit—$NEWLINE$With heigh-ho, the wind and the rain—$NEWLINE$With heigh-ho, the wind and the rain—$NEWLINE$Must make content with his fortunes fit,$NEWLINE$Must make content with his fortunes fit,$NEWLINE$For the rain it raineth every day.$NEWLINE$For the rain it raineth every day.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$The stupid man—$NEWLINE$The stupid man—$NEWLINE$Hey-hoy, the wind and the rain—$NEWLINE$Hey-hoy, the wind and the rain—$NEWLINE$Must take what he can get,$NEWLINE$Must take what he can get,$NEWLINE$Since the rain comes every day.$NEWLINE$Since the rain comes every day.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$True, my good boy.—Come, bring us to this hovel.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$That’s true, my good boy.—Come on, take us to that hut.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LEAR and KENT$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$KENT
paragraphs.translated: LEAR and KENT exit.$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$KENT

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$This is a brave night to cool a courtesan.$NEWLINE$I’ll speak a prophecy ere I go.$NEWLINE$When priests are more in word than matter,$NEWLINE$When brewers mar their malt with water,$NEWLINE$When nobles are their tailors' tutors,$NEWLINE$No heretics burned but wenches' suitors,$NEWLINE$When every case in law is right,$NEWLINE$No squire in debt nor no poor knight,$NEWLINE$When slanders do not live in tongues,$NEWLINE$Nor cutpurses come not to throngs,$NEWLINE$When usurers tell their gold i' th' field,$NEWLINE$And bawds and whores do churches build—$NEWLINE$Then shall the realm of Albion$NEWLINE$Come to great confusion.$NEWLINE$Then comes the time, who lives to see ’t,$NEWLINE$That going shall be used with feet.$NEWLINE$This prophecy Merlin shall make, for I live before his time.
paragraphs.translated:
FOOL$NEWLINE$This would be a great night to satisfy a whore’s lust. I’ll recite a prophecy before I go.$NEWLINE$One day, when priests don’t practice what they preach,$NEWLINE$When brewers dilute their beer with water,$NEWLINE$When noblemen teach their tailors how to sew,$NEWLINE$When instead of heretics being burned at the stake, lovers are burned by syphilis,$NEWLINE$When every law case is tried fairly,$NEWLINE$When no gentleman is in debt,$NEWLINE$When no one slanders anyone else,$NEWLINE$And thieves don’t snatch wallets in crowds,$NEWLINE$When moneylenders count their gold in the open air,$NEWLINE$And pimps and whores build fine churches—$NEWLINE$Then the kingdom of England$NEWLINE$Will come to ruin.$NEWLINE$And whoever lives to see that day$NEWLINE$Will walk with his feet.$NEWLINE$This is the prophecy that the wizard
Merlin will make one day. I’m a little ahead of my time in saying it now.$NEWLINE$Merlin$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter GLOUCESTER and EDMUND the bastard, with lights$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$EDMUND
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER and EDMUND enter with torches.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$EDMUND

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Alack, alack, Edmund, I like not this unnatural dealing. When I desire their leave that I might pity him, they took from me the use of mine own house, charged me on pain of their perpetual displeasure neither to speak of him, entreat for him, nor any way sustain him.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Oh, oh, Edmund, I don’t like this monstrous business. When asked the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall if I could take pity on the king and shelter him from the storm, they took my house away from me and ordered me never to talk about him, lobby for him, or support him in any way.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Most savage and unnatural!
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$That’s uncivilized and unnatural!

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Go to, say you nothing. There’s a division betwixt the dukes. And a worse matter than that: I have received a letter this night. 'Tis dangerous to be spoken. I have locked the letter in my closet. These injuries the king now bears will be revenged home. There’s part of a power already footed. We must incline to the king. I will look him and privily relieve him. Go you and maintain talk with the duke, that my charity be not of him perceived. If he ask for me, I am ill and gone to bed. Though I die for it—as no less is threatened me—the king my old master must be relieved. There is some strange thing toward, Edmund. Pray you, be careful.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Oh, be quiet. There’s a feud between the two dukes. And there’s something even worse than that. I got a letter tonight. It’s dangerous to talk about it. I’ve locked it up in my room. The humiliation that the king is suffering now will be revenged thoroughly. Armed forces have already landed. We have to take the king’s side. I’ll look for him and secretly help him. You go and talk to the duke so he won’t notice I’m helping the king. If he asks to see me, tell him I’m sick and went to bed. Even if I have to die—as they threaten—I have to help the king. Strange things are about to happen, Edmund. Please be careful.

paragraphs.original: Exit GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER exits.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$This courtesy, forbid thee, shall the duke$NEWLINE$Instantly know, and of that letter too.$NEWLINE$This seems a fair deserving, and must draw me$NEWLINE$That which my father loses—no less than all.$NEWLINE$The younger rises when the old doth fall.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’ll tell the duke right away that you’re going to see the king, which is forbidden. And I’ll tell him about the letter too. You’ll get what you deserve, and I’ll be rewarded with everything you lose—in other words, all your lands. The young generation rises while the old one falls.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LEAR, KENT disguised, and FOOL$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: LEAR enters with KENT in disguise and the FOOL.$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Here is the place, my lord. Good my lord, enter.$NEWLINE$The tyranny of the open night’s too rough$NEWLINE$For nature to endure.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Here’s the hut, my lord. Please go inside. The night’s too rough for humans to bear.

paragraphs.original: Storm still
paragraphs.translated: The storm continues.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Let me alone.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Leave me for a bit.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Good my lord, enter here.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$My lord, here is the entrance.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Wilt break my heart?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Will you break my heart?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I had rather break mine own. Good my lord, enter.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I’d rather break my own heart. Now please go in.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Thou think’st ’tis much that this contentious storm$NEWLINE$Invades us to the skin. So ’tis to thee.$NEWLINE$But where the greater malady is fixed$NEWLINE$The lesser is scarce felt. Thou’dst shun a bear,$NEWLINE$But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea$NEWLINE$Thou’dst meet the bear i' th' mouth. When the mind’s free,$NEWLINE$The body’s delicate. The tempest in my mind$NEWLINE$Doth from my senses take all feeling else$NEWLINE$Save what beats there—filial ingratitude.$NEWLINE$Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand$NEWLINE$For lifting food to ’t? But I will punish home.$NEWLINE$No, I will weep no more. In such a night$NEWLINE$To shut me out! Pour on, I will endure.$NEWLINE$In such a night as this! O Regan, Goneril,$NEWLINE$Your old kind father, whose frank heart gave all—$NEWLINE$Oh, that way madness lies. Let me shun that.$NEWLINE$No more of that.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$You think it’s a big deal that this fierce storm is soaking me to the skin. It’s a big deal to you. But whenever you feel a larger pain, the smaller one disappears. You would run away from a bear, but if the only way to run was into the stormy ocean, you’d turn around and confront the bear. When your mind is at peace, your body is sensitive to the elements. But this storm in my mind keeps me from feeling anything except what’s tormenting me—how ungrateful my children are! Isn’t their ingratitude like the mouth biting the hand that feeds it? But I’ll punish them thoroughly. No, I won’t cry any more. Imagine them locking me out on a night like this! But let it rain; I’ll survive. On a night like this! Oh, Regan, Goneril, your kind old father whose generous heart gave you everything—Oh, if I think about that I’ll go mad. I want to avoid that. No more of these thoughts.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Good my lord, enter here.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$My lord, please go inside here.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Prithee, go in thyself. Seek thine own ease.$NEWLINE$This tempest will not give me leave to ponder$NEWLINE$On things would hurt me more. But I’ll go in.$NEWLINE$(to FOOL) In, boy. Go first. You houseless poverty—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Nay, get thee in. I’ll pray, and then I’ll sleep.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Go inside yourself. Make yourself comfortable. This storm protects me from thoughts that would hurt me more. But I’ll go in. (to FOOL) You go in first, boy. Oh, you suffering homeless people—No, you go in. I’ll pray first, then I’ll sleep.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit FOOL$NEWLINE$FOOL
paragraphs.translated: The FOOL exits.$NEWLINE$FOOL

paragraphs.original: Poor naked wretches, whereso'er you are,$NEWLINE$That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm,$NEWLINE$How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides,$NEWLINE$Your looped and windowed raggedness, defend you$NEWLINE$From seasons such as these? Oh, I have ta'en$NEWLINE$Too little care of this! Take physic, pomp.$NEWLINE$Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel,$NEWLINE$That thou mayst shake the superflux to them$NEWLINE$And show the heavens more just.
paragraphs.translated: Poor homeless creatures suffering this storm, wherever you are, how will you survive a night like this with no roof over your heads, no fat on your sides to keep you warm, and only rags for clothes? When I was king I didn’t do enough to help you. Powerful men, take your medicine by learning about hardship. Go out and feel what the impoverished feel. Then you can give them your extra wealth and make the world more fair.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(within) Fathom and half, fathom and half! Poor Tom!$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(from inside) The water in here is nine feet deep! Poor Tom!$NEWLINE$(from inside)

paragraphs.original: Enter FOOL
paragraphs.translated: FOOL enters.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Come not in here, nuncle. Here’s a spirit. Help me, help me!
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Don’t come in here, uncle! There’s a spirit in here! Help me, help me!

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Give me thy hand. Who’s there?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Give me your hand. Who’s there?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$A spirit, a spirit. He says his name’s Poor Tom.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$A ghost, a ghost! He says his name’s Poor Tom.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$What art thou that dost grumble there i' th' straw?$NEWLINE$Come forth.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Who are you, moaning in the hut like that? Come out.

paragraphs.original: Enter EDGAR disguised$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR enters disguised.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Away! The foul fiend follows me! Through the sharp hawthorn blows the cold wind. Hum! Go to thy cold bed and warm thee.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Go away! The devil’s after me! The cold wind blows through the hawthorn trees. Ha! Get into your cold beds and warm yourselves up.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Didst thou give all to thy two daughters, and art thou come to this?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Did you give everything to your two daughters and end up like this?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Who gives any thing to Poor Tom, whom the foul fiend hath led through fire and through flame, through ford and whirlipool, o'er bog and quagmire; that hath laid knives under his pillow and halters in his pew, set ratsbane by his porridge, made him proud of heart to ride on a bay trotting- horse over four-inched bridges to course his own shadow for a traitor? Bless thy five wits. Tom’s a-cold. Oh, do-de, do-de, do-de. Bless thee from whirlwinds, star-blasting, and taking! Do Poor Tom some charity, whom the foul fiend vexes. There could I have him now—and there—and there again—and there.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Whoever gave a thing to Poor Tom? The devil has chased him through fires, across rivers and whirlpools, and over swamps. The devil has put knives under Tom’s pillow and hangman’s ropes in his church pew, encouraging him to kill himself. The devil has put rat poison next to Poor Tom’s oatmeal and made him gallop his horse over narrow bridges, chasing his own shadow as if it were a traitor. Bless your five senses! Tom’s chilly. Oh do-de, do-de, do-de. God protect you from tornadoes, evil stars, and diseases! Take pity on Poor Tom, who is persecuted by the devil. I can almost catch him. There!… And over there!… And over there!

paragraphs.original: Storm still
paragraphs.translated: The storm continues.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$What, has his daughters brought him to this pass?—$NEWLINE$Couldst thou save nothing? Wouldst thou give 'em all?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Have his daughters made him crazy like this?—Couldn’t you have kept something for yourself? Did you have to give them everything?

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Nay, he reserved a blanket, else we had been all shamed.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, he kept a blanket to cover himself with. If he hadn’t, we’d all be embarrassed to look at him.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Now all the plagues that in the pendulous air$NEWLINE$Hang fated o'er men’s faults light on thy daughters!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Then may your daughters be cursed with all the horrible fates that await sinners!

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$He hath no daughters, sir.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$He doesn’t have any daughters, sir.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Death, traitor! Nothing could have subdued nature$NEWLINE$To such a lowness but his unkind daughters.$NEWLINE$Is it the fashion that discarded fathers$NEWLINE$Should have thus little mercy on their flesh?$NEWLINE$Judicious punishment! 'Twas this flesh begot$NEWLINE$Those pelican daughters.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Like hell! Nothing but cruel daughters could have degraded him like this. Is it fashionable now for neglected fathers to get so little pity? That’s a fair punishment! I’m the one who fathered those bloodsucking daughters.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Pillicock sat on Pillicock hill. Alow, alow, loo, loo!
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Pillicock sat on Pillicock hill. La, la, la, la!$NEWLINE$Pillicock$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$This stormy night will turn us all into fools and madmen.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Take heed o' th' foul fiend. Obey thy parents, keep thy word’s justice, swear not, commit not with man’s sworn spouse, set not thy sweet heart on proud array. Tom’s a- cold.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Beware of the devil. Obey your parents, keep your word, don’t swear, don’t sleep with another man’s wife, and don’t covet flashy clothes. Tom’s chilly.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$What hast thou been?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$What were you before this?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$A servingman, proud in heart and mind, that curled my hair, wore gloves in my cap, served the lust of my mistress' heart and did the act of darkness with her, swore as many oaths as I spake words and broke them in the sweet face of heaven—one that slept in the contriving of lust and waked to do it. Wine loved I deeply, dice dearly, and in woman outparamoured the Turk. False of heart, light of ear, bloody of hand—hog in sloth, fox in stealth, wolf in greediness, dog in madness, lion in prey. Let not the creaking of shoes nor the rustling of silks betray thy poor heart to woman. Keep thy foot out of brothels, thy hand out of plackets, thy pen from lenders' books, and defy the foul fiend. Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind, says, “Suum, mun, nonny.” Dauphin my boy, my boy, cessez. Let him trot by.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I used to be an honorable devoted servant who curled his hair, wore his mistress’s glove in his hat as a token of her affection, and slept with his mistress whenever she wanted. I swore oaths with every other word out of my mouth, and broke the oaths shamelessly. I used to dream of having sex and wake up to do it. I loved wine and gambling, and had more women than a Turkish sultan keeps in his harem. I was disloyal and violent. I eavesdropped. I was as lazy as a hog, as sneaky as a fox, as greedy as a wolf, as mad as a dog, and as ruthless as a lion. Don’t ever let a woman know what you’re thinking. Stay away from whores, don’t chase skirts, don’t borrow money, and resist the devil. The cold wind’s still blowing through the hawthorn tree. (speaking to an imaginary horse) Dauphin, my boy, stop that.—Let the horse go by.$NEWLINE$(speaking to an imaginary horse)

paragraphs.original: Storm still
paragraphs.translated: The storm continues.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Why, thou wert better in thy grave than to answer with thy uncovered body this extremity of the skies.—Is man no more than this? Consider him well.—Thou owest the worm no silk, the beast no hide, the sheep no wool, the cat no perfume. Ha! Here’s three on ’s are sophisticated. Thou art the thing itself.$NEWLINE$Unaccommodated man is no more but such a poor, bare, forked animal as thou art.—$NEWLINE$Off, off, you lendings! Come. Unbutton here. (tears at his clothes)$NEWLINE$(tears at his clothes)
paragraphs.translated:
LEAR$NEWLINE$You’d be better off dead than facing the storm as naked as you are. Is this all a human being is? Look at him. (to EDGAR) You are not indebted to animals for your clothes since don’t wear silk, leather, or wool—not even
perfume. Ha! The three of us are sophisticated compared to you. You’re the real thing.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$perfume$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$The human being unburdened by the trappings of civilization is no more than a poor, naked, two-legged animal like you.$NEWLINE$Off with these clothes borrowed from animals! Let me unbutton this. (he tears at his clothes)$NEWLINE$(he tears at his clothes)

paragraphs.original: Enter GLOUCESTER with a torch$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER enters with a torch.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Prithee, nuncle, be contented. 'Tis a naughty night to swim in. Now a little fire in a wild field were like an old lecher’s heart—a small spark, all the rest on ’s body cold. Look, here comes a walking fire.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Please calm down, uncle. This is a nasty night to go swimming. On a night like this a campfire in an empty field would be like the heart of a dirty old man—a tiny spark in a cold body. Look, here comes a walking fire.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet. He begins at curfew and walks till the first cock. He gives the web and the pin, squints the eye and makes the harelip, mildews the white wheat and hurts the poor creature of earth.$NEWLINE$Swithold footed thrice the 'old.$NEWLINE$He met the nightmare and her ninefold,$NEWLINE$Bid her alight,$NEWLINE$And her troth plight.$NEWLINE$And aroint thee, witch, aroint thee!
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$This is the devil Flibbertigibbet. He gets up at nightfall and wanders around till dawn. He can make your eyes squint and film over and give you a harelip. He rots ripened wheat and hurts the poor creatures of the earth.$NEWLINE$Saint Withold crossed the field three times,$NEWLINE$He met a she-demon and her nine kids,$NEWLINE$He told her to promise$NEWLINE$To stop doing harm.$NEWLINE$And go away, witch, go away.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$How fares your grace?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$How are you, your highness?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$(indicating GLOUCESTER) What’s he?$NEWLINE$(indicating$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$(pointing at GLOUCESTER) Who’s that?$NEWLINE$(pointing at$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Who’s there? What is ’t you seek?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Who are you? What do you want?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$What are you there? Your names?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Who are you? What are your names?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Poor Tom, that eats the swimming frog, the toad, the tadpole, the wall newt, and the water; that in the fury of his heart, when the foul fiend rages, eats cow dung for salads, swallows the old rat and the ditch-dog, drinks the green mantle of the standing pool; who is whipped from tithing to tithing and stocked, punished and imprisoned; who hath had three suits to his back, six shirts to his body, Horse to ride and weapon to wear. But mice and rats and such small deer Have been Tom’s food for seven long year. Beware my follower. Peace, Smulkin. Peace, thou fiend!
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Poor Tom, who eats frogs, toads, tadpoles, lizards, and newts. When the devil tells me to, I eat cow dung for salads, I swallow old rats and dead dogs, I drink pond scum. In every village I’m whipped and put in the stocks, punished and imprisoned. But I used to be a respectable servant, with three suits and six shirts. Once I had a horse to ride and a sword to wear, but now poor Tom’s been eating rats and mice for seven long years. Beware of the devil who follows me around. Calm down, Smulkin, you fiend!

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) What, hath your grace no better company?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) Don’t you have anyone more respectable with you, your highness?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$The Prince of Darkness is a gentleman. Modo he’s called, and Mahu.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Oh, the devil is quite a gentleman. He’s called Modo and Mahu.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) Our flesh and blood, my lord, is grown so vile$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$That it doth hate what gets it.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) My lord, our children have become so beastly that they hate their own parents.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Poor Tom’s a-cold.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Poor Tom’s chilly.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Go in with me. My duty cannot suffer$NEWLINE$To obey in all your daughters' hard commands.$NEWLINE$Though their injunction be to bar my doors$NEWLINE$And let this tyrannous night take hold upon you,$NEWLINE$Yet have I ventured to come seek you out$NEWLINE$And bring you where both fire and food is ready.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Come back to my house with me. I couldn’t bear to obey all of your daughters' harsh orders. They commanded me to lock my doors and leave you out in this merciless storm, but I’ve come out here to find you and take you where there’s warmth and food.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$First let me talk with this philosopher.—$NEWLINE$(to EDGAR) What is the cause of thunder?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$First let me talk with this philosopher here.—(to EDGAR) What causes thunder?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) Good my lord, take his offer. Go into the house.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) Sir, please take him up on his offer and go back with him.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$I’ll talk a word with this same learnèd Theban.—$NEWLINE$What is your study?
paragraphs.translated:
LEAR$NEWLINE$I want to chat a bit with this wise
Greek man.—What kind of philosophy do you study?$NEWLINE$Greek$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$How to prevent the fiend and to kill vermin.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$How to keep the devil away and kill rats.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Let me ask you one word in private.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Let me ask you something in private.

paragraphs.original: LEAR and EDGAR talk aside$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: LEAR and EDGAR talk privately.$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(aside to GLOUCESTER)Importune him once more to go, my lord.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$His wits begin t' unsettle.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only GLOUCESTER can hear) Ask him again to return with you, my lord. He’s beginning to lose his mind.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Canst thou blame him?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Can you blame him?

paragraphs.original: Storm still
paragraphs.translated: The storm continues.
