paragraphs.original: His daughters seek his death. Ah, that good Kent—$NEWLINE$He said it would be thus, poor banished man.$NEWLINE$Thou say’st the king grows mad. I’ll tell thee, friend,$NEWLINE$I am almost mad myself. I had a son,$NEWLINE$Now outlawed from my blood. He sought my life,$NEWLINE$But lately, very late. I loved him, friend—$NEWLINE$No father his son dearer. Truth to tell thee,
paragraphs.translated: His daughters want to kill him. Ah, good old Kent said this would happen—that poor, banished man. You say the king is losing his mind. Let me tell you, my friend, I’m almost insane myself. I had a son, whom I’ve legally disowned. He tried to kill me recently, very recently. I loved him, as much as any father ever loved his son. To tell you the truth, I’m crazed with grief.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The grief hath crazed my wits. What a night’s this!$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) I do beseech your grace—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: What a storm! (to LEAR) Your highness, please, I’m begging you—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$O, cry your mercy, sir.—$NEWLINE$(to EDGAR) Noble philosopher, your company.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Excuse me, sir.—(to EDGAR) Noble philosopher, come talk to me.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Tom’s a-cold.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Tom’s chilly.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$In, fellow. There, into th' hovel. Keep thee warm.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Get into the hut, man. Stay warm.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Come let’s in all.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Come on, let’s all go inside.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$This way, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$This way, my lord.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$(indicating EDGAR)$NEWLINE$(indicating$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$With him!$NEWLINE$I will keep still with my philosopher.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$(pointing to EDGAR) I’ll go with him. I want to stay with my philosopher.$NEWLINE$(pointing to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(to GLOUCESTER)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Good my lord, soothe him. Let him take the fellow.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$(to GLOUCESTER) My lord, calm him down. Let him take that guy inside too.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Take him you on.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$All right, bring him along.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(to EDGAR) Sirrah, come on. Go along with us.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$(to EDGAR) Boy, come along with us.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Come, good Athenian.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Come on, my dear Greek philosopher.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$No words, no words. Hush.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Hush, don’t talk.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Child Roland to the dark tower came,$NEWLINE$His word was still “Fie, foh, and fum,$NEWLINE$I smell the blood of a British man.”
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$The young knight Roland came to the dark tower.$NEWLINE$He said, “Fee, fie, fo, fum,$NEWLINE$I smell the blood of an Englishman.”

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CORNWALL and EDMUND$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$EDMUND
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL enters with EDMUND.$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$EDMUND

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$I will have my revenge ere I depart his house.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$I’ll get my revenge before I leave this house.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$How, my lord, I may be censured, that nature thus gives way to loyalty, something fears me to think of.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’m afraid to think how I’ll be criticized for letting my natural affection for my father give way to my loyalty to you.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$I now perceive it was not altogether your brother’s evil disposition made him seek his death, but a provoking merit set awork by a reprovable badness in himself.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Now I realize your brother tried to kill your father not just because your brother is an evil man, but because your father deserved it by being wicked himself.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$How malicious is my fortune, that I must repent to be just! (giving CORNWALL a letter) This is the letter which he spoke of, which approves him an intelligent party to the advantages of France. O heavens, that this treason were not, or not I the detector!$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$a letter)
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$How unlucky am I, having to apologize for doing the right thing! (giving CORNWALL a letter) This is the letter he was talking about, and it confirms he was a spy for France. Oh God, I wish he had never betrayed us, or that I hadn’t been the one to discover his treason.$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$a letter)

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Go with me to the duchess.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Come with me to see the duchess.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$If the matter of this paper be certain, you have mighty business in hand.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$If this letter’s right, you’ve got a lot to deal with.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$True or false, it hath made thee Earl of Gloucester. Seek out where thy father is, that he may be ready for our apprehension.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Right or not, it’s made you the Earl of Gloucester. Go find your father and let him know we’re going to arrest him.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$(aside) If I find him comforting the king, it will stuff his suspicion more fully.(to CORNWALL) I will persevere in my course of loyalty, though the conflict be sore between that and my blood.$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$(to himself) If I catch my father helping the king, he’ll seem even more guily. (to CORNWALL) I’ll do what I must loyally, even though it pains me to take action against my father.$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$I will lay trust upon thee, and thou shalt find a dearer father in my love.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$I put my trust in you. You’ll see that I’m a better father to you than Gloucester.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter GLOUCESTER, LEAR, KENT disguised, FOOL, and EDGAR disguised$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER enters with LEAR, the FOOL, and KENT and EDGAR, both in disguise.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$FOOL$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Here is better than the open air. Take it thankfully. I will piece out the comfort with what addition I can. I will not be long from you.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$It’s better here than outside. Be happy about it. I’ll do what I can to make you even more comfortable. I won’t be gone long.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$All the power of his wits have given way to his impatience.$NEWLINE$The gods reward your kindness!
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$He can’t bear his grief and so he’s losing his mind. May God reward you for your kindness!

paragraphs.original: Exit GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER exits.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Frateretto calls me and tells me Nero is an angler in the lake of darkness. Pray, innocent, and beware the foul fiend.
paragraphs.translated:
EDGAR$NEWLINE$The devil Frateretto is telling me that the diabolical Roman emperor
Nero likes to go fishing in hell. Pray to the gods, you fool, and beware the foul devil.$NEWLINE$Nero$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Prithee, nuncle, tell me whether a madman be a gentleman or a yeoman?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Here’s a riddle, uncle. Is the lunatic a gentleman or an ordinary guy?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$A king, a king!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$He’s a king, a king!

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, he’s a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son, for he’s a mad yeoman that sees his son a gentleman before him.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$No, he’s an ordinary guy who ’s got a gentleman for a son, since someone would have to be crazy to let his son become a gentleman before he’s achieved that distinction himself.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$To have a thousand with red burning spits$NEWLINE$Come hissing in upon 'em!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I see Regan and Goneril in hell—A thousand hissing devils with sizzling red pitchforks come up to them!

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$The foul fiend bites my back.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$The nasty devil’s biting my butt.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$He’s mad that trusts in the tameness of a wolf, a horse’s health, a boy’s love, or a whore’s oath.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$You’ve got to be crazy to trust a wolf that pretends to be tame, a horse that seems healthy, a teenager in love, or a whore who swears she’ll be faithful.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$It shall be done. I will arraign them straight.$NEWLINE$(to EDGAR) Come, sit thou here, most learnèd justicer.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to FOOL)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thou, sapient sir, sit here.—Now, you she-foxes—
paragraphs.translated:
LEAR$NEWLINE$I’ll do it. I’ll put them on
trial right now. (to EDGAR) Come sit here, our able judge. (to FOOL) And you sit here, wise sir.—Now, you she-foxes—$NEWLINE$trial$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Look, where he stands and glares!—Want’st thou eyes at trial, madam?$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Come o'er the bourn, Bessy, to me—$NEWLINE$Come o'er the bourn, Bessy, to me—
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$There he is, standing and glaring at me!—Hey, lady, can’t you see how the judge is?$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Come over the stream to me, dear Bessy—$NEWLINE$Come over the stream to me, dear Bessy—

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Her boat hath a leak,$NEWLINE$Her boat hath a leak,$NEWLINE$And she must not speak$NEWLINE$And she must not speak$NEWLINE$Why she dares not come over to thee.$NEWLINE$Why she dares not come over to thee.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$She’s getting her period,$NEWLINE$She’s getting her period,$NEWLINE$And she won’t tell you$NEWLINE$And she won’t tell you$NEWLINE$Why she won’t come see you.$NEWLINE$Why she won’t come see you.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$The foul fiend haunts Poor Tom in the voice of a nightingale. Hoppedance cries in Tom’s belly for two white herring. Croak not, black angel. I have no food for thee.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$The devil sings like a nightingale to haunt Poor Tom. The demon Hoppedance is in Tom’s belly, crying for some fish to eat. Stop whining, devil. I’ve got no food to give you.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) How do you, sir? Stand you not so amazed.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Will you lie down and rest upon the cushions?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) How are you, sir? Please don’t stand there in a daze. Wouldn’t you like to lie down on the pillows?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$I’ll see their trial first. Bring in the evidence.$NEWLINE$(to EDGAR) Thou robèd man of justice, take thy place.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to FOOL) And thou, his yoke-fellow of equity,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Bench by his side.$NEWLINE$(to KENT)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$You are o' th' commission.$NEWLINE$Sit you too.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, I want to see their trial first. Let’s have the evidence. (to EDGAR) Take your place, honorable judge. (to FOOL) And you, his fellow justice of the peace, sit next to him. (to KENT) You can also be a judge. Sit down as well.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Let us deal justly.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Let’s give a fair verdict.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: (sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Sleepest or wakest thou, jolly shepherd?$NEWLINE$Sleepest or wakest thou, jolly shepherd?$NEWLINE$Thy sheep be in the corn.$NEWLINE$Thy sheep be in the corn.$NEWLINE$And for one blast of thy minikin mouth,$NEWLINE$And for one blast of thy minikin mouth,$NEWLINE$Thy sheep shall take no harm.$NEWLINE$Thy sheep shall take no harm.$NEWLINE$Purr! The cat is gray.$NEWLINE$Purr! The cat is gray.
paragraphs.translated: (sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Are you asleep or awake, happy shepherd?$NEWLINE$Are you asleep or awake, happy shepherd?$NEWLINE$Your sheep are running around the cornfield.$NEWLINE$Your sheep are running around the cornfield.$NEWLINE$But if you blow your cute little horn,$NEWLINE$But if you blow your cute little horn,$NEWLINE$Your sheep will be fine.$NEWLINE$Your sheep will be fine.$NEWLINE$Purr! The devil-cat is gray.$NEWLINE$Purr! The devil-cat is gray.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Arraign her first. 'Tis Goneril. I here take my oath before this honorable assembly, she kicked the poor king her father.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Let’s put Goneril on trial first. There she is. I hereby swear before this honored assembly that she kicked her father when he was down.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Come hither, mistress. Is your name Goneril?
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$Come here, ma'am. Is your name Goneril?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$She cannot deny it.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$She can’t deny it.

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$Cry you mercy, I took you for a joint-stool.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$I’m so sorry, ma'am, I thought you were a good person, a well-made chair instead of a crude stool.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$And here’s another, whose warped looks proclaim$NEWLINE$What store her heart is made on. Stop her there!$NEWLINE$Arms, arms, sword, fire, corruption in the place!$NEWLINE$False justicer, why hast thou let her ’scape?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$And here’s Regan, whose grotesque face betrays her twisted heart. Stop her! Guards, guards, use your weapons. Fire! The courtroom is in chaos. You corrupt judge, why did you let her escape?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Bless thy five wits.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Bless your heart.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) O pity! Sir, where is the patience now,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$That thou so oft have boasted to retain?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) How sorrowful! Sir, where’s the self-control you used to be so proud of?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(aside) My tears begin to take his part so much,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$They’ll mar my counterfeiting.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to himself) I feel so sorry for him that my tears are starting to ruin my disguise.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$The little dogs and all,$NEWLINE$Tray, Blanch, and Sweetheart—see, they bark at me.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Look at the three little dogs, Tray, Blanch, and Sweetheart—all barking at me.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Tom will throw his head at them.—Avaunt, you curs!$NEWLINE$Tooth that poisons if it bite,$NEWLINE$Mastiff, greyhound, mongrel grim,
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Tom will chase them off.—Go away, you mongrels!$NEWLINE$Whether you bite to kill,$NEWLINE$Mastiff, greyhound, or ugly mutt,

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Hound or spaniel, brach or him,$NEWLINE$Bobtail tyke or trundle-tail—$NEWLINE$Tom will make them weep and wail.$NEWLINE$For with throwing thus my head,$NEWLINE$Dogs leap the hatch, and all are fled.$NEWLINE$Be thy mouth or black or white,$NEWLINE$Do-de, de-de. Cessez! Come, march to wakes and fairs and market towns. Poor Tom, thy horn is dry.
paragraphs.translated: Hound or spaniel, bitch or dog,$NEWLINE$Whether your tail is short or curly—$NEWLINE$Tom will make you cry and wail.$NEWLINE$With one little toss of his head,$NEWLINE$He can scare you off for good.$NEWLINE$Whether your mouth is black or white,$NEWLINE$Do-dee, dee-dee da. Stop! Run off, go visit fairs and festivals! Poor Tom, your cup is empty.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Then let them anatomize Regan. See what breeds about her heart. Is there any cause in nature that makes these hard hearts? (to EDGAR) You, sir, I entertain you for one of my hundred. Only I do not like the fashion of your garments. You will say they are Persian attire, but let them be changed.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Now let them dissect Regan and her hard heart. Is there any natural cause for hardening of the heart? (to EDGAR) Sir, you can serve me as one of my hundred knights. But I don’t like your style of clothes. I’m sure you’ll tell me they’re fabulous, but I think you should change them anyway.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Now, good my lord, lie here and rest awhile.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Please lie down and rest a while, my lord.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Make no noise, make no noise. Draw the curtains—so, so, so. We’ll go to supper i' th' morning. So, so, so.$NEWLINE$(sleeps)$NEWLINE$(sleeps)
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Be quiet, be quiet. Draw the curtains, just like that. We’ll have supper in the morning. That’s right.$NEWLINE$(he falls asleep)$NEWLINE$(he falls asleep)

paragraphs.original: FOOL$NEWLINE$And I’ll go to bed at noon.
paragraphs.translated: FOOL$NEWLINE$And I’ll go to bed at noon.

paragraphs.original: Enter GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER enters.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to KENT) Come hither, friend. Where is the king my master?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to KENT) Come here, my friend. Where’s my master the king?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Here, sir, but trouble him not. His wits are gone.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$He’s here, sir, but please don’t bother him. He’s out of his right mind.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Good friend, I prithee, take him in thy arms.$NEWLINE$I have o'erheard a plot of death upon him.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Please get him, my friend, I beg you. I’ve overheard people plotting to kill him. I have a carriage ready. Put

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: There is a litter ready. Lay him in ’t$NEWLINE$And drive towards Dover, friend, where thou shalt meet$NEWLINE$Both welcome and protection. Take up thy master.$NEWLINE$If thou shouldst dally half an hour, his life,$NEWLINE$With thine and all that offer to defend him,$NEWLINE$Stand in assurèd loss. Take up, take up,$NEWLINE$And follow me, that will to some provision$NEWLINE$Give thee quick conduct.
paragraphs.translated: him inside and take him to Dover, where you’ll find people who’ll welcome and protect him. Carry your master out. If you waste even half an hour, he’ll be killed, along with you and everyone else helping him. Bring him here, carry him and follow me. I’ll quickly take you to where you can find supplies.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Oppressèd nature sleeps.—$NEWLINE$This rest might yet have balmed thy broken sinews,$NEWLINE$Which, if convenience will not allow,$NEWLINE$Stand in hard cure.$NEWLINE$(to FOOL)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Come, help to bear thy master.$NEWLINE$Thou must not stay behind.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Lear’s suffering has finally put him to sleep. (to the sleeping LEAR) This rest might have calmed your shattered nerves. It will be difficult for you to get better now that rest is impossible. (to FOOL) Come on, help me carry your master. You can’t stay here.$NEWLINE$(to the sleeping$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Come, come, away.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Come on, come on.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but EDGAR$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except EDGAR.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$When we our betters see bearing our woes,$NEWLINE$We scarcely think our miseries our foes.$NEWLINE$Who alone suffers, suffers most i' th' mind,$NEWLINE$Leaving free things and happy shows behind.$NEWLINE$But then the mind much sufferance doth o'erskip$NEWLINE$When grief hath mates and bearing fellowship.$NEWLINE$How light and portable my pain seems now$NEWLINE$When that which makes me bend makes the king bow.$NEWLINE$He childed as I fathered. Tom, away!$NEWLINE$Mark the high noises and thyself bewray$NEWLINE$When false opinion, whose wrong thought defiles thee,$NEWLINE$In thy just proof repeals and reconciles thee.$NEWLINE$What will hap more tonight, safe ’scape the king!$NEWLINE$Lurk, lurk.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$When we see that our betters have the same problems we do, we can almost forget our own misery. The person who suffers alone suffers the most. Companions in sorrow alleviate our grief. My troubles seem so easy to bear now that I see the king collapsing under a similar sorrow. His children have done the same to him as my father has to me. Let’s go, Tom. We’ll pay attention to the political situation, and you’ll be able to reveal your true identity when you’re proven innocent. Whatever else happens tonight, I hope the king escapes safely! Lurk out of sight.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CORNWALL, and REGAN, and GONERIL, and EDMUND the bastard, and servants$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$EDMUND
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL enters with REGAN, GONERIL, EDMUND, and servants.$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$EDMUND

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL) Post speedily to my lord your husband. Show him this letter. The army of France is landed. —Seek out the traitor Gloucester.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL) Hurry to your husband. Show him this letter. The French army has landed.—Find the traitor Gloucester.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt some servants
paragraphs.translated: Some servants exit.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Hang him instantly.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Hang him immediately.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Pluck out his eyes.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Gouge out his eyes!

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Leave him to my displeasure.—Edmund, keep you our sister company. The revenges we are bound to take upon your traitorous father are not fit for your beholding. Advise the duke where you are going, to a most festinate preparation. We are bound to the like. Our posts shall be swift and intelligent betwixt us.—Farewell, dear sister. (to EDMUND) Farewell, my lord of Gloucester.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Leave him to my wrath.—Edmund, go with my sister-in-law. You shouldn’t have to see the punishment we inflict on your father. Tell the Duke of Albany to prepare for war immediately. We will do the same. We’ll keep the lines of communication open between us. (to GONERIL) Goodbye, my dear sister-in-law. (to EDMUND) Goodbye, lord Gloucester.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Enter OSWALD the steward$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD enters.$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: How now? Where’s the king?
paragraphs.translated: Hello. Where’s the king?

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$My lord of Gloucester hath conveyed him hence.$NEWLINE$Some five or six and thirty of his knights,$NEWLINE$Hot questrists after him, met him at gate,$NEWLINE$Who with some other of the lord’s dependants$NEWLINE$Are gone with him towards Dover, where they boast$NEWLINE$To have well-armèd friends.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Lord Gloucester has helped him leave. Thirty-five or thirty-six of his knights met him at the gate, and together with some others they’ve set off for Dover, where they claim to have powerful friends.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Get horses for your mistress.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Prepare the horses for your lady.

paragraphs.original: Exit OSWALD$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD exits.$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Farewell, sweet lord, and sister.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Goodbye, my sweet lord.—Goodbye, my sister.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Edmund, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Goodbye, Edmund.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt GONERIL and EDMUND the bastard$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$EDMUND
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL and EDMUND exit.$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$EDMUND

paragraphs.original: Go seek the traitor Gloucester.$NEWLINE$Pinion him like a thief, bring him before us.
paragraphs.translated: Go find the traitor Gloucester. Tie him up like a thief and bring him here to me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt some servants
paragraphs.translated: Some servants exit.

paragraphs.original: Though well we may not pass upon his life$NEWLINE$Without the form of justice, yet our power$NEWLINE$Shall do a courtesy to our wrath, which men$NEWLINE$May blame, but not control.—Who’s there? The traitor?
paragraphs.translated: I can’t condemn him to death without a formal trial, but I’m powerful enough that I can still do something to express my anger. Some men may blame me for doing this, but they won’t be able to do anything about it.—Who’s there? Is that the traitor?$NEWLINE$something

paragraphs.original: Enter GLOUCESTER, brought in by two or three servants$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: Two or three servants bring in GLOUCESTER.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Ingrateful fox, ’tis he.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Ungrateful traitor! That’s him.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Bind fast his corky arms.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Tie up his withered old arms.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$What mean your graces? Good my friends, consider$NEWLINE$You are my guests. Do me no foul play, friends.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$What are you doing? My friends, remember that you’re my guests here. Don’t play any nasty tricks on me.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Bind him, I say.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Tie him up, I tell you.

paragraphs.original: Servants bind GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: Servants tie up GLOUCESTER.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Hard, hard.—O filthy traitor!
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Tie him up harder.—You filthy traitor!

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Unmerciful lady as you are, I’m none.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I’m not a traitor, unfair lady.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$To this chair bind him.—Villain, thou shalt find—
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Tie him to this chair.—You’ll see, criminal—

paragraphs.original: REGAN plucks GLOUCESTER’s beard$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: REGAN pulls GLOUCESTER’s beard.$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$By the kind gods, ’tis most ignobly done$NEWLINE$To pluck me by the beard.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$By the gods, it’s disgraceful for you to pull my beard.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$So white, and such a traitor?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$As old and white-haired as you are, and you’re such a traitor?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Naughty lady,$NEWLINE$These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin$NEWLINE$Will quicken and accuse thee. I am your host.$NEWLINE$With robbers' hands my hospitable favors$NEWLINE$You should not ruffle thus. What will you do?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Wicked woman, these white hairs you’re pulling off my chin will come to life and accuse you of wrong-doing. You are my guests. This is no way to treat a host who has welcomed you into his house. What do you think you’re doing?

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Come, sir, what letters had you late from France?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Tell us about the letters that you got from France.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Be simple-answered, for we know the truth.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Get to the point, since we already know the truth.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$And what confederacy have you with the traitors$NEWLINE$Late footed in the kingdom?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$And what’s your connection with the traitors who landed in our kingdom recently?

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$To whose hands$NEWLINE$You have sent the lunatic king. Speak.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$The ones you’ve sent our lunatic king to. Tell us.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I have a letter guessingly set down,$NEWLINE$Which came from one that’s of a neutral heart,$NEWLINE$And not from one opposed.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I got a letter that made some guesses about what was going on, without any proof. It came from a neutral party, not from someone opposed to you.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Cunning.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$How clever of you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$And false.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Clever lies.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Where hast thou sent the king?
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Where have you sent the king?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$To Dover.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$To Dover.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Wherefore to Dover? Wast thou not charged at peril—
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Why Dover? Weren’t you ordered, on penalty of—

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Wherefore to Dover?—Let him first answer that.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Why Dover?—Let him answer that question first.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I am tied to th' stake, and I must stand the course.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I’m backed into a corner with nowhere to run.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Wherefore to Dover, sir?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Why Dover?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Because I would not see thy cruèl nails$NEWLINE$Pluck out his poor old eyes, nor thy fierce sister$NEWLINE$In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs.$NEWLINE$The sea, with such a storm as his bare head$NEWLINE$In hell-black night endured, would have buoyed up,$NEWLINE$And quenched the stellèd fires.$NEWLINE$Yet poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain.$NEWLINE$If wolves had at thy gate howled that stern time,$NEWLINE$Thou shouldst have said, “Good porter, turn the key,”$NEWLINE$All cruèls else subscribed. But I shall see$NEWLINE$The wingèd vengeance overtake such children.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Because I didn’t want to watch while you gouged out his poor old eyes with your cruel fingernails, or while your vicious sister sank her fangs into his sacred flesh. You left him out in the storm in the black night, bareheaded, a storm so terrible that if it had happened at sea, the waters would have risen up and extinguished the fire burning in the stars. And the poor old man just wept, mixing his tears with the rain. If wolves had been howling outside your gate at the heart of that storm, you would’ve told your doorman to let them in, despite all the cruelties you inflict on the world. But soon I’ll see the gods punish you for your lack of respect to your father.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$“See” ’t shalt thou never.—Fellows, hold the chair.—$NEWLINE$Upon these eyes of thine I’ll set my foot.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$You won’t be seeing anything.—Hold his chair still, men.—I’m going to put my foot on his eyes.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He that will think to live till he be old,$NEWLINE$Give me some help!
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Oh, help me, anyone who wants to live long!

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL plucks out one of GLOUCESTER’s eyes and stamps on it$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL gouges out one of GLOUCESTER’s eyes and steps on it.$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O cruel! O you gods!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, so cruel! Oh dear gods!

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$One side will mock another—th' other too.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Now he’s a little crooked. Gouge out the other eye too.

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$If you see vengeance—
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$If you see vengeance—

paragraphs.original: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$Hold your hand, my lord!$NEWLINE$I have served you ever since I was a child.$NEWLINE$But better service have I never done you$NEWLINE$Than now to bid you hold.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$Stop, my lord! I’ve served you since childhood, but I’ve never done you a better service than telling you to stop.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$How now, you dog?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$What’s this, you dog?

paragraphs.original: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$If you did wear a beard upon your chin,$NEWLINE$I’d shake it on this quarrel. What do you mean?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$I am willing to fight you if I must. What do you mean by all this?

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$My villein!
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$My peasant, acting like this?

paragraphs.original: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$Nay then, come on, and take the chance of anger.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$Come on then. Over my dead body.

paragraphs.original: FIRST SERVANT and CORNWALL draw and fight CORNWALL is wounded$NEWLINE$FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$CORNWALL
paragraphs.translated: The FIRST SERVANT and CORNWALL draw swords and fight. CORNWALL is wounded.$NEWLINE$FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$CORNWALL

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$(to another servant)$NEWLINE$(to another servant)$NEWLINE$Give me thy sword.—A peasant stand up thus?$NEWLINE$(takes a sword, runs at FIRST SERVANT behind, and kills him)$NEWLINE$(takes a sword, runs at$NEWLINE$behind, and kills him)
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$(to another servant) Give me your sword.—A lowly peasant defying his lord like this?$NEWLINE$(to another servant)$NEWLINE$She takes a sword and stabs the FIRST SERVANT from behind, killing him.$NEWLINE$She takes a sword and stabs the$NEWLINE$from behind, killing him.

paragraphs.original: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$Oh, I am slain!—My lord, you have one eye left$NEWLINE$To see some mischief on him. Oh!$NEWLINE$(dies)$NEWLINE$(dies)
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$I am dying!—My lord, you still have one eye left to see Cornwall punished. Oh!(he dies)$NEWLINE$(he dies)

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$Lest it see more, prevent it.—Out, vile jelly!
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$We’ll just have to stop him from seeing ever again. Out, vile jelly, pop out of your eye sockets!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: (plucks out GLOUCESTER’s other eye)$NEWLINE$(plucks out$NEWLINE$’s other eye)$NEWLINE$Where is thy luster now?
paragraphs.translated: (he gouges out GLOUCESTER’s other eye)$NEWLINE$(he gouges out$NEWLINE$’s other eye)$NEWLINE$Where’s your sparkle now?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$All dark and comfortless. Where’s my son Edmund?$NEWLINE$Edmund, enkindle all the sparks of nature$NEWLINE$To quit this horrid act.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Nothing but darkness and horror. Where’s my son Edmund? Edmund, let your love for me ignite your bloodlust to avenge this horrible crime!

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Out, treacherous villain!$NEWLINE$Thou call’st on him that hates thee. It was he$NEWLINE$That made the overture of thy treasons to us,$NEWLINE$Who is too good to pity thee.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Wrong, evil traitor. You’re appealing to a son who hates you. He was the one who revealed your treason to us. He’s too good to have any compassion for you.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$O my follies! Then Edgar was abused.$NEWLINE$Kind gods, forgive me that, and prosper him!
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$What a fool I’ve been! This means I’ve mistreated Edgar. Dear God, forgive me. Let him be well!

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smell$NEWLINE$His way to Dover.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Kick him out of the gate. He can sniff his way to Dover.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt some servants with GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: Some servants exit with GLOUCESTER.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: (to CORNWALL) How is ’t, my lord? How look you?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: (to CORNWALL) What is it, my lord? Why do you look like that?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$I have received a hurt. Follow me, lady.—$NEWLINE$Turn out that eyeless villain. Throw this slave$NEWLINE$Upon the dunghill.—Regan, I bleed apace.$NEWLINE$Untimely comes this hurt. Give me your arm.
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL$NEWLINE$I’m wounded. Follow me, madam.—Throw the blind traitor outside. And throw this dead peasant into the manure pit.—Regan, I’m bleeding. It’s a bad time for such an injury. Give me your arm.

paragraphs.original: Exit CORNWALL with REGAN$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$REGAN
paragraphs.translated: CORNWALL and REGAN exit.$NEWLINE$CORNWALL$NEWLINE$REGAN

paragraphs.original: SECOND SERVANT$NEWLINE$I’ll never care what wickedness I do,$NEWLINE$If this man come to good.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SERVANT$NEWLINE$If our criminal master gets off free, I won’t care what happens to me anymore.

paragraphs.original: THIRD SERVANT$NEWLINE$If she live long,$NEWLINE$And in the end meet the old course of death,$NEWLINE$Women will all turn monsters.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD SERVANT$NEWLINE$If she lives a long and happy life, then all women may as well turn into monsters.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SECOND SERVANT$NEWLINE$Let’s follow the old earl, and get the Bedlam$NEWLINE$To lead him where he would. His roguish madness$NEWLINE$Allows itself to any thing.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SERVANT$NEWLINE$Let’s follow the old earl, and get that crazy Tom to take him wherever he wants to go. As a wandering lunatic, he can do whatever he wants.

paragraphs.original: THIRD SERVANT$NEWLINE$Go thou. I’ll fetch some flax and whites of eggs$NEWLINE$To apply to his bleeding face. Now heaven help him!
paragraphs.translated: THIRD SERVANT$NEWLINE$Go ahead. I’ll get some cloth and egg whites to bandage his bleeding face. Heaven help him!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit in different directions.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter EDGAR diguised$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR enters in disguise.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Yet better thus, and known to be contemned,$NEWLINE$Than still contemned and flattered. To be worst,$NEWLINE$The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune$NEWLINE$Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear.$NEWLINE$The lamentable change is from the best;$NEWLINE$The worst returns to laughter. Welcome, then,$NEWLINE$Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace!$NEWLINE$The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst$NEWLINE$Owes nothing to thy blasts.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Still, I’m better off now, as a beggar who is openly hated, than when I was flattered to my face hated in secret. The lowliest and most dejected creatures live without fear and still harbor hope. The worst kind of change is when good fortune turns sour. At the bottom, any change is for the better. So I welcome this wind freely. I’ve sunk as far down as I can go, so I’ve got nothing more to fear from the weather.

paragraphs.original: Enter GLOUCESTER led by an OLD MAN$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$OLD MAN
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER enters, led by an OLD MAN.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$OLD MAN

paragraphs.original: But who comes here?$NEWLINE$My father, poorly led? World, world, O world!$NEWLINE$But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee,$NEWLINE$Life would not yield to age.
paragraphs.translated: But who is this? My father, led by a poor peasant? Oh, life is full of surprises! We age and die because they wear us out.

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$(to GLOUCESTER)    O my good lord,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I have been your tenant and your father’s tenant these fourscore years.
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$(to GLOUCESTER) My good lord,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I’ve rented land from you and your father for eighty years.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Away, get thee away. Good friend, be gone.$NEWLINE$Thy comforts can do me no good at all.$NEWLINE$Thee they may hurt.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Away, get out of here. Leave me, my friend. There’s nothing you can do to help me now, and being with me puts your life in danger.

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$Alack, sir, you cannot see your way.
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$But you can’t see where you’re going, sir.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I have no way, and therefore want no eyes.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I don’t have anywhere to go, so I don’t need to see. When I could see, I didn’t always see clearly. I made

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I stumbled when I saw. Full oft ’tis seen,$NEWLINE$Our means secure us and our mere defects$NEWLINE$Prove our commodities. O dear son Edgar,$NEWLINE$The food of thy abusèd father’s wrath,$NEWLINE$Might I but live to see thee in my touch,$NEWLINE$I’d say I had eyes again!
paragraphs.translated: mistakes, I stumbled and fell. It’s often the case that having something makes us spoiled, while not having it turns out to be advantageous. So may it be with my eyesight. Oh, my dear son Edgar,$NEWLINE$how enraged I was at you when I was deceived. If I live long enough to touch you again, that would be as good as having my eyesight back.

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$How now? Who’s there?
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$Who’s that? Who’s there?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(aside) O gods! Who is ’t can say “I am at the worst”?$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$I am worse than e'er I was.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to himself) Oh, gods! Who can ever say, “This is as bad as it can get”? I’m worse off now than ever before.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$(to GLOUCESTER)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$'Tis poor mad Tom.
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$(to GLOUCESTER) It’s poor crazy Tom.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(aside) And worse I may be yet. The worst is not$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$So long as we can say “This is the worst.”
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to himself) And my life could still be worse. If you have the presence of mind to say, “This is the worst,” then it’s not the worst yet.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$(to EDGAR) Fellow, where goest?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$(to EDGAR) Where are you going, man?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Is it a beggarman?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Is it a beggar?

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$Madman and beggar too.
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$Yes, he’s both crazy and a beggar.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He has some reason, else he could not beg.$NEWLINE$I' th' last night’s storm I such a fellow saw,$NEWLINE$Which made me think a man a worm. My son$NEWLINE$Came then into my mind, and yet my mind$NEWLINE$Was then scarce friends with him. I have heard more since.$NEWLINE$As flies to wanton boys are we to th' gods.$NEWLINE$They kill us for their sport.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Well, he can’t be completely crazy, or he wouldn’t be able to beg. Last night during the storm I saw a man who was both poor and crazy. He made me think that men are as weak and insignificant as worms. I was reminded of my son, even though I despised my son at that time. Now I know better. The gods play around with us as cruelly as schoolboys who pull the wings off flies.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$How should this be?$NEWLINE$Bad is the trade that must play fool to sorrow,$NEWLINE$Angering itself and others.—Bless thee, master!
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to himself) What’s going on? I hate pretending I’m a wandering beggar when all I want to do now is comfort my poor father.—Bless you, master.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Is that the naked fellow?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Is that the naked guy?

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Then prithee, get thee gone. If for my sake$NEWLINE$Thou wilt o'ertake us hence a mile or twain$NEWLINE$I' th' way toward Dover, do it for ancient love.$NEWLINE$And bring some covering for this naked soul,$NEWLINE$Which I’ll entreat to lead me.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(to the OLD MAN) Then please go. If you’re willing to do me a favor, as an old friend, then catch up to us a mile or two further on the way to Dover, and bring some clothes for this poor beggar. I’ll ask him to be my guide.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$Alack, sir, he is mad.
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$But sir, he’s crazy.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$'Tis the time’s plague when madmen lead the blind.$NEWLINE$Do as I bid thee. Or rather, do thy pleasure.$NEWLINE$Above the rest, be gone.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$It’s the tragedy of our times that lunatics must lead the blind. Do as I asked you. Or rather, do what you feel like doing. But above all, get out of here.

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$I’ll bring him the best 'parel that I have,$NEWLINE$Come on ’t what will.
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$I’ll bring the crazy beggar the best clothes I have, no matter what happens.

paragraphs.original: Exit OLD MAN$NEWLINE$OLD MAN
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Sirrah, naked fellow—
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Hey, naked guy—

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Poor Tom’s a-cold.$NEWLINE$(aside) I cannot daub it further.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Poor Tom’s chilly. (to himself) I can’t play this role any longer.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Come hither, fellow.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Come here, man.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(aside) And yet I must.—Bless thy sweet eyes, they bleed.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to himself) But I must.—Bless you, sir. Your dear eyes are bleeding.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Know’st thou the way to Dover?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Do you know the way to Dover?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Both stile and gate, horseway and footpath. Poor Tom hath been scared out of his good wits. Bless thee, goodman’s son, from the foul fiend! Five fiends have been in poor Tom at once: of lust, as Obidicut; Hobbididence, prince of dumbness; Mahu, of stealing; Modo, of murder; Flibbertigibbet, of mopping and mowing, who since possesses chambermaids and waiting-women. So bless thee, master.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I know it like the back of my hand, every step of the way. Poor Tom has been scared out of his mind. Bless you, good man, and stay away from the devil. Five devils haunted Poor Tom at the same time: Obidicut, the devil of lust; Hobbididence, the devil of mutes; Mahu, the devil of stealing; Modo, the devil of murder; and Flibbertigibbet, the devil of mockery, who causes chambermaids to make silly faces. Bless you, master.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(giving EDGAR a purse)$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$a purse)$NEWLINE$Here, take this purse, thou whom the heavens' plagues$NEWLINE$Have humbled to all strokes. That I am wretched$NEWLINE$Makes thee the happier. Heavens, deal so still.$NEWLINE$Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man,$NEWLINE$That slaves your ordinance, that will not see$NEWLINE$Because he doth not feel, feel your power quickly.$NEWLINE$So distribution should undo excess,$NEWLINE$And each man have enough. Dost thou know Dover?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$(giving EDGAR a purse) Here, take some money. The torments of heaven have brought you down to this humble state. My misery makes you more fortunate in comparison. It should always work like that. The spoiled man who has everything, who can’t see the misery around him because he doesn’t feel it himself, should be made to feel agony so he can learn to share his wealth. That way wealth would be redistributed until everyone has enough to survive. Are you familiar with Dover?$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$a purse)

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Ay, master.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Yes, sir.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$There is a cliff, whose high and bending head$NEWLINE$Looks fearfully in the confinèd deep.$NEWLINE$Bring me but to the very brim of it,$NEWLINE$And I’ll repair the misery thou dost bear$NEWLINE$With something rich about me. From that place$NEWLINE$I shall no leading need.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$There’s a cliff there that leans precariously over the deep sea. Take me to the edge of it, and I’ll reward all your troubles with something valuable. Once I’m there, I won’t need a guide anymore.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Give me thy arm.$NEWLINE$Poor Tom shall lead thee.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Give me your arm. Poor Tom will take you there.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter GONERIL and EDMUND the bastard$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$EDMUND
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL enters with EDMUND.$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$EDMUND

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Welcome, my lord. I marvel our mild husband$NEWLINE$Not met us on the way.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Welcome, my lord. I’m surprised my bland husband didn’t meet me on the way here.

paragraphs.original: Enter OSWALD$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD enters.$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: Now, where’s your master?
paragraphs.translated: Where’s your master?

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Madam, within—but never man so changed.$NEWLINE$I told him of the army that was landed.$NEWLINE$He smiled at it. I told him you were coming.$NEWLINE$His answer was “The worse.” Of Gloucester’s treachery$NEWLINE$And of the loyal service of his son,$NEWLINE$When I informed him, then he called me “sot,”$NEWLINE$And told me I had turned the wrong side out.$NEWLINE$What most he should dislike seems pleasant to him;$NEWLINE$What like, offensive.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$He’s inside, ma'am, but he has changed dramatically since you last saw him. When I told him that the invading army has landed, he just smiled at me. When I told him you were on your way, he replied, “Too bad.” When I told him about Gloucester’s betrayal and his son Edmund’s loyal service, he called me an idiot and said I had it all wrong. He was delighted by the bad news and disgusted by the good news.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Then shall you go no further.$NEWLINE$It is the cowish terror of his spirit$NEWLINE$That dares not undertake. He’ll not feel wrongs$NEWLINE$Which tie him to an answer. Our wishes on the way$NEWLINE$May prove effects. Back, Edmund, to my brother.$NEWLINE$Hasten his musters and conduct his powers.$NEWLINE$I must change names at home, and give the distaff$NEWLINE$Into my husband’s hands. This trusty servant$NEWLINE$Shall pass between us. Ere long you are like to hear—$NEWLINE$If you dare venture in your own behalf—$NEWLINE$A mistress’s command. Wear this. Spare speech.$NEWLINE$Decline your head. This kiss, if it durst speak,$NEWLINE$Would stretch thy spirits up into the air.$NEWLINE$(kisses EDMUND) Conceive, and fare thee well.$NEWLINE$(kisses$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated:
GONERIL$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND) Then don’t come in with me. He’s a coward and can’t commit himself to doing anything risky. He chooses not to be insulted rather than challenge those who offend him. But what we talked about with longing on the way may soon come true.
Edmund, go back to see my brother-in-law. Gather his soldiers and organize his troops. I plan to take charge of my household. From now on I will wear the pants, and my husband can play the housewife. We can trust Oswald to carry messages between us. If you act boldly, you will soon obey me as your true mistress. Take this as a token of my esteem. Don’t speak. Lean down. This kiss should encourage you. (she kisses
EDMUND ) I hope you understand me. Goodbye, and good luck.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Edmund$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(she kisses$NEWLINE$EDMUND$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Yours in the ranks of death.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’m at your service until death.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$My most dear Gloucester!
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$My dear Gloucester!

paragraphs.original: Exit EDMUND$NEWLINE$EDMUND
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND exits.$NEWLINE$EDMUND

paragraphs.original: Oh, the difference of man and man!$NEWLINE$To thee a woman’s services are due.$NEWLINE$My fool usurps my body.
paragraphs.translated: What a man!—especially compared to my husband. Edmund, you deserve me to be your woman. There’s a fool sharing my bed now.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Madam, here comes my lord.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Ma'am, my master’s coming.

paragraphs.original: Exit OSWALD$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter ALBANY$NEWLINE$ALBANY
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY enters.$NEWLINE$ALBANY

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$I have been worth the whistle.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$So you finally find me worthy of your attentions.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$O Goneril,$NEWLINE$You are not worth the dust which the rude wind$NEWLINE$Blows in your face. I fear your disposition.$NEWLINE$That nature, which contemns its origin$NEWLINE$Cannot be bordered certain in itself.$NEWLINE$She that herself will sliver and disbranch$NEWLINE$From her material sap perforce must wither$NEWLINE$And come to deadly use.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Goneril, you aren’t worth the dust the wind blows in your face. I don’t trust you. You can’t trust anyone who abuses her own father, her flesh and blood. A woman who breaks off relations with her bloodline is like a branch that tries to break away from the tree. She will wither and come to a bad end.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$No more. The text is foolish.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Oh, shut up. Your words are idiotic.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile.$NEWLINE$Filths savor but themselves. What have you done?$NEWLINE$Tigers, not daughters, what have you performed?$NEWLINE$A father, and a gracious agèd man,$NEWLINE$Whose reverence even the head-lugged bear would lick,$NEWLINE$Most barbarous, most degenerate, have you madded.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Bad people can’t appreciate wisdom or goodness. They only like things as bad as themselves. What have you two sisters done? You’re tigers, not daughters. Barbaric degenerates, you’ve driven insane a kindly old father, whom even an angry bear would treat gent-ly. Could my good brother-in-law—a man to whom the

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Could my good brother suffer you to do it—$NEWLINE$A man, a prince by him so benefited?$NEWLINE$If that the heavens do not their visible spirits$NEWLINE$Send quickly down to tame these vile offenses,$NEWLINE$It will come:$NEWLINE$Humanity must perforce prey on itself$NEWLINE$Like monsters of the deep.
paragraphs.translated: king gave half his kingdom—have allowed you to do it? If the heavens don’t punish these crimes immediately, the end will come. Human beings will become cannibals, like ravenous sea fishes.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Milk-livered man$NEWLINE$That bear’st a cheek for blows, a head for wrongs—$NEWLINE$Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning$NEWLINE$Thine honor from thy suffering; that not know’st$NEWLINE$Fools do those villains pity who are punished$NEWLINE$Ere they have done their mischief. Where’s thy drum?$NEWLINE$France spreads his banners in our noiseless land,$NEWLINE$With plumèd helm thy state begins to threat,$NEWLINE$Whiles thou, a moral fool, sits still and cries,$NEWLINE$“Alack, why does he so?”
paragraphs.translated:
GONERIL$NEWLINE$Coward! You take everything lying down, you just turn the other cheek—you can’t even see the difference between being honored and being taken advantage of! If we punish
criminals before they have a chance to commit their crimes, you’re a fool to pity them. Why aren’t you preparing for war? The French have invaded our peaceful country. Your territory is at risk, and all you can do is sit around like a preachy fool and whine, “Ah, why is he doing that?”$NEWLINE$criminals$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$See thyself, devil!$NEWLINE$Proper deformity shows not in the fiend$NEWLINE$So horrid as in woman.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Look at yourself, devilish shrew! A woman deformed by hatred and rage is more horrifying than the devil!—at least the devil is supposed to look that way.$NEWLINE$supposed

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$O vain fool!
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$You useless fool!

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Thou changèd and self-covered thing, for shame!$NEWLINE$Bemonster not thy feature. Were ’t my fitness$NEWLINE$To let these hands obey my blood,$NEWLINE$They are apt enough to dislocate and tear$NEWLINE$Thy flesh and bones. Howe'er thou art a fiend,$NEWLINE$A woman’s shape doth shield thee.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Shame on you, warped hag! Your true demonic features are distorting your body. If I let myself do what I yearn to, I’d rip the flesh off your bones. But I won’t attack a woman, even if she is a demon.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Marry, your manhood, mew!
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$I sneeze on your manhood. Ha!

paragraphs.original: Enter FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$FIRST MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The FIRST MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$FIRST MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$What news?
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$What news do you bring?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$O my good lord, the Duke of Cornwall’s dead,$NEWLINE$Slain by his servant, going to put out$NEWLINE$The other eye of Gloucester.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Oh my lord, the Duke of Cornwall’s dead. He was killed by his servant as he about to gouge out Glouces-ter’s other eye.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Gloucester’s eyes?
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Gloucester’s eyes?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$A servant that he bred, thrilled with remorse,$NEWLINE$Opposed against the act, bending his sword$NEWLINE$To his great master; who thereat enraged$NEWLINE$Flew on him and amongst them felled him dead—$NEWLINE$But not without that harmful stroke, which since$NEWLINE$Hath plucked him after.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$A servant Gloucester had raised in his house, full of compunction, opposed the blinding and turned his sword on the Duke of Cornwall. Enraged, Cornwall attacked and killed the servant, but not without receiving his own wound, of which he later died.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$This shows you are above,$NEWLINE$You justicers, that these our nether crimes$NEWLINE$So speedily can venge! But oh, poor Gloucester—$NEWLINE$Lost he his other eye?
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$There’s justice in heaven after all! That these crimes are punished so quickly is proof. But oh, poor Glou-cester! Did he lose his other eye?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Both, both, my lord.—$NEWLINE$This letter, madam, craves a speedy answer.$NEWLINE$'Tis from your sister.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He lost both, my lord.—Ma'am, this letter is from your sister, and needs an immediate answer.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$One way I like this well.$NEWLINE$But being widow, and my Gloucester with her,$NEWLINE$May all the building in my fancy pluck$NEWLINE$Upon my hateful life. Another way$NEWLINE$The news is not so tart.—I’ll read and answer.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(to herself) In a way I’m glad to hear that Cornwall is dead. But on the other hand, Edmund is traveling with Regan, who is now a widow. If something happens between them on the road, it would shatter my hopes of having Edmund for myself and escaping this hateful life. Still, there are benefits to having Cornwall out of the way.—I’ll read this letter and answer it.$NEWLINE$(to herself)

paragraphs.original: Exit GONERIL$NEWLINE$GONERIL
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Where was his son when they did take his eyes?
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Where was Gloucester’s son Edmund when they gouged his eyes out?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Come with my lady hither.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He was on his way here with your wife.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$He is not here.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$But he isn’t here now.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$No, my good lord. I met him back again.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$No, my lord. I met him going back again.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Knows he the wickedness?
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Does he know about this wicked crime?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Ay, my good lord. 'Twas he informed against him,$NEWLINE$And quit the house on purpose that their punishment$NEWLINE$Might have the freer course.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord. He was the one who denounced his father. He then left the house specifically so that the punishment might be carried out without concern for their father-son bond.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Gloucester, I live$NEWLINE$To thank thee for the love thou showed’st the king,$NEWLINE$And to revenge thine eyes.—Come hither, friend.$NEWLINE$Tell me what more thou know’st.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Gloucester, I’ll thank you forever for the love you’ve shown the king. I’ll get revenge for what they did to your eyes.—Come here, my friend. What else you do know?

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter KENT disguised and GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated: KENT enters in disguise, along with the GENTLEMAN.$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Why the King of France is so suddenly gone back know you the reason?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Do you know why the King of France suddenly went back home?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Something he left imperfect in the state which, since his coming forth, is thought of; which imports to the kingdom so much fear and danger that his personal return was most required and necessary.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$He’d left some unfinished business, which he remembered after arriving here. It was urgent and important enough to require his personal presence.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Who hath he left behind him general?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Whom did he leave in charge here?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$The Marshal of France, Monsieur la Far.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$The marshal of France, Monsieur la Far.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Did your letters pierce the queen to any demonstration of grief?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Was Queen Cordelia aggrieved by the letters you delivered?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Ay, sir. She took them, read them in my presence,$NEWLINE$And now and then an ample tear trilled down$NEWLINE$Her delicate cheek. It seemed she was a queen$NEWLINE$Over her passion, who, most rebel-like,$NEWLINE$Sought to be king o'er her.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Yes, sir. She took the letters and read them in front of me. Now and then a large tear trickled down her delicate cheek. She seemed to be trying to control her emotions, which were overwhelming her.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$O, then it moved her?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$So she was moved by it?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Not to a rage. Patience and sorrow strove$NEWLINE$Who should express her goodliest. You have seen$NEWLINE$Sunshine and rain at once—her smiles and tears$NEWLINE$Were like a better way. Those happy smilets$NEWLINE$That played on her ripe lip seemed not to know$NEWLINE$What guests were in her eyes, which parted thence$NEWLINE$As pearls from diamonds dropped. In brief,$NEWLINE$Sorrow would be a rarity most beloved$NEWLINE$If all could so become it.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$There were no outbursts. She was struggling between emotion and self-control. You’ve seen how it can rain while the sun shines? That’s how she was, smiling and crying at once, only more lovely. The little smile on her full lips didn’t seem aware of the tears that were dropping like diamonds from her pearly eyes. If everyone looked so lovely in their sorrow, then sorrow would be highly prized.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Made she no verbal question?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$She didn’t ask anything?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Faith, once or twice she heaved the name of “father”$NEWLINE$Pantingly forth as if it pressed her heart,$NEWLINE$Cried, “Sisters, sisters! Shame of ladies, sisters!$NEWLINE$Kent, father, sisters! What, i' th' storm, i' th' night?$NEWLINE$Let pity not be believed.” There she shook$NEWLINE$The holy water from her heavenly eyes,$NEWLINE$And clamor moistened. Then away she started$NEWLINE$To deal with grief alone.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Actually, once or twice she sighed and said, “father,” as if the word were pressing on her chest. Once she exclaimed, “Sisters, sisters, shame on you! Kent, father, sisters! What, out in a storm in the middle of the night? I can’t believe it.” The tears fell from her eyes like holy water. Then she ran away to grieve alone.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$It is the stars,$NEWLINE$The stars above us, govern our conditions.$NEWLINE$Else one self mate and mate could not beget$NEWLINE$Such different issues. You spoke not with her since?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$It must be fate that makes us who we are—otherwise someone as good as Cordelia could not possibly be related to those two witches. Have you not spoken to her since then?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$No.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$No.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Was this before the king returned?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Did this happen before the King of France returned home?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$No, since.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$No, afterward.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Well, sir, the poor distressèd Lear’s i' th' town,$NEWLINE$Who sometime in his better tune remembers$NEWLINE$What we are come about, and by no means$NEWLINE$Will yield to see his daughter.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Well, sir, poor delirious Lear is in town. Sometimes when he’s lucid he remembers why we’re here, and absolutely refuses to see his daughter.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Why, good sir?
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Why, good sir?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$A sovereign shame so elbows him. His own unkindness$NEWLINE$That stripped her from his benediction turned her$NEWLINE$To foreign casualties, gave her dear rights$NEWLINE$To his dog-hearted daughters. These things sting$NEWLINE$His mind so venomously that burning shame$NEWLINE$Detains him from Cordelia.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$He’s too overwhelmed with shame. He remembers how unkind he was to her, how he disowned her and sent her abroad, how he gave her rightful inheritance to her two dog-hearted sisters. All those memories pain his mind so deeply that guilt and shame keep him away from Cordelia.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Alack, poor gentleman!
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Oh, the poor man!

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Of Albany’s and Cornwall’s powers you heard not?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Have you heard about Albany’s and Cornwall’s troops?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$'Tis so. They are afoot.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$I have. They’re on the march.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Well, sir, I’ll bring you to our master Lear$NEWLINE$And leave you to attend him. Some dear cause$NEWLINE$Will in concealment wrap me up awhile.$NEWLINE$When I am known aright you shall not grieve$NEWLINE$Lending me this acquaintance. I pray you, go$NEWLINE$Along with me.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Well, sir, I’ll take you to Lear and have you stay with him a while. I have important business that requires me to remain in disguise a while longer. When I’ve revealed my true identity, you’ll be glad you took the time to help me out. Please come with me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter, with drum and colors, CORDELIA, DOCTOR, and soldiers$NEWLINE$CORDELIA$NEWLINE$DOCTOR
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA enters with a DOCTOR and soldiers carrying drums and banners.$NEWLINE$CORDELIA$NEWLINE$DOCTOR

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Alack, ’tis he. Why, he was met even now$NEWLINE$As mad as the vexed sea, singing aloud,$NEWLINE$Crowned with rank fumiter and furrow-weeds,$NEWLINE$With burdocks, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo-flowers,$NEWLINE$Darnel, and all the idle weeds that grow$NEWLINE$In our sustaining corn.—A century send forth.$NEWLINE$Search every acre in the high-grown field,$NEWLINE$And bring him to our eye.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Sadly, it’s the king that’s missing. They saw him just now as mad and deranged as the stormy sea, singing loudly, wearing a crown of nettles, thorns, hemlock, and all the other weeds that grow in our cornfields.—Send out a hundred soldiers to find him. Search high and low, in every acre of the fields, and bring him here for me to see him.

paragraphs.original: Exit some soldiers
paragraphs.translated: Some soldiers exit.

paragraphs.original: What can man’s wisdom$NEWLINE$In the restoring his bereavèd sense?$NEWLINE$He that helps him take all my outward worth.
paragraphs.translated: What can human knowledge do to make him sane again? I’d give all my wealth to whoever can help him.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$There is means, madam.$NEWLINE$Our foster nurse of nature is repose,$NEWLINE$The which he lacks—that to provoke in him$NEWLINE$Are many simples operative, whose power$NEWLINE$Will close the eye of anguish.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$There is a way, ma'am. Nature heals people with rest, which Lear hasn’t had. But there are many herbs that will help him rest and take his mind off his anguish for a while.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$All blessed secrets,$NEWLINE$All you unpublished virtues of the earth,$NEWLINE$Spring with my tears. Be aidant and remediate$NEWLINE$In the good man’s distress. Seek, seek for him,$NEWLINE$Lest his ungoverned rage dissolve the life$NEWLINE$That wants the means to lead it.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Then I’ll water all those precious herbs with my tears to make them grow. May they relieve a sick old man’s suffering. Go find those herbs for him, before his madness puts his life in danger.

paragraphs.original: Enter SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$SECOND MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The SECOND MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$SECOND MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$News, madam.$NEWLINE$The British powers are marching hitherward.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I have news, ma'am. The British forces are on their way here.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$'Tis known before. Our preparation stands$NEWLINE$In expectation of them. O dear father,$NEWLINE$It is thy business that I go about.$NEWLINE$Therefore great France$NEWLINE$My mourning and importuned tears hath pitied.$NEWLINE$No blown ambition doth our arms incite,$NEWLINE$But love—dear love!—and our aged father’s right.$NEWLINE$Soon may I hear and see him.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$We already knew that. Our forces are ready for them. Oh, father, I’m taking care of your business. That’s why the King of France listened to my pleas and tears. We’re not invading England out of ambition or greed, but out of love—dear love!—and my father’s right to his kingdom. I hope I see him and hear him again soon.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter REGAN and the steward OSWALD$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: REGAN enters with OSWALD.$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$But are my brother’s powers set forth?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Have my brother-in-law’s troops been mobilized?

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Ay, madam.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Yes, ma'am.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Himself in person there?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Is he there in person?

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Madam, with much ado.$NEWLINE$Your sister is the better soldier.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Yes, making a big fuss. Your sister’s the better soldier of the two.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Lord Edmund spake not with your lord at home?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Lord Edmund didn’t speak to your master at home?

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$No, madam.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$No, ma'am.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$What might import my sister’s letter to him?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$What could my sister’s letter to him say?

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I know not, lady.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I don’t know, ma'am.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Faith, he is posted hence on serious matter.$NEWLINE$It was great ignorance, Gloucester’s eyes being out,$NEWLINE$To let him live. Where he arrives he moves$NEWLINE$All hearts against us. Edmund I think is gone$NEWLINE$In pity of his misery to dispatch$NEWLINE$His nighted life; moreover to descry$NEWLINE$The strength o' th' enemy.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$He rushed away on serious business. It was a huge mistake to let old Gloucester live after we blinded him. Wherever he goes, he inspires compassion and people turn against us. I think Edmund went off to kill him, to put him out of his blind misery. And also to find out the size of the enemy army.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I must needs after him, madam, with my letter.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I have to follow him and give him the letter.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Our troops set forth tomorrow. Stay with us.$NEWLINE$The ways are dangerous.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Our troops are deployed tomorrow. Stay with us tonight. It’s dangerous out there.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I may not, madam.$NEWLINE$My lady charged my duty in this business.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I can’t, ma'am. My lady ordered me to deliver her letter.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Why should she write to Edmund? Might not you$NEWLINE$Transport her purposes by word? Belike$NEWLINE$Some things—I know not what. I’ll love thee much.$NEWLINE$Let me unseal the letter.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Why would she write to Edmund? Couldn’t you just deliver the message orally? It probably has something to do with… I don’t know. I’ll be so grateful to you if you let me open that letter.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Madam, I had rather—
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Ma'am, I’d rather—

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$I know your lady does not love her husband.$NEWLINE$I am sure of that. And at her late being here$NEWLINE$She gave strange oeillades and most speaking looks$NEWLINE$To noble Edmund. I know you are of her bosom.
