paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$I know your lady Goneril doesn’t love her husband. I’m sure of that. And when she was here recently she flirted with Edmund and gave him significant glances. I know she trusts you and tells you everything.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$I, madam?
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Me, ma'am?

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$I speak in understanding. Y' are. I know ’t.$NEWLINE$Therefore I do advise you, take this note.$NEWLINE$My lord is dead. Edmund and I have talked,$NEWLINE$And more convenient is he for my hand$NEWLINE$Than for your lady’s. You may gather more.$NEWLINE$If you do find him, pray you give him this.$NEWLINE$And when your mistress hears thus much from you,$NEWLINE$I pray desire her call her wisdom to her.$NEWLINE$So fare you well.$NEWLINE$If you do chance to hear of that blind traitor,$NEWLINE$Preferment falls on him that cuts him off.
paragraphs.translated:
REGAN$NEWLINE$I know what I’m talking about. You’re close to her, I know it. So I recommend you take note of what I’m about to say. My husband is dead. Edmund and I have talked, and it makes more sense for him to marry me than Goneril. You can figure out the rest. If you find him, please
give him this. And when your mistress hears about all this, please tell her to use her head next time. So goodbye. If you happen to hear anything about that blind traitor Gloucester, I’ll reward anyone who snuffs him out.$NEWLINE$give$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Would I could meet him, madam, I should show$NEWLINE$What party I do follow.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$If I could run into him, ma'am, I’d prove which side I’m on.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Fare thee well.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit in opposite directions.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter GLOUCESTER, and EDGAR disguised in peasant clothing$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER enters with EDGAR, who is dressed as a peasant.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$When shall we come to th' top of that same hill?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$When will we get to the top of that cliff?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$You do climb up it now. Look how we labor.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$We’re walking up to the top right now. See how hard it is to climb?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Methinks the ground is even.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$The ground feels flat to me.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Horrible steep.$NEWLINE$Hark, do you hear the sea?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$No, it’s dreadfully steep. Listen. Do you hear the sea?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$No, truly.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$No, really, I don’t.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Why then, your other senses grow imperfect$NEWLINE$By your eyes' anguish.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Then your other senses must be getting worse because of the trauma of blindness.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$So may it be indeed.$NEWLINE$Methinks thy voice is altered, and thou speak’st$NEWLINE$In better phrase and matter than thou didst.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$It may be so. It seems to me that your voice has changed, and that your speech is more elegant than it used to be.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$You’re much deceived. In nothing am I changed$NEWLINE$But in my garments.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$You’re mistaken about all that. The only thing different about me is my clothes.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Methinks you’re better spoken.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I think you’re more articulate.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Come on, sir. Here’s the place. Stand still. How fearful$NEWLINE$And dizzy ’tis to cast one’s eyes so low!$NEWLINE$The crows and choughs that wing the midway air$NEWLINE$Show scarce so gross as beetles. Halfway down$NEWLINE$Hangs one that gathers samphire—dreadful trade!$NEWLINE$Methinks he seems no bigger than his head.$NEWLINE$The fishermen that walk upon the beach$NEWLINE$Appear like mice. And yon tall anchoring bark,
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Come on, sir. This is the place. Stand still. It’s so scary to look down! It makes me dizzy. The crows flying down below look as small as ants. Halfway down the cliff there’s somebody clinging to the rock and gathering wild herbs—a risky business! He looks like a dot to me. The fishermen walking along the beach are as small as mice. That big ship over there looks no bigger

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Diminished to her cock, her cock a buoy$NEWLINE$Almost too small for sight. The murmuring surge$NEWLINE$That on th' unnumbered idle pebbles chafes$NEWLINE$Cannot be heard so high. I’ll look no more$NEWLINE$Lest my brain turn and the deficient sight$NEWLINE$Topple down headlong.
paragraphs.translated: than its lifeboat, and its lifeboat looks as small as a tiny buoy. Up here you can’t even hear the waves crashing against the rocks. I have to stop looking, or my head will start spinning and I’ll fall.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Set me where you stand.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Lead me to where you’re standing.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Give me your hand. You are now within a foot$NEWLINE$Of th' extreme verge. For all beneath the moon$NEWLINE$Would I not leap upright.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Give me your hand. You’re now within a foot of the cliff’s edge. I wouldn’t try to jump up and down here for anything on earth.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Let go my hand.$NEWLINE$(gives EDGAR another purse)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$another purse)$NEWLINE$Here, friend, ’s another purse, in it a jewel$NEWLINE$Well worth a poor man’s taking. Fairies and gods$NEWLINE$Prosper it with thee! Go thou farther off.$NEWLINE$Bid me farewell, and let me hear thee going.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Let go of my hand. (he gives EDGAR another purse) Here’s another purse, my friend. Inside it there’s a jewel that any poor man would be happy to have. I hope it’s only the beginning of future prosperity for you. Now go further away. Say goodbye to me, and let me hear your footsteps as you walk away.$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$another purse)

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Now fare you well, good sir.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Goodbye, good sir.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$With all my heart.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$With all my heart.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR moves aside$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR moves aside.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(aside) Why I do trifle thus with his despair$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Is done to cure it.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to himself) I’m toying with his despair to cure him of it.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$O you mighty gods, (kneels)$NEWLINE$(kneels)$NEWLINE$This world I do renounce, and in your sights$NEWLINE$Shake patiently my great affliction off.$NEWLINE$If I could bear it longer and not fall$NEWLINE$To quarrel with your great opposeless wills,$NEWLINE$My snuff and loathèd part of nature should$NEWLINE$Burn itself out. If Edgar live, O, bless him!—$NEWLINE$Now, fellow, fare thee well. (falls)$NEWLINE$(falls)
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Oh, you mighty gods! (he kneels) I hereby renounce this world and all my troubles and torments. If I could bear them better, and not fight against your unstoppable decisions, then I would simply wait until I expired naturally. If Edgar’s alive, bless him, gods!—Now, man, goodbye. (he falls)$NEWLINE$(he kneels)$NEWLINE$(he falls)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Gone, sir. Farewell.$NEWLINE$(aside) And yet I know not how conceit may rob$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$The treasury of life when life itself$NEWLINE$Yields to the theft. Had he been where he thought,$NEWLINE$By this had thought been past. Alive or dead?—$NEWLINE$Ho you, sir, friend! Hear you, sir? Speak.—$NEWLINE$Thus might he pass indeed. Yet he revives.—$NEWLINE$What are you, sir?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Gone, sir. Goodbye. (to himself) But I still wonder if it’s possible for his own imagination to kill him, since he’s so willing to die. If he’d been standing on the edge of the cliff as he thought, he’d be dead right now. Is he alive or dead?—Hey, sir, friend! Can you hear me? Answer me.—Maybe he passed away after all. But no, he’s stirring.—Who are you, sir?$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Away, and let me die.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Go away and let me die.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Hadst thou been aught but gossamer, feathers, air,$NEWLINE$So many fathom down precipitating,$NEWLINE$Thou’dst shivered like an egg. But thou dost breathe,$NEWLINE$Hast heavy substance, bleed’st not, speak’st, art sound.$NEWLINE$Ten masts at each make not the altitude$NEWLINE$Which thou hast perpendicularly fell.$NEWLINE$Thy life’s a miracle. Speak yet again.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Even if you were made of feathers and air, you should’ve been smashed in pieces like an egg after falling as far as you just did. But your flesh is solid, your mind is strong, you’re breathing and talking, you’re not bleeding. You just fell the height of ten ship masts, straight down. It’s a miracle you’re alive. Say something again.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$But have I fall'n, or no?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$But did I fall or not?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$From the dread summit of this chalky bourn.$NEWLINE$Look up a-height. The shrill-gorged lark so far$NEWLINE$Cannot be seen or heard. Do but look up.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$You fell from the terrifying top of this chalk cliff. Look for yourself—see the top of the cliff way up there? The lark shrilly singing up there is too far away to be heard. Just look.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Alack, I have no eyes.$NEWLINE$Is wretchedness deprived that benefit,$NEWLINE$To end itself by death? 'Twas yet some comfort$NEWLINE$When misery could beguile the tyrant’s rage$NEWLINE$And frustrate his proud will.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I can’t. I have no eyes. If you’re wretched and desperate, aren’t you allowed to kill yourself? It used to be the last ditch comfort of miserable people.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Give me your arm.$NEWLINE$Up so. How is ’t? Feel you your legs? You stand.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Give me your arm. Get up. There you go. How do you feel? Can you feel your legs? You’re standing.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Too well, too well.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Only too well.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$This is above all strangeness.$NEWLINE$Upon the crown o' th' cliff, what thing was that$NEWLINE$Which parted from you?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$This is beyond weird. What was that thing I saw moving away from you up on the cliff before you fell?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$A poor unfortunate beggar.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$That was a poor unlucky beggar.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$As I stood here below, methought his eyes$NEWLINE$Were two full moons. He had a thousand noses,$NEWLINE$Horns whelked and waved like the enragèd sea.$NEWLINE$It was some fiend. Therefore, thou happy father,$NEWLINE$Think that the clearest gods, who make them honors$NEWLINE$Of men’s impossibilities, have preserved thee.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$From down here, I thought his eyes looked like full moons. He had a thousand noses and twisted horns, like wave crests in a storm at sea. It was some devil. You lucky old man, it seems that the gods have saved your life. They love to perform miracles so that humans will worship them.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I do remember now. Henceforth I’ll bear$NEWLINE$Affliction till it do cry out itself,$NEWLINE$“Enough, enough,” and die. That thing you speak of,$NEWLINE$I took it for a man. Often ’twould say,$NEWLINE$“The fiend, the fiend!” He led me to that place.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I understand now. From now on I’ll put up with my anguish until the anguish itself cries out, “Enough, enough!” and disappears. I thought that thing you’re talking about was a man. It would often talk about the devil. It took me to that deadly place.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Bear free and patient thoughts.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Cheer up and be at peace.

paragraphs.original: Enter LEAR, mad$NEWLINE$LEAR
paragraphs.translated: LEAR enters, insane.$NEWLINE$LEAR

paragraphs.original: But who comes here?$NEWLINE$The safer sense will ne'er accommodate$NEWLINE$His master thus.
paragraphs.translated: But who is that? A sane person would never dress like this.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, they cannot touch me for coining. I am the king himself.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, they can’t accuse me of counterfeiting coins. I’m the king himself.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(aside) O thou side-piercing sight!$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to himself) Oh, what a heartbreaking sight!$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Nature’s above art in that respect. There’s your press- money. That fellow handles his bow like a crowkeeper. Draw me a clothier’s yard. Look, look, a mouse! Peace,
paragraphs.translated:
LEAR$NEWLINE$Life’s better at
breaking hearts than art is.—Hey, a new recruit. Here’s your enlistment bonus.—Look how awkwardly he handles his crossbow.—Come on, pull it back farther!—Look, look, a mouse! Calm down, this$NEWLINE$breaking hearts$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: peace, this piece of toasted cheese will do ’t. There’s my gauntlet. I’ll prove it on a giant. Bring up the brown bills. O, well flown, bird. I' th' clout, i' th' clout. Hewgh! Give the word.
paragraphs.translated: piece of cheese will get him.—I challenge you to a match. I’ll even fight a giant.—Call out the infantry. —Oh, that arrow was well shot. Whoosh! Right in the bull’s eye.–—What’s the password?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Sweet marjoram.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Sweet marjoram.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Pass.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$That’s it!

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I know that voice.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I know that voice.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Ha! Goneril with a white beard? Ha, Regan? They flattered me like a dog and told me I had white hairs in my beard ere the black ones were there. To say “Ay” and “No” to everything that I said “Ay” and “No” to was no good divinity. When the rain came to wet me once, and the wind to make me chatter, when the thunder would not peace at my bidding—there I found 'em, there I smelt 'em out. Go to, they are not men o' their words. They told me I was everything. 'Tis a lie, I am not ague-proof.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Ha! Goneril with a white beard? Ha, Regan?—They flattered me and told me how wise I was, wise before my time. To agree to everything I said was not truly devout.—The rain came to drench me, and the wind to make me shiver, and the thunder wouldn’t stop roaring when I ordered it to. That’s when I learned the truth about them. That’s when I sniffed them out. I tell you, they are not honest men. They told me I was everything. It’s a lie. I’m not immune to chills.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$The trick of that voice I do well remember.$NEWLINE$Is ’t not the king?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I recognize something about that voice. Isn’t that the king?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Ay, every inch a king. When I do stare, see how the subject quakes. I pardon that man’s life. What was thy cause? Adultery? Thou shalt not die. Die for adultery? No. The wren goes to ’t, and the small gilded fly does lecher in my sight. Let copulation thrive, for Gloucester’s bastard son Was kinder to his father than my daughters got ’tween the lawful sheets. To ’t, luxury, pell-mell—for I lack soldiers.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Yes, every inch a king. My subjects tremble when I look at them. I pardon that man. What are you accused of? Adultery? I’ll commute your death sentence. To die for adultery? No. Little birds do it, and dragonflies copulate right in front of me. Let’s have more sex in the world, since Gloucester’s bastard son was kinder to him than my daughters, conceived in lawful wedlock, have been to me. Get to it, be lustful, sleep around—I need soldiers for my army. Look at that simpering lady over there. From looking at her face, I’d say she’s

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Behold yond simpering dame, whose face between her forks presages snow, that minces virtue and does shake the head to hear of pleasure’s name. The fitchew, nor the soiled horse, goes to ’t with a more riotous appetite. Down from the waist they are centaurs, though women all above. But to the girdle do the gods inherit; beneath is all the fiends'. There’s hell, there’s darkness, there’s the sulfurous pit— burning, scalding, stench, consumption! Fie, fie, fie, pah, pah!—Give me an ounce of civet, good apothecary, to sweeten my imagination. There’s money for thee.
paragraphs.translated: frigid. She pretends to be virtuous and to disdain the word “sex, but she’s hornier than a passel of rabbits. Women are sex machines below the waist, though they’re chaste up above. Above the waist they belong to God, but the lower part belongs to the devil. That’s where hell is, and darkness, and fires and stench! Death and orgasm! Ah, ah, ah! Give me an aphrodisiac, pharmacist. Let me have sweet dreams. There’s money in it for you.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$O, let me kiss that hand!
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Oh, let me kiss his hand!

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Let me wipe it first. It smells of mortality.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Let me wipe it off first. It stinks of death.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$O ruined piece of nature! This great world$NEWLINE$Shall so wear out to naught. Dost thou know me?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$A ruined man! This is how the whole world will end up, worn away to nothing.—Do you know who I am?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$I remember thine eyes well enough. Dost thou squiny at me? No, do thy worst, blind Cupid. I’ll not love. Read thou this challenge. Mark but the penning of it.
paragraphs.translated:
LEAR$NEWLINE$I remember your eyes quite well. Are you squinting at me? Go ahead, try to make me fall in love, blind
Cupid. I won’t ever love again. Read this letter. Just look at the handwriting.$NEWLINE$Cupid$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Were all thy letters suns, I could not see one.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$If every letter on that page were a sun, I couldn’t see even one of them.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(aside) I would not take this from report. It is,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$And my heart breaks at it.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to himself) I wouldn’t believe this if I weren’t seeing it with my own eyes. It’s real, and it breaks my heart.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Read.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Read it.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$What, with the case of eyes?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$How? With my eye sockets?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Oh ho, are you there with me? No eyes in your head, nor no money in your purse? Your eyes are in a heavy case, your purse in a light. Yet you see how this world goes.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Oh ho, is that what you’re getting at? You want money before you’ll read? No eyes in your head til there’s money in your wallet? Your eyes are in a bad way, your wallet’s empty, but you understand the ways of the world.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I see it feelingly.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I do understand, by touch.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$What, art mad? A man may see how this world goes with no eyes. Look with thine ears. See how yon justice rails upon yon simple thief. Hark in thine ear: change places and, handy-dandy, which is the justice, which is the thief? Thou hast seen a farmer’s dog bark at a beggar?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$What, are you crazy? You don’t need eyes to see how the world works. Look with your ears. Look how the judge yells at a simple thief. Listen. But mix them up, have them switch places, and do you think you’d be able to tell which one is which? Have you seen a farmer’s dog bark at a beggar?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Ay, sir.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Yes, sir.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$And the creature run from the cur? There thou mightst behold the great image of authority: a dog’s obeyed in office.$NEWLINE$Thou rascal beadle, hold thy bloody hand.$NEWLINE$Why dost thou lash that whore? Strip thine own back.$NEWLINE$Thou hotly lust’st to use her in that kind$NEWLINE$For which thou whipp’st her. The usurer hangs the cozener.$NEWLINE$Through tattered clothes great vices do appear;$NEWLINE$Robes and furred gowns hide all. Plate sin with gold,$NEWLINE$And the strong lance of justice hurtless breaks.$NEWLINE$Arm it in rags, a pigmy’s straw does pierce it.$NEWLINE$None does offend—none, I say, none. I’ll able 'em.$NEWLINE$Take that of me, my friend, who have the power$NEWLINE$To seal th' accuser’s lips. Get thee glass eyes,$NEWLINE$And like a scurvy politician seem$NEWLINE$To see the things thou dost not. Now, now, now, now,$NEWLINE$Pull off my boots. Harder, harder. So.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$And you saw how the beggar ran from the mutt? That’s authority! Even a dog is obeyed sometimes. You stupid cop, stop your violence! Why are you whipping that whore? You should be whipping yourself, since you lust after her and yearn to do the same thing for which you’re punishing her. One criminal punishes another. Poor men’s sins are much more noticeable than rich men’s. Cover up a crime with gold and the arm of justice can’t touch it. But dress the crime in rags and it’s caught easily. Everyone sins. You can’t blame anyone for it anyone, I say. I’ll vouch for that. Believe me, my friend, since I have the power to stop the prosecutors. Get yourself some glass eyes, and pretend to see things you can’t, like a crooked politician. Now, now, now, now. Pull off my boots. Harder, harder. Like that.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(aside) O matter and impertinency mixed! Reason in madness!$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to himself) Oh, wisdom and absurdity mixed up together! Reason in madness!$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes.$NEWLINE$I know thee well enough. Thy name is Gloucester.$NEWLINE$Thou must be patient. We came crying hither.$NEWLINE$Thou know’st the first time that we smell the air$NEWLINE$We wawl and cry. I will preach to thee. Mark me.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$If you want to cry over my bad luck, I’ll give you my eyes. I know you. Your name’s Gloucester. You have to be patient with me. I came here crying. The first time we see the world as newborns, we cry and scream. I’ll read you a sermon. Listen to this.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Alack, alack the day!
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Oh, how awful!

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$When we are born, we cry that we are come$NEWLINE$To this great stage of fools. This a good block.$NEWLINE$It were a delicate stratagem to shoe$NEWLINE$A troop of horse with felt. I’ll put ’t in proof.$NEWLINE$And when I have stol'n upon these sons-in-law,$NEWLINE$Then, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$When we’re born, we cry because we’ve arrived on the stage of life, like all the other fools. That’s a nice hat you’ve got there. How ingenious to make horseshoes out of felt. I’ll test it out. And when I’ve sneaked up on my sons-in-law, then I’ll kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!

paragraphs.original: Enter GENTLEMAN with two others$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated: The GENTLEMAN enters with two other gentlemen.$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Oh, here he is. Lay hand upon him.—Sir,$NEWLINE$Your most dear daughter—
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$(noticing LEAR) Oh, here he is. Grab him.—Sir, your most dear daughter—$NEWLINE$(noticing$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No rescue? What, a prisoner? I am even$NEWLINE$The natural fool of fortune. Use me well.$NEWLINE$You shall have ransom. Let me have surgeons.$NEWLINE$I am cut to th' brains.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$What, I’m a prisoner? No rescue for me? My luck has always been bad. Treat me well. There’s a ransom. I need a doctor. My brains are injured.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$You shall have anything.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$You can have anything you want.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No seconds? All myself?$NEWLINE$Why, this would make a man a man of salt,$NEWLINE$To use his eyes for garden water-pots,$NEWLINE$Ay, and laying autumn’s dust.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Will no one back me up? Am I all alone? That would make anyone cry enough to water his garden with his tears.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Good sir—
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Good sir—

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$I will die bravely, like a smug bridegroom.$NEWLINE$What, I will be jovial. Come, come.$NEWLINE$I am a king, my masters, know you that?
paragraphs.translated:
LEAR$NEWLINE$I’ll die
courageously, like a well-dressed bridegroom. Okay, I’ll be cheery. I’m king. Did you know that, gentlemen?$NEWLINE$courageously$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$You are a royal one, and we obey you.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$You’re of royal blood, and we obey you.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Then there’s life in ’t. Come, an if you get it, you shall get it by running. Sa, sa, sa, sa.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Then there’s still a chance. Come and get it! But you’ll have to catch me! Catch me if you can! Sa, sa, sa, sa.

paragraphs.original: Exit LEAR running, followed by two gentlemen$NEWLINE$LEAR
paragraphs.translated: LEAR exits running, chased by two gentlemen.$NEWLINE$LEAR

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$A sight most pitiful in the meanest wretch,$NEWLINE$Past speaking of in a king. Thou hast a daughter$NEWLINE$Who redeems nature from the general curse$NEWLINE$Which twain have brought her to.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$This is a difficult to see even in a beggar. In a king, the sight is unbearable. He has a daughter good enough to cancel out the wickedness of the other two.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Hail, gentle sir.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Hello, good sir.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Sir, speed you. What’s your will?
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$How do you do, sir. How can I help you?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Do you hear aught, sir, of a battle toward?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Have you heard any news of impending battle?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Most sure and vulgar. Everyone hears that$NEWLINE$That can distinguish sound.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Certainly. Everyone who can hear has heard about it.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$But, by your favor, how near’s the other army?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Could you tell me how near the enemy is?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Near and on speedy foot. The main descry$NEWLINE$Stands in the hourly thought.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Very near, and approaching fast. The main body of the army is expected here any hour now.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I thank you, sir. That’s all.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Thank you, sir. That’s all I wanted to know.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Though that the queen on special cause is here,$NEWLINE$Her army is moved on.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$The queen is here on special business, and her army has moved on.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I thank you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Thank you, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated: The GENTLEMAN exits.$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$You ever gentle gods, take my breath from me.$NEWLINE$Let not my worser spirit tempt me again$NEWLINE$To die before you please.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Gentle gods in heaven, please let me die. Don’t tempt me to suicide again.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Well pray you, father.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Pray well, father.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Now, good sir, what are you?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$And who are you, good sir?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$A most poor man made tame to fortune’s blows,$NEWLINE$Who by the art of known and feeling sorrows$NEWLINE$Am pregnant to good pity. Give me your hand,$NEWLINE$I’ll lead you to some biding.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I’m a poor man who’s been humbled by many misfortunes. I’ve had enough sorrow in my life to feel compassion for others. Give me your hand. I’ll lead you to some shelter.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Hearty thanks.$NEWLINE$The bounty and the benison of heaven$NEWLINE$To boot and boot.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Thank you very much. May heaven bless you.

paragraphs.original: Enter OSWALD the steward$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD enters.$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$A proclaimed prize! Most happy!$NEWLINE$That eyeless head of thine was first framed flesh$NEWLINE$To raise my fortunes. Thou old unhappy traitor,$NEWLINE$Briefly thyself remember. The sword is out$NEWLINE$That must destroy thee.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$What good luck! I’ll get the promised reward. That blind head of yours was created to make me rich. You old traitor, repent all your sins. Prepare to die.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Now let thy friendly hand$NEWLINE$Put strength enough to ’t.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Death is exactly what I want. I hope you’re strong enough to do it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDGAR interferes$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR steps in between GLOUCESTER and OSWALD.$NEWLINE$EDGAR$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Wherefore, bold peasant,$NEWLINE$Darest thou support a published traitor? Hence,$NEWLINE$Lest that th' infection of his fortune take$NEWLINE$Like hold on thee. Let go his arm.
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Whoa, man, you dare to support someone who’s been proclaimed a traitor? Get out of here, before his bad luck infects you too. Let go of his arm.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$'Chill not let go, zir, without vurther 'casion.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Oh no, sir, I won’t let him go, sir, not without a good reason.

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Let go, slave, or thou diest!
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Let go of him, peasant, or you die!

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Good gentleman, go your gait, and let poor volk pass. An 'chud ha' bin zwaggered out of my life, ’twould not ha' bin zo long as ’tis by a vortnight. Nay, come not near th' old man. Keep out, che vor' ye, or I’se try whether your costard or my ballow be the harder. 'Chill be plain with you.
paragraphs.translated:
EDGAR$NEWLINE$Get on with your business, sir, and leave the poor people alone. If
macho talk like yours could kill me, I’d have died weeks ago. No, don’t come near the old man. Keep away, I’m warning you, or I’ll find out whether your head is harder than my walking stick. I’m completely serious.$NEWLINE$macho talk$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Out, dunghill!
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$Get out of here, you pile of crap.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$'Chill pick your teeth, zir. Come, no matter vor your foins.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I’ll knock your teeth out, sir. To hell with your sword.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR and OSWALD fight$NEWLINE$EDGAR$NEWLINE$OSWALD
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR and OSWALD fight.$NEWLINE$EDGAR$NEWLINE$OSWALD

paragraphs.original: OSWALD$NEWLINE$(falling) Slave, thou hast slain me. Villain, take my purse.$NEWLINE$(falling)$NEWLINE$If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body.$NEWLINE$And give the letters which thou find’st about me$NEWLINE$To Edmund, Earl of Gloucester. Seek him out$NEWLINE$Upon the British party. O untimely death! (dies)$NEWLINE$(dies)
paragraphs.translated: OSWALD$NEWLINE$(falling) You peasant, you’ve killed me! Villain, take my money. If you survive, make sure I have a decent burial. Give the letters I’m carrying to Edmund, Earl of Gloucester. He’s with the English camp. Oh, early death! (he dies)$NEWLINE$(falling)$NEWLINE$(he dies)

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I know thee well—a serviceable villain,$NEWLINE$As duteous to the vices of thy mistress$NEWLINE$As badness would desire.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I know you well. You’re a hardworking villain who’d do anything his evil mistress wanted him to.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$What, is he dead?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Is he dead?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Sit you down, father. Rest you.$NEWLINE$Let’s see these pockets. The letters that he speaks of$NEWLINE$May be my friends. He’s dead. I am only sorry$NEWLINE$He had no other death’s-man. Let us see.$NEWLINE$(takes letters out of OSWALD’s pocket and opens them)$NEWLINE$(takes letters out of$NEWLINE$’s pocket and opens them)$NEWLINE$Leave, gentle wax, and, manners, blame us not.$NEWLINE$To know our enemies' minds, we rip their hearts.$NEWLINE$Their papers is more lawful.$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“Let our reciprocal vows be remembered. You have many opportunities to cut him off. If your will want not, time and place will be fruitfully offered. There is nothing done if he return the conqueror. Then am I the prisoner and his bed my gaol, from the loathed warmth whereof deliver me, and supply the place for your labor. Your—wife, so I would say—affectionate servant, and for you her own for venture,$NEWLINE$Goneril.”$NEWLINE$O indistinguished space of woman’s will!$NEWLINE$A plot upon her virtuous husband’s life,$NEWLINE$And the exchange my brother!—Here in the sands$NEWLINE$Thee I’ll rake up, the post unsanctified$NEWLINE$Of murderous lechers. And in the mature time$NEWLINE$With this ungracious paper strike the sight$NEWLINE$Of the death-practiced duke. For him ’tis well$NEWLINE$That of thy death and business I can tell.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Sit down and rest, father. Let’s look in his pockets. The letters he spoke of may help me. He’s dead. I’m just sorry I had to be the one to kill him. Let’s see here.$NEWLINE$(takes letters out of OSWALD’s pocket and opens them)$NEWLINE$(takes letters out of$NEWLINE$’s pocket and opens them)$NEWLINE$Come on, envelope, open up for me. I know it’s bad manners, but we kill our enemies to know their secrets. Reading their mail isn’t as bad.$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“Don’t forget the vows we made to each other. You have many chances to kill Albany. If you have the strength of will to do it, you’ll have many opportunities. If he returns in triumph, then all is lost. I’ll be his prisoner, and his bed will be my prison. Help me escape him, and you can take his place. Your—I wish I could say “wife”—loving servant, who is ready to love you,$NEWLINE$Goneril.”$NEWLINE$Is there no limit to women’s lust? She’s plotting against the life of her virtuous husband, and wants my brother to replace him! (to the dead OSWALD) I’ll bury you here in a shallow grave, you messenger for lustful criminals. In due time I’ll show this ugly letter to the duke whose life’s at risk. It’s a good thing for him that I can tell him about your death and the letter you were carrying.$NEWLINE$(to the dead$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$The king is mad. How stiff is my vile sense,$NEWLINE$That I stand up and have ingenious feeling$NEWLINE$Of my huge sorrows. Better I were distract—$NEWLINE$So should my thoughts be severed from my griefs,$NEWLINE$And woes by wrong imaginations lose$NEWLINE$The knowledge of themselves.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$The king is insane. I hate the fact that I’m sane enough to be aware of my own great suffering. It’d be better to be delirious and unaware of anything. Then my mind would be free of sorrow, and sadness would be forgotten in my hallucinations.

paragraphs.original: Drum afar off
paragraphs.translated: Drums play in the distance.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Give me your hand.$NEWLINE$Far off methinks I hear the beaten drum.$NEWLINE$Come, father, I’ll bestow you with a friend.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Give me your hand. I think I hear the drums far away. Come, father, I’ll leave you at a friend’s house.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CORDELIA, KENT disguised, GENTLEMAN, and DOCTOR$NEWLINE$CORDELIA$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$DOCTOR
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA enters with KENT in disguise, the GENTLEMAN, and the DOCTOR.$NEWLINE$CORDELIA$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$DOCTOR

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$O thou good Kent, how shall I live and work$NEWLINE$To match thy goodness? My life will be too short,$NEWLINE$And every measure fail me.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Oh, Kent, what could I ever do to become as good as you are? I won’t live long enough, and all my efforts will fail me.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$To be acknowledged, madam, is o'erpaid.$NEWLINE$All my reports go with the modest truth,$NEWLINE$Nor more, nor clipped, but so.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Just being thanked is more than enough for me, madam. I hope all reports about me simply tell the truth, no more or less.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Be better suited.$NEWLINE$These weeds are memories of those worser hours.$NEWLINE$I prithee, put them off.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Change into better clothes. These rags will just remind us of those bad times when you had to wear a disguise. Please take them off.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Pardon, dear madam.$NEWLINE$Yet to be known shortens my made intent.$NEWLINE$My boon I make it that you know me not$NEWLINE$Till time and I think meet.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I’m sorry, madam, but I can’t do that yet. If people recognize me now, I won’t be able to carry out my plans. I have to ask you, as a favor, not to let on that you recognize me until the time is right.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Then be ’t so, my good lord.—$NEWLINE$How does the king?
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$All right, my lord.—How’s the king doing?

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Madam, sleeps still.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$He’s still sleeping, ma'am.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$O you kind gods,$NEWLINE$Cure this great breach in his abusèd nature,$NEWLINE$Th' untuned and jarring senses, O, wind up,$NEWLINE$Of this child-changèd father!
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Kind gods, heal the wounds that he’s wrongly suffered! Restore the sanity of this father whose children have driven him mad and changed him into a child again!

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$So please your majesty$NEWLINE$That we may wake the king? He hath slept long.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Would you mind if we woke up the king? He’s slept a long time.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Be governed by your knowledge, and proceed$NEWLINE$I' th' sway of your own will. Is he arrayed?
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Do whatever you think best. Is he in his royal garments?

paragraphs.original: Enter LEAR asleep in a chair carried by servants$NEWLINE$LEAR
paragraphs.translated: Servants carry in LEAR sleeping in a chair.$NEWLINE$LEAR

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Ay, madam. In the heaviness of his sleep$NEWLINE$We put fresh garments on him.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Yes, ma'am. We changed his clothes while he was fast asleep.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Be by, good madam, when we do awake him.$NEWLINE$I doubt not of his temperance.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Stay close by when we wake him up, ma'am. I’m sure he will stay under control.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Very well.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$All right.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Please you, draw near.—Louder the music there!
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Please come closer.— Make the music louder, please!

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(kisses LEAR) O my dear father, restoration hang$NEWLINE$(kisses$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thy medicine on my lips, and let this kiss$NEWLINE$Repair those violent harms that my two sisters$NEWLINE$Have in thy reverence made!
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(kisses LEAR) Oh, my dear father, please get better. May my kiss heal the wounds inflicted on you by my sisters—who should have respected and cherished you.$NEWLINE$(kisses$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Kind and dear princess!
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Kind and dear princess!

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Had you not been their father, these white flakes$NEWLINE$Did challenge pity of them. Was this a face$NEWLINE$To be opposed against the warring winds?$NEWLINE$To stand against the deep dread-bolted thunder$NEWLINE$In the most terrible and nimble stroke$NEWLINE$Of quick cross lightning? To watch—poor perdu!—$NEWLINE$With this thin helm? Mine enemy’s meanest dog,$NEWLINE$Though he had bit me, should have stood that night$NEWLINE$Against my fire. And wast thou fain, poor father,$NEWLINE$To hovel thee with swine and rogues forlorn$NEWLINE$In short and musty straw? Alack, alack!$NEWLINE$'Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once$NEWLINE$Had not concluded all.—He wakes. Speak to him.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$If you hadn’t been their father, your white hair would have inspired in them only compassion. Is this a face that should have endured the freezing winds or withstood the dreadful thunder or the terrible lightning? To stay awake all night like a guardsman—poor lost soul!—with only your thinning hair for a helmet? I would’ve let even my enemy’s nastiest dog stay inside by the fireplace on that night, even if he had bit me. And were you then happy to find shelter on a bed of hay along with swine and homeless bums? Oh, oh! It’s a wonder you didn’t lose your life and your mind all at once.—He’s waking up. Talk to him.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Madam, do you. 'Tis fittest.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$You talk to him, ma'am. That’s most appropriate.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$How does my royal lord? How fares your majesty?
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$How are you, my royal lord? How is your majesty doing?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$You do me wrong to take me out o' th' grave.$NEWLINE$Thou art a soul in bliss, but I am bound$NEWLINE$Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears$NEWLINE$Do scald like molten lead.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$You do me wrong by taking me out of the grave. You’re a soul in heaven, but I’m tied to the fiery wheel of a torture machine in hell. Even my tears burn me like molten lead.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Sir, do you know me?
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Sir, do you know who I am?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$You are a spirit, I know. Where did you die?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$You’re a spirit, I know. Where did you die?

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(aside to DOCTOR) Still, still far wide!$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(whispering to the DOCTOR) He’s still in outer space.$NEWLINE$(whispering to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$He’s scarce awake. Let him alone awhile.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$He’s still half asleep. Let him be for a bit.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Where have I been? Where am I? Fair daylight?$NEWLINE$I am mightily abused. I should ev'n die with pity$NEWLINE$To see another thus. I know not what to say.$NEWLINE$I will not swear these are my hands. Let’s see.$NEWLINE$I feel this pinprick. Would I were assured$NEWLINE$Of my condition.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Where have I been? Where am I? Is it daytime? I’ve been tricked. I would die of pity to see someone else in my condition. I don’t know what to say. I can’t even be sure these are my hands. Let’s see. I feel this pinprick. I wish I knew what is happening.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(kneels)$NEWLINE$(kneels)$NEWLINE$O, look upon me, sir,$NEWLINE$And hold your hands in benediction o'er me.$NEWLINE$No, sir, you must not kneel.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(kneeling) Look at me, sir, and give me your blessing. No, sir, don’t kneel.$NEWLINE$(kneeling)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Pray, do not mock me.$NEWLINE$I am a very foolish fond old man,$NEWLINE$Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less.$NEWLINE$And to deal plainly$NEWLINE$I fear I am not in my perfect mind.$NEWLINE$Methinks I should know you, and know this man.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Please don’t make fun of me. I’m a foolish, senile old man, eighty-something years old, not an hour more or less. To put it plainly, I’m afraid I’m not quite sane. I feel I should recognize you and that man (he points to KENT),$NEWLINE$(he points to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Yet I am doubtful, for I am mainly ignorant$NEWLINE$What place this is, and all the skill I have$NEWLINE$Remembers not these garments. Nor I know not$NEWLINE$Where I did lodge last night. Do not laugh at me,$NEWLINE$For as I am a man, I think this lady$NEWLINE$To be my child Cordelia.
paragraphs.translated: but I’m not sure. I don’t know where I am. I don’t remember these clothes. I can’t recall where I slept last night. Don’t laugh at me, but I swear I think this lady is my child Cordelia.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$And so I am, I am.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$And I am, I am.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Be your tears wet? Yes, faith. I pray, weep not.$NEWLINE$If you have poison for me, I will drink it.$NEWLINE$I know you do not love me, for your sisters$NEWLINE$Have, as I do remember, done me wrong.$NEWLINE$You have some cause; they have not.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Are your tears wet? Yes, indeed they are. Please don’t cry. If you have poison for me, I’ll drink it. I know you don’t love me. If I remember, your sisters did me wrong for no reason. But you didn’t, even though you had every reason.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$No cause, no cause.
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$I had no reason, no reason.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Am I in France?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Am I in France?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$In your own kingdom, sir.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$You’re in your own kingdom, sir.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Do not abuse me.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Don’t deceive me.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Be comforted, good madam. The great rage,$NEWLINE$You see, is killed in him. And yet it is danger$NEWLINE$To make him even o'er the time he has lost.$NEWLINE$Desire him to go in. Trouble him no more$NEWLINE$Till further settling.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$You can relax, ma'am. His insane period is over. But it’s dangerous to make him try to make sense of the time he lost. Ask him to go in. Don’t trouble him further until his mind is more settled.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Will ’t please your highness walk?
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$Would your highness like to take a walk?

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$You must bear with me.$NEWLINE$Pray you now, forget and forgive.$NEWLINE$I am old and foolish.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$You’ll have to bear with me. Please forgive and forget. I’m old and foolish.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Manent KENT and GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated: KENT and the GENTLEMAN remain.$NEWLINE$KENT$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Holds it true, sir, that the Duke of Cornwall was so slain?
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Is it true, sir, that the Duke of Cornwall was killed as they say?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Most certain, sir.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Yes, it’s true, sir.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Who is conductor of his people?
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Who is leading his men?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$As ’tis said, the bastard son of Gloucester.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$They say Gloucester’s bastard son is.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$They say Edgar, his banished son, is with the Earl of Kent in Germany.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$I hear that Edgar, Gloucester’s exiled son, is with the Earl of Kent in Germany.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Report is changeable. Tis time to look about. The powers of the kingdom approach apace.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$You can’t trust all the rumors. It’s time to reassess the situation. The British troops are coming near.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$The arbitrament is like to be bloody. Fare you well, sir.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$It will likely be a bloody fight. Goodbye, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$My point and period will be throughly wrought,$NEWLINE$Or well or ill, as this day’s battle’s fought.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$My life and my plans completely depend on how today’s battle ends.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter with drum and colors EDMUND, REGAN, gentlemen, and soldiers$NEWLINE$EDMUND$NEWLINE$REGAN
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND, REGAN, gentlemen, and soldiers enter with drums and banners.$NEWLINE$EDMUND$NEWLINE$REGAN

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$(to a gentleman) Know of the duke if his last purpose hold,$NEWLINE$(to a gentleman)$NEWLINE$Or whether since he is advised by aught$NEWLINE$To change the course. He’s full of alteration$NEWLINE$And self-reproving. Bring his constant pleasure.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$(to a gentleman) Go find out from the Duke of Albany if his decision still holds, or if he’s changed his mind. He’s always going back and forth and second-guessing himself. Come back and tell me what his final decision is.$NEWLINE$(to a gentleman)

paragraphs.original: Exit gentleman
paragraphs.translated: Gentleman exits.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Our sister’s man is certainly miscarried.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$My sister’s servant Oswald has certainly run into trouble.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$'Tis to be doubted, madam.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’m afraid that may be the case, madam.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Now, sweet lord,$NEWLINE$You know the goodness I intend upon you.$NEWLINE$Tell me but truly—but then speak the truth—$NEWLINE$Do you not love my sister?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Now, my sweet lord, you know how much I like you. Tell me truthfully, do you love my sister?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$In honored love.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Yes, truly and honorably.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$But have you never found my brother’s way$NEWLINE$To the forfended place?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$But have you ever gone in my brother-in-law’s bed and had sex with her?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$That thought abuses you.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$No. You dishonor yourself and our relationship by thinking that.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$I am doubtful that you have been conjunct$NEWLINE$And bosomed with her as far as we call hers.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$I’m just worried that you’ve been cozying up to her, and gotten intimate with her.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$No, by mine honor, madam.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$No, I swear on my honor, I haven’t, madam.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$I never shall endure her. Dear my lord,$NEWLINE$Be not familiar with her.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$I can’t stand her. Please, my lord, don’t be friendly with her.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Fear me not.—$NEWLINE$She and the duke her husband!
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Don’t worry about me.—Your sister and the duke are here.

paragraphs.original: Enter with drum and colors ALBANY and GONERIL, with troops$NEWLINE$ALBANY$NEWLINE$GONERIL
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY, GONERIL, and soldiers enter with drums and banners.$NEWLINE$ALBANY$NEWLINE$GONERIL

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(aside) I had rather lose the battle than that sister$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Should loosen him and me.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(to herself) I’d rather lose this battle than allow that sister of mine to come between me and Edmund.$NEWLINE$(to herself)

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Our very loving sister, well bemet.—$NEWLINE$Sir, this I hear: the king is come to his daughter,$NEWLINE$With others whom the rigor of our state$NEWLINE$Forced to cry out. Where I could not be honest$NEWLINE$I never yet was valiant. For this business,$NEWLINE$It touches us as France invades our land,$NEWLINE$Not bolds the king, with others whom I fear$NEWLINE$Most just and heavy causes make oppose.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$My dear and loving sister-in-law, I’m happy to see you. (to EDMUND) Sir, I’ve heard that the king has joined up with his daughter as well as others who have complained about our strict policies. I’ve never fought for a cause I didn’t believe in. I’m concerned about the French because they have invaded our soil, not because they support King Lear or those others—who, I’m afraid, may have legitimate grievances against us.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Sir, you speak nobly.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Noble words, sir.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Why is this reasoned?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Why are we talking about this?

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Combine together 'gainst the enemy,$NEWLINE$For these domestic and particular broils$NEWLINE$Are not the question here.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$We must join forces against the enemy. Our domestic squabbles are not the issue here.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Let’s then determine with the ancient of war$NEWLINE$On our proceedings.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Then let’s meet with our senior command and discuss what to do next.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I shall attend you presently at your tent.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’ll meet you at your tent.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Sister, you’ll go with us?
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Goneril, are you coming with us?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$No.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$No.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$'Tis most convenient. Pray you, go with us.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$It’s the best thing to do. Please come with me.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(aside) Oh ho, I know the riddle.—I will go.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(to herself) Oh ho, I know her little tricks.—Okay, I’ll go.$NEWLINE$(to herself)

paragraphs.original: Enter EDGAR disguised$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR enters, disguised as a peasant.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to ALBANY) If e'er your grace had speech with man so poor,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Hear me one word.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to ALBANY) If you can stoop to speak to a man as poor as I am, then listen to me, please.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND, REGAN, and GONERIL)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$,$NEWLINE$, and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I’ll overtake you.—
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND, REGAN, and GONERIL exiting) I’ll catch up with you.—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$,$NEWLINE$, and$NEWLINE$exiting)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but ALBANY and EDGAR$NEWLINE$ALBANY$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except ALBANY and EDGAR.$NEWLINE$ALBANY$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: Speak.
paragraphs.translated: Go ahead.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(giving ALBANY a letter)$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$a letter)$NEWLINE$Before you fight the battle, ope this letter.$NEWLINE$If you have victory, let the trumpet sound$NEWLINE$For him that brought it. Wretched though I seem,$NEWLINE$I can produce a champion that will prove$NEWLINE$What is avouchèd there. If you miscarry,$NEWLINE$Your business of the world hath so an end,$NEWLINE$And machination ceases. Fortune love you.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(giving ALBANY a letter) Before you go into battle, open this letter. If you win, then blow your trumpet as a signal for me. I may look wretched, but I’ll bravely stand up to defend my claims. If you die in battle, all your projects and this plan are off. Good luck to you.$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$a letter)

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Stay till I have read the letter.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Wait until I read the letter.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I was forbid it.$NEWLINE$When time shall serve, let but the herald cry,$NEWLINE$And I’ll appear again.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I was ordered not to. When the time comes, tell the herald to blow the trumpet and I’ll return.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Why, fare thee well. I will o'erlook thy paper.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Goodbye, then. I’ll take a look at your letter.

paragraphs.original: Exit EDGAR$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR exits.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: Enter EDMUND$NEWLINE$EDMUND
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND enters.$NEWLINE$EDMUND

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$The enemy’s in view. Draw up your powers.$NEWLINE$(gives ALBANY a document)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$a document)$NEWLINE$Here is the guess of their true strength and forces$NEWLINE$By diligent discovery, but your haste$NEWLINE$Is now urged on you.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$The enemy’s in sight. Prepare your troops. (gives ALBANY a document) The reconnaissance operation has returned this estimate of the enemy’s manpower and weaponry. But now, please hurry.$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$a document)

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$We will greet the time.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$We’ll be ready when the time comes.

paragraphs.original: Exit ALBANY$NEWLINE$ALBANY
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$To both these sisters have I sworn my love,$NEWLINE$Each jealous of the other as the stung$NEWLINE$Are of the adder. Which of them shall I take?$NEWLINE$Both? One? Or neither? Neither can be enjoyed$NEWLINE$If both remain alive. To take the widow$NEWLINE$Exasperates, makes mad her sister Goneril,$NEWLINE$And hardly shall I carry out my side,$NEWLINE$Her husband being alive. Now, then, we’ll use$NEWLINE$His countenance for the battle, which being done,$NEWLINE$Let her who would be rid of him devise$NEWLINE$His speedy taking off. As for the mercy$NEWLINE$Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia,$NEWLINE$The battle done and they within our power,$NEWLINE$Shall never see his pardon, for my state$NEWLINE$Stands on me to defend, not to debate.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’ve sworn my love to both of these sisters. They’re jealous of each other like poisonous snakes. Which one of them should I pick? Both? One? Neither? I can’t enjoy either of them as long as the other one’s alive. Goneril would go crazy if I chose Regan, but it would be hard to get in with Goneril while her husband’s still alive. I’ll use Albany’s power and authority for now to win the war, but afterward one of the sisters—whichever one wants to—can get rid of him. Albany wants to spare Lear and Cordelia, but once they are my prisoners after the battle, they won’t stay alive long enough to see his pardon. I have to defend my position with actions, not words.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum within Enter with drum and colors the powers of France over the stage, and CORDELIA with her father LEAR in her hand And exeunt$NEWLINE$CORDELIA$NEWLINE$LEAR
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle offstage. CORDELIA enters hand in hand with LEAR, accompanied by drums, banners, and French troops. They cross the stage and exit.$NEWLINE$CORDELIA$NEWLINE$LEAR

paragraphs.original: Enter EDGAR disguised and GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$EDGAR$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR enters, disguised, along with GLOUCESTER.$NEWLINE$EDGAR$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Here, father, take the shadow of this tree$NEWLINE$For your good host. Pray that the right may thrive.$NEWLINE$If ever I return to you again,$NEWLINE$I’ll bring you comfort.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Here, father, rest awhile in the shade of this tree. Say a little prayer for our side in battle. If I ever come back, I’ll bring you good news.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Grace go with you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Good luck, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit EDGAR$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR exits.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: Alarum and retreat within
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle offstage. They grow fainter.

paragraphs.original: Enter EDGAR$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR returns.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Away, old man. Give me thy hand. Away!$NEWLINE$King Lear hath lost, he and his daughter ta'en.$NEWLINE$Give me thy hand. Come on.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$We have to get out of here, old man. Let me help you up. Let’s go! King Lear’s been defeated. He and his daughter are captured. Give me your hand. Come on.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$No further, sir. A man may rot even here.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I can’t go any further, sir. This is as good a place as any to die.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$What, in ill thoughts again? Men must endure$NEWLINE$Their going hence even as their coming hither.$NEWLINE$Ripeness is all. Come on.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Are you depressed again? You can’t choose your time of death any more than your time of birth. We live and die when our time comes. Come on.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$And that’s true too.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$And that’s true too.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter in conquest with drum and colors EDMUND, with LEAR and CORDELIA as prisoners, and FIRST CAPTAIN with soldiers$NEWLINE$EDMUND$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$CORDELIA$NEWLINE$FIRST CAPTAIN
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND enters, victorious, with drums and banners. LEAR and CORDELIA enter as prisoners, led by the FIRST CAPTAIN and soldiers.$NEWLINE$EDMUND$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$CORDELIA$NEWLINE$FIRST CAPTAIN

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Some officers take them away. Good guard$NEWLINE$Until their greater pleasures first be known$NEWLINE$That are to censure them.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Officers, take them away. Guard them carefully until we decide how to punish them.

paragraphs.original: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(to LEAR)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$We are not the first$NEWLINE$Who with best meaning have incurred the worst.$NEWLINE$For thee, oppressèd King, I am cast down.$NEWLINE$Myself could else outfrown false fortune’s frown.$NEWLINE$Shall we not see these daughters and these sisters?
paragraphs.translated: CORDELIA$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) At least we’re not the first ones in our position. The road to hell is paved with good intentions. But I’m worried about you, my poor King. If it were only me, I would just wait out my bad luck. Should we meet with my sisters?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, no, no, no! Come, let’s away to prison.$NEWLINE$We two alone will sing like birds i' th' cage.$NEWLINE$When thou dost ask me blessing, I’ll kneel down$NEWLINE$And ask of thee forgiveness. So we’ll live,$NEWLINE$And pray, and sing, and tell old tales, and laugh$NEWLINE$At gilded butterflies, and hear poor rogues$NEWLINE$Talk of court news, and we’ll talk with them too—$NEWLINE$Who loses and who wins, who’s in, who’s out—$NEWLINE$And take upon ’s the mystery of things$NEWLINE$As if we were God’s spies. And we’ll wear out$NEWLINE$In a walled prison packs and sects of great ones$NEWLINE$That ebb and flow by the moon.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$No, no, no, no! Come on, let’s go to prison. The two of us together will sing like birds in a cage. We will be good to each other. When you ask for my blessing, I’ll get down on my knees and ask you to forgive me. That’s how we’ll live—we’ll pray, we’ll sing, we’ll tell old stories, we’ll laugh at pretentious courtiers, we’ll listen to nasty court gossip, we’ll find out who’s losing and who’s winning, who’s in and who’s out. We’ll think about the mysteries of the universe as if we were God’s spies. In prison we’ll outlast hordes of rulers that will come and go as their fortunes change.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Take them away.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Take them away.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Upon such sacrifices, my Cordelia,$NEWLINE$The gods themselves throw incense. Have I caught thee?$NEWLINE$He that parts us shall bring a brand from heaven$NEWLINE$And fire us hence like foxes. Wipe thine eyes.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$My Cordelia, even the gods admire how much you’ve sacrificed for me. Have I hugged you yet? Anyone who wants to separate us will have to smoke us out of the cave of our togetherness like foxes. Wipe your eyes.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The good years shall devour them, flesh and fell,$NEWLINE$Ere they shall make us weep. We’ll see 'em starve first.$NEWLINE$Come.
paragraphs.translated: Our jailers will shrivel up with old age before they make us cry again. We’ll watch them starve to death first.$NEWLINE$Come on.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LEAR and CORDELIA, led by soldiers$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$CORDELIA
paragraphs.translated: LEAR and CORDELIA exit, led by soldiers.$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$CORDELIA

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Come hither, captain. Hark.$NEWLINE$(gives FIRST CAPTAIN a document)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$a document)$NEWLINE$Take thou this note. Go follow them to prison.$NEWLINE$One step I have advanced thee. If thou dost$NEWLINE$As this instructs thee, thou dost make thy way$NEWLINE$To noble fortunes. Know thou this: that men$NEWLINE$Are as the time is. To be tender-minded$NEWLINE$Does not become a sword. Thy great employment$NEWLINE$Will not bear question. Either say thou'lt do ’t,$NEWLINE$Or thrive by other means.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Come here, captain. Listen. (gives the FIRST CAPTAIN a sheet of paper) Take this note. Follow those two to prison and follow these instructions. I’ve already promoted you once. If you do as you’re told, you’ll be richly rewarded. Just remember this: you have to go with the times, and these are the times for being tough. A soldier can’t afford to be a ninny. There’ll be no quibbling about this assignment. Either you accept it, or go find some other way to support yourself.$NEWLINE$(gives the$NEWLINE$a sheet of paper)

paragraphs.original: FIRST CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$I’ll do ’t, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$I’ll do it, sir.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$About it, and write “happy” when thou’st done.$NEWLINE$Mark, I say, instantly, and carry it so$NEWLINE$As I have set it down.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Then off you go. When you’ve finished, you’ll be a happy man. Go immediately, and do exactly as I wrote down.

paragraphs.original: FIRST CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$I cannot draw a cart, nor eat dried oats.$NEWLINE$If it be man’s work, I’ll do ’t.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$Jobs are hard to come by. I can’t pull a cart or eat dried oats like a horse. If it’s work for a man, I’ll do it.

paragraphs.original: Exit FIRST CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$FIRST CAPTAIN
paragraphs.translated: The FIRST CAPTAIN exits.$NEWLINE$FIRST CAPTAIN

paragraphs.original: Flourish Enter the Duke of ALBANY, the two ladies GONERIL and REGAN, a SECOND CAPTAIN, and soldiers$NEWLINE$ALBANY$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$SECOND CAPTAIN
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. ALBANY enters with GONERIL and REGAN, a SECOND CAPTAIN, and more soldiers.$NEWLINE$ALBANY$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$SECOND CAPTAIN

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND) Sir, you have shown today your valiant strain,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And fortune led you well. You have the captives$NEWLINE$That were the opposites of this day’s strife.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND) Sir, you’ve shown your true courage today, and luck was on your side. You’ve taken prisoner the leaders of the opposition. I need to take cus-$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I do require them of you, so to use them$NEWLINE$As we shall find their merits and our safety$NEWLINE$May equally determine.
paragraphs.translated: tody of them so I can do what’s best out of concern for their honor and the safety of the kingdom.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Sir, I thought it fit$NEWLINE$To send the old and miserable king$NEWLINE$To some retention and appointed guard—$NEWLINE$Whose age has charms in it, whose title more—$NEWLINE$To pluck the common bosom on his side,$NEWLINE$An turn our impressed lances in our eyes$NEWLINE$Which do command them. With him I sent the queen,$NEWLINE$My reason all the same, and they are ready$NEWLINE$Tomorrow or at further space t' appear$NEWLINE$Where you shall hold your session. At this time$NEWLINE$We sweat and bleed. The friend hath lost his friend,$NEWLINE$And the best quarrels, in the heat, are cursed$NEWLINE$By those that feel their sharpness.$NEWLINE$The question of Cordelia and her father$NEWLINE$Requires a fitter place.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Sir, I decided it was appropriate to send the pathetic old king to a guarded prison cell. His old age and his title make him so popular among the commoners that I was worried our enlisted soldiers would turn against us on his behalf. I sent the French queen with him too, for the same reason. They’re ready to meet with you tomorrow, or whenever you like, wherever you’d like to hold your hearing. These are difficult times. Many have lost friends in battle, and soldiers will curse even a justified war if it causes them pain. We need a more appropriate place to discuss Cordelia and her father.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$I hold you but a subject of this war,$NEWLINE$Not as a brother.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$I’m sorry, sir, but in this war I consider you a subordinate, not my equal.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$That’s as we list to grace him.$NEWLINE$Methinks our pleasure might have been demanded$NEWLINE$Ere you had spoke so far. He led our powers,$NEWLINE$Bore the commission of my place and person—$NEWLINE$The which immediacy may well stand up$NEWLINE$And call itself your brother.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$That’s for to me to decide. You might have asked my opinion before saying something so rude. Edmund has led our forces well, and implemented my wishes—and his close connection with me gives him the right to be considered your equal.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Not so hot.$NEWLINE$In his own grace he doth exalt himself$NEWLINE$More than in your addition.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Not so fast. He has distinguished himself as a great soldier in his own right, deserving more than any honor your can bestow on him.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$In my rights,$NEWLINE$By me invested, he compeers the best.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$I’m the one who gave him his military commission, and it is as my proxy that he fought bravely.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$That were the most if he should$NEWLINE$husband you.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$He’d really be your proxy if he married you.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Jesters do oft prove prophets.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Don’t joke, it might come true.

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Holla, holla!$NEWLINE$That eye that told you so looked but asquint.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Whoa, whoa! You’re so infatuated with him that you’re hallucinating.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Lady, I am not well, else I should answer$NEWLINE$From a full-flowing stomach.$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND)     General,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Take thou my soldiers, prisoners, patrimony.$NEWLINE$Dispose of them, of me. The walls is thine.$NEWLINE$Witness the world that I create thee here$NEWLINE$My lord and master.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Hey, lady, if I weren’t feeling a little sick, I’d give you a piece of my mind. (to EDMUND) General, take my soldiers, my prisoners, my whole inheritance, and do as you like with them. I surrender myself to your good judgment. Let the whole world see that I hereby make you my lord and master.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Mean you to enjoy him then?
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Are you trying to sleep with him?

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$The let-alone lies not in your good will.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL) It’s not up to you to say “Yes” or “No.”$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Nor in thine, lord.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Nor is it up to you, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Half-blooded fellow, yes.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Yes it is, you half-blood.

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND) Let the drum strike and prove my title thine.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND) Let the drums beat. Prove your right to me by defeating any challenger.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Stay yet. Hear reason.—Edmund, I arrest thee$NEWLINE$On capital treason, and in thine attaint$NEWLINE$This gilded serpent.(indicates GONERIL)$NEWLINE$(indicates$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to REGAN) For your claim, fair sister,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I bar it in the interest of my wife.$NEWLINE$'Tis she is subcontracted to this lord.$NEWLINE$And I, her husband, contradict your banns.$NEWLINE$If you will marry, make your loves to me,$NEWLINE$My lady is bespoke.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Hang on a second. Listen to me.—Edmund, you’re under arrest for capital treason. Along with you, your co-conspirator, this snake of a woman. (points at GONERIL. Then, speaking to REGAN) My dear sister-in-law, I veto your marriage announcement for the benefit of my wife, who is already engaged to Edmund. So if you want to get married, you’ll have to woo me. My wife’s already spoken for.$NEWLINE$(points at$NEWLINE$. Then, speaking to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$An interlude!
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$What a farce!

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Thou art armed, Gloucester. Let the trumpet sound.$NEWLINE$If none appear to prove upon thy person$NEWLINE$Thy heinous, manifest, and many treasons,$NEWLINE$There is my pledge. (throws down his glove)$NEWLINE$(throws down his glove)$NEWLINE$I’ll make it on thy heart,$NEWLINE$Ere I taste bread, thou art in nothing less$NEWLINE$Than I have here proclaimed thee.
paragraphs.translated:
ALBANY$NEWLINE$You’ve got a sword, Gloucester. Blow the trumpets. If nobody else comes to challenge you and prove what an abominable traitor you have been, I’ll have to challenge you myself. (he
throws down his glove) I’ll prove soon enough that you’re just as wicked as I say you are.$NEWLINE$(he$NEWLINE$throws$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$down his glove)

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$Sick, oh, sick!
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$Oh, I’m sick, sick!

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(aside) If not, I’ll ne'er trust medicine.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$(to herself) If she’s not ill, I’ll never trust drugs again.$NEWLINE$(to herself)

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$(throwing down his glove)$NEWLINE$(throwing down his glove)$NEWLINE$There’s my exchange.
