What in the world he is$NEWLINE$That names me traitor, villainlike he lies.$NEWLINE$Call by thy trumpet. He that dares approach,$NEWLINE$On him—on you, who not?—I will maintain$NEWLINE$My truth and honor firmly.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$(throwing down his glove) You’re on. Whoever calls me a traitor is a vicious liar. Blow the trumpet. Anyone who dares to step forward and make that accusation—you or anyone else—go ahead. I’ll uphold my truth and my honor.$NEWLINE$(throwing down his glove)

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$A herald, ho!
paragraphs.translated:
ALBANY$NEWLINE$A
herald! Call a herald!$NEWLINE$herald!$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$A herald, ho, a herald!
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$A herald, a herald!

paragraphs.original: Enter a HERALD$NEWLINE$HERALD
paragraphs.translated: A HERALD enters.$NEWLINE$HERALD

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND) Trust to thy single virtue, for thy soldiers,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$All levied in my name, have in my name$NEWLINE$Took their discharge.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND) You’re on your own now. The soldiers were all drafted in my name, and now they are discharged in my name.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: REGAN$NEWLINE$My sickness grows upon me.
paragraphs.translated: REGAN$NEWLINE$I feel sicker and sicker.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$She is not well. Convey her to my tent.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$She’s not feeling well. Take her to my tent.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit REGAN, led$NEWLINE$REGAN
paragraphs.translated: REGAN is helped to exit.$NEWLINE$REGAN

paragraphs.original: Come hither, herald.—Let the trumpet sound,—$NEWLINE$And read out this. (gives the HERALD a document)$NEWLINE$(gives the$NEWLINE$a document)
paragraphs.translated: Come here, herald.—Let the trumpet sound!—Read this out. (he hands the HERALD a document)$NEWLINE$(he hands the$NEWLINE$a document)

paragraphs.original: SECOND CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$Sound, trumpet!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$Blow the trumpet!

paragraphs.original: A trumpet sounds
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet sounds.

paragraphs.original: HERALD$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“If any man of quality or degree within the lists of the army will maintain upon Edmund, supposed Earl of Gloucester, that he is a manifold traitor, let him appear by the third sound of the trumpet. He is bold in his defense.”
paragraphs.translated: HERALD$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“If any noble man in the army asserts that Edmund, so-called Earl of Gloucester, is a traitor many times over, let him step forward by the third trumpet blast.”

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Sound!
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Sound!

paragraphs.original: First trumpet
paragraphs.translated: First trumpet sounds.

paragraphs.original: HERALD$NEWLINE$Again!
paragraphs.translated: HERALD$NEWLINE$Again!

paragraphs.original: Second trumpet
paragraphs.translated: Second trumpet sounds.

paragraphs.original: HERALD$NEWLINE$Again!
paragraphs.translated: HERALD$NEWLINE$Again!

paragraphs.original: Third trumpet Trumpet answers within Enter EDGAR, at the third sound, armed, a trumpet before him$NEWLINE$EDGAR
paragraphs.translated: Third trumpet sounds. Another trumpet answers inside. EDGAR enters, wearing armor.$NEWLINE$EDGAR

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$(to HERALD) Ask him his purposes, why he appears$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Upon this call o' th' trumpet.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$(to HERALD) Ask him why he’s stepping forward.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: HERALD$NEWLINE$What are you?$NEWLINE$Your name, your quality, and why you answer$NEWLINE$This present summons?
paragraphs.translated: HERALD$NEWLINE$Who are you? What’s your name and rank, and why are you stepping forward?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$O, know, my name is lost.$NEWLINE$By treason’s tooth bare-gnawn and canker-bit.$NEWLINE$Yet am I noble as the adversary$NEWLINE$I come to cope withal.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I’ve lost my name and title to a traitor. But I’m as noble as my opponent.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Which is that adversary?
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$And who is that?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$What’s he that speaks for Edmund, Earl of Gloucester?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Who’s the spokesman for Edmund, Earl of Gloucester?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Himself. What sayst thou to him?
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’m my own spokesman. What do you have to say to me?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Draw thy sword,$NEWLINE$That if my speech offend a noble heart$NEWLINE$Thy arm may do thee justice. (draws his sword) Here is mine.$NEWLINE$(draws his sword)$NEWLINE$Behold: it is the privilege of mine honors,$NEWLINE$My oath, and my profession. I protest—$NEWLINE$Maugre thy strength, youth, place, and eminence,$NEWLINE$Despite thy victor sword and fire-new fortune,$NEWLINE$Thy valor and thy heart—thou art a traitor,$NEWLINE$False to thy gods, thy brother, and thy father,$NEWLINE$Conspirant 'gainst this high illustrious prince,$NEWLINE$And from th' extremest upward of thy head$NEWLINE$To the descent and dust below thy foot$NEWLINE$A most toad-spotted traitor. Say thou “No,”$NEWLINE$This sword, this arm, and my best spirits are bent$NEWLINE$To prove upon thy heart, whereto I speak,$NEWLINE$Thou liest.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Draw your sword. If I offend you by what I say, you can use your sword to take revenge. Here’s mine. (he draws his sword) Look at it. It’s the symbol of my honor, my rank, and my status as a knight. In spite of your youth, rank, strength, and excellence at warfare, in spite of your courage, your recent victory, and your good luck, I declare that you’re a traitor. You’ve betrayed your gods, your brother, and your father. You’ve plotted against this noble duke. You’re a rotten traitor, through and through, from the top of your head to the soles of your feet. If you disagree with me, I’m ready to use this sword and my courage to prove that you’re a liar.$NEWLINE$(he draws his sword)

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$In wisdom I should ask thy name.$NEWLINE$But since thy outside looks so fair and warlike,$NEWLINE$And that thy tongue some say of breeding breathes,$NEWLINE$What safe and nicely I might well delay$NEWLINE$By rule of knighthood, I disdain and spurn.$NEWLINE$Back do I toss these treasons to thy head,$NEWLINE$With the hell-hated lie o'erwhelm thy heart—
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Normally I would ask you what your name is first. But since you look so fine and noble, and since you’re so well mannered in your speech, I’m prepared to overlook the rules of knighthood, which say I should refuse to fight a man I don’t know. I throw your accusations back in your face. Your lies can hardly hurt me, but I’ll

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Which, for they yet glance by and scarcely bruise,$NEWLINE$This sword of mine shall give them instant way,$NEWLINE$Where they shall rest for ever.—Trumpets, speak!
paragraphs.translated: still fight you and embed your lies back in your hellish heart.—Trumpets, blow!

paragraphs.original: Alarums EDMUND and EDGAR fight EDMUND falls$NEWLINE$EDMUND$NEWLINE$EDGAR$NEWLINE$EDMUND
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. EDMUND and EDGAR fight. EDMUND falls.$NEWLINE$EDMUND$NEWLINE$EDGAR$NEWLINE$EDMUND

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Save him, save him!
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$(to EDGAR) Save him, save him!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$This is practice, Gloucester.$NEWLINE$By th' law of arms thou wast not bound to answer$NEWLINE$An unknown opposite. Thou art not vanquished,$NEWLINE$But cozened and beguiled.
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$You were tricked into fighting, Gloucester. According to the laws of war, you didn’t have to fight a stranger. You haven’t lost this fight; you’ve been tricked and deceived.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Shut your mouth, dame,$NEWLINE$Or with this paper shall I stop it.—Hold, sir,$NEWLINE$(gives the letter to EDMUND)$NEWLINE$(gives the letter to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thou worse than any name, read thine own evil.—$NEWLINE$(to GONERIL) Nay, no tearing, lady. I perceive you know it.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Shut your mouth, woman, or I’ll shove this paper in it.—Stop, sir. (gives the letter to EDMUND) You despicable criminal, read your crime. (to GONERIL) Don’t try to tear it up, madam. I take it you know what this letter says.$NEWLINE$(gives the letter to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GONERIL$NEWLINE$Say, if I do? The laws are mine, not thine.$NEWLINE$Who can arraign me for ’t?
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL$NEWLINE$And what if I do? I make the laws, not you. Who can prosecute me for it?

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Most monstrous, oh!$NEWLINE$(to EDMUND) Know’st thou this paper?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Oh, monstrous! (to EDMUND) Do you know what letter this is?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Ask me not what I know.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Don’t ask me what I know.

paragraphs.original: Exit GONERIL$NEWLINE$GONERIL
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL exits.$NEWLINE$GONERIL

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Go after her. She’s desperate. Govern her.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Follow her. She’s desperate. Make sure she doesn’t do anything stupid.

paragraphs.original: Exit a soldier
paragraphs.translated: A soldier exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$What you have charged me with, that have I done—$NEWLINE$And more, much more. The time will bring it out.$NEWLINE$'Tis past, and so am I.$NEWLINE$(to EDGAR)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$But what art thou$NEWLINE$That hast this fortune on me? If thou'rt noble,$NEWLINE$I do forgive thee.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I’ve done everything you accuse me of—and more, much more. You’ll find out everything in due time. It’s all over now, and so am I. (to EDGAR) But who are you, you who’ve managed to defeat me? If you’re a nobleman, I forgive you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Let’s exchange charity.$NEWLINE$I am no less in blood than thou art, Edmund.$NEWLINE$If more, the more thou’st wronged me.$NEWLINE$My name is Edgar, and thy father’s son.$NEWLINE$The gods are just, and of our pleasant vices$NEWLINE$Make instruments to plague us.$NEWLINE$The dark and vicious place where thee he got$NEWLINE$Cost him his eyes.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Let’s forgive each other. I’m no less noble than you are, Edmund. If I’m more noble than you, you’ve done me wrong. My name is Edgar, and I’m your father’s son. The gods are fair, and they use our little vices to punish us. The woman he committed adultery with, your mother, cost him his eyes.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Thou’st spoken right. 'Tis true.$NEWLINE$The wheel is come full circle. I am here.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$You’re right. That’s true. It’s all come full circle, and here I am.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Methought thy very gait did prophesy$NEWLINE$A royal nobleness. I must embrace thee.$NEWLINE$Let sorrow split my heart if ever I$NEWLINE$Did hate thee or thy father.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$I suspected that you were noble when I saw how you walked. Let me embrace you. I swear I never hated you or your father!

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Worthy prince, I know ’t.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I know, prince.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Where have you hid yourself?$NEWLINE$How have you known the miseries of your father?
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Where have you been hiding? How did you know what happened to your poor father?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$By nursing them, my lord. List a brief tale,$NEWLINE$And when ’tis told, oh, that my heart would burst!$NEWLINE$The bloody proclamation to escape,$NEWLINE$That followed me so near—O our lives' sweetness,
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$I knew because I helped nurse him through his suffering. Listen to my little story, and when it’s done, oh, my heart will break! To escape the decree condemning me

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: That we the pain of death would hourly die$NEWLINE$Rather than die at once!—taught me to shift$NEWLINE$Into a madman’s rags, t' assume a semblance$NEWLINE$That very dogs disdained. And in this habit$NEWLINE$Met I my father with his bleeding rings,$NEWLINE$Their precious stones new lost, became his guide,$NEWLINE$Led him, begged for him, saved him from despair.$NEWLINE$Never—O fault!—revealed myself unto him$NEWLINE$Until some half-hour past, when I was armed.$NEWLINE$Not sure, though hoping of this good success,$NEWLINE$I asked his blessing, and from first to last$NEWLINE$Told him my pilgrimage. But his flawed heart—$NEWLINE$Alack, too weak the conflict to support—$NEWLINE$'Twixt two extremes of passion, joy and grief,$NEWLINE$Burst smilingly.
paragraphs.translated: to death, I disguised myself as a madman beggar and became a creature despised even by dogs.—Oh, how sweet our lives must be if we prefer to die gradually by debasing ourselves rather than dying all at once!—In that disguise I met up with my father with bloody sockets where his beautiful eyes used to be. I became his guide, I led him and begged for him, and kept him from suicide. I never—oh, what a mistake!—revealed myself to him until half an hour ago, when I was in my armor. With hope in my heart I asked him for his blessing, not sure that he’d give it to me. He did. I told him everything that had happened on my journey. But his frail heart, too weak to grapple with such a conflict between joy and sadness, gave out.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$This speech of yours hath moved me,$NEWLINE$And shall perchance do good. But speak you on.$NEWLINE$You look as you had something more to say.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Your words have moved me, and maybe it’ll do some good. But go on. You look like you have something more to say.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$If there be more, more woeful, hold it in.$NEWLINE$For I am almost ready to dissolve,$NEWLINE$Hearing of this.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$If there’s anything more sorrowful left to add, keep it to yourself. I’m almost ready to break down hearing this much.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$This would have seemed a period$NEWLINE$To such as love not sorrow, but another$NEWLINE$To amplify too much would make much more$NEWLINE$And top extremity.$NEWLINE$Whilst I was big in clamor came there in a man$NEWLINE$Who, having seen me in my worst estate,$NEWLINE$Shunned my abhorred society, but then, finding$NEWLINE$Who ’twas that so endured, with his strong arms$NEWLINE$He fastened on my neck, and bellowed out$NEWLINE$As he’d burst heaven, threw him on my father,$NEWLINE$Told the most piteous tale of Lear and him$NEWLINE$That ever ear received—which in recounting
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$This may have seemed like the pinnacle of sadness, but if I went on I could outdo it. While I was sobbing loudly, a man came in. He had seen me in my ragged clothes and shunned me, but when he found out who I was, he clasped my neck with his strong arms and cried to high heaven. He threw himself on my father and told the saddest story you’ve ever heard about Lear and him. As he was telling that story he grieved more and

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: His grief grew puissant and the strings of life$NEWLINE$Began to crack. Twice then the trumpets sounded,$NEWLINE$And there I left him tranced.
paragraphs.translated: more, until his heart started to break. Then I heard the trumpets blow twice, and left him there in a trance.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$But who was this?
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$But who was that man?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Kent, sir, the banished Kent, who in disguise$NEWLINE$Followed his enemy king and did him service$NEWLINE$Improper for a slave.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$It was Kent, sir, the exiled Kent, who, after the king treated him like an enemy of the state, put on a disguise and followed his king, carrying out tasks unworthy of even a slave.

paragraphs.original: Enter SECOND KNIGHT with a bloody knife$NEWLINE$SECOND KNIGHT
paragraphs.translated: The SECOND KNIGHT enters with a bloody knife.$NEWLINE$SECOND KNIGHT

paragraphs.original: SECOND KNIGHT$NEWLINE$Help, help, O, help!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND KNIGHT$NEWLINE$Help, help, oh, help!

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$What kind of help?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$What kind of help do you need?

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Speak, man.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Say something, man!

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$What means that bloody knife?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$What is that bloody knife?

paragraphs.original: SECOND KNIGHT$NEWLINE$'Tis hot, it smokes.$NEWLINE$It came even from the heart of—oh, she’s dead!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND KNIGHT$NEWLINE$It’s still warm from the cut. It was just removed from from the heart of—oh, she’s dead!

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Who dead? Speak, man.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Who’s dead? Speak, man.

paragraphs.original: SECOND KNIGHT$NEWLINE$Your lady, sir, your lady. And her sister$NEWLINE$By her is poisoned. She confesses it.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND KNIGHT$NEWLINE$Your wife, sir, your wife. And her sister’s dead too, poisoned by your wife. She confessed.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I was contracted to them both. All three$NEWLINE$Now marry in an instant.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I was engaged to both of them. All three of us will marry now in death.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Here comes Kent.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Here comes Kent.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Produce their bodies, be they alive or dead.$NEWLINE$This judgment of the heavens that makes us tremble$NEWLINE$Touches us not with pity.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$(to SECOND KNIGHT) Bring the bodies here, whether they’re alive or dead. We tremble at the gods' wrath, but we don’t mourn these deaths.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit SECOND KNIGHT$NEWLINE$SECOND KNIGHT
paragraphs.translated: The SECOND KNIGHT exits.$NEWLINE$SECOND KNIGHT

paragraphs.original: Enter KENT$NEWLINE$KENT
paragraphs.translated: KENT enters.$NEWLINE$KENT

paragraphs.original: Oh, is this he?$NEWLINE$The time will not allow the compliment$NEWLINE$Which very manners urges.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, is that Kent? There’s no time for polite greetings.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I am come$NEWLINE$To bid my king and master aye good night.$NEWLINE$Is he not here?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I’ve come to say farewell to my king and master. Isn’t he here?

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Great thing of us forgot!—$NEWLINE$Speak, Edmund, where’s the king? And where’s Cordelia?—
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$What an enormous thing for us to forget!—Edmund, tell us, where’s the king? And where’s Cordelia?—

paragraphs.original: REGAN’s and GONERIL’s corpses are brought out$NEWLINE$REGAN$NEWLINE$GONERIL
paragraphs.translated: GONERIL’s and REGAN’s bodies are brought out.$NEWLINE$GONERIL$NEWLINE$REGAN

paragraphs.original: Seest thou this object, Kent?
paragraphs.translated: Do you see this, Kent?

paragraphs.original: Kent$NEWLINE$Alack, why thus?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Oh, why is this so?

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Yet Edmund was beloved.$NEWLINE$The one the other poisoned for my sake,$NEWLINE$And after slew herself.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Still, Edmund was beloved. One of the sisters poisoned the other out of love for me, and then killed herself.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Even so.—Cover their faces.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Apparently so.—Cover their faces.

paragraphs.original: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I pant for life. Some good I mean to do$NEWLINE$Despite of mine own nature. Quickly send—$NEWLINE$Be brief in it—to th' castle, for my writ$NEWLINE$Is on the life of Lear and on Cordelia.$NEWLINE$Nay, send in time!
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$I wish I could live longer. I want to do a little good despite my evil nature. Go quickly—hurry—to the castle, for I’ve given orders to have Lear and Cordelia killed. Hurry, send someone immediately!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Run, run, O, run!
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Run, run, oh, run!

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$To who, my lord?—Who hath the office? Send$NEWLINE$Thy token of reprieve.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Whom should we look for in the castle?—Whose job is it? Send something along to prove you’re withdrawing the orders.

paragraphs.original: Edmund$NEWLINE$Well thought on. Take my sword. The captain—$NEWLINE$Give it the captain.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$Good idea. Take my sword. The captain—give it to the captain.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Haste thee for thy life.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Run as if your life depended on it.

paragraphs.original: Exit a soldier
paragraphs.translated: A soldier exits.

paragraphs.original: Edmund$NEWLINE$He hath commission from thy wife and me$NEWLINE$To hang Cordelia in the prison and$NEWLINE$To lay the blame upon her own despair,$NEWLINE$That she fordid herself.
paragraphs.translated: EDMUND$NEWLINE$My wife and I ordered him to hang Cordelia in prison and then to make it look as if she committed suicide in despair.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$The gods defend her!—hear him hence awhile.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Heaven help her!—Get him out of here for now.

paragraphs.original: Exit soldiers with EDMUND$NEWLINE$EDMUND
paragraphs.translated: Soldiers exit with EDMUND.$NEWLINE$EDMUND

paragraphs.original: Enter LEAR with CORDELIA in his arms, a THIRD KNIGHT following$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$CORDELIA$NEWLINE$THIRD KNIGHT
paragraphs.translated: LEAR enters with CORDELIA in his arms, followed by the THIRD KNIGHT.$NEWLINE$LEAR$NEWLINE$CORDELIA$NEWLINE$THIRD KNIGHT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Howl, howl, howl, howl! Oh, you are men of stones.$NEWLINE$Had I your tongues and eyes, I’d use them so$NEWLINE$That heaven’s vault should crack. She’s gone forever.$NEWLINE$I know when one is dead and when one lives.$NEWLINE$She’s dead as earth. Lend me a looking-glass.$NEWLINE$If that her breath will mist or stain the stone,$NEWLINE$Why then, she lives.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Howl, howl, howl, howl! Oh, you men are made of stone! If I were you with eyes and a tongue to speak with, I’d crack heaven wide open with my laments! She’s gone forever. I know how to tell when someone is alive or dead. She’s as dead as the cold ground. Let me borrow a mirror. If her breath steams up the glass, then she’s alive.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Is this the promised end?
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Is this doomsday? The end of the world?

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Or image of that horror?
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Or just a foretaste of it?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Fall and cease.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Let the world collapse around us.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$This feather stirs. She lives. If it be so,$NEWLINE$It is a chance which does redeem all sorrows$NEWLINE$That ever I have felt.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$This feather moved because of her breath. She’s alive. If that’s true, it makes up for all the sorrows I’ve ever known.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$O my good master!
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Oh, my good master!

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Prithee, away.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Please, go away.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$'Tis noble Kent, your friend.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$It’s noble Kent, your friend.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$A plague upon you, murderers, traitors all!$NEWLINE$I might have saved her. Now she’s gone for ever.—$NEWLINE$Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little. Ha?$NEWLINE$What is ’t thou say’st?—Her voice was ever soft,$NEWLINE$Gentle and low, an excellent thing in woman.—$NEWLINE$I killed the slave that was a-hanging thee.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Curse you all, you’re all murderers and traitors! I could have saved her. Now she’s gone forever.—Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a while. Ha? What are you saying?—Her voice always was so soft and gentle. That’s a good thing in a woman.—I killed the scum who was hanging you.

paragraphs.original: THIRD KNIGHT$NEWLINE$'Tis true, my lords, he did.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD KNIGHT$NEWLINE$It’s true, my lords, he did.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Did I not, fellow?$NEWLINE$I have seen the day with my good biting falchion$NEWLINE$I would have made them skip. I am old now,$NEWLINE$And these same crosses spoil me. (to KENT) Who are you?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Mine eyes are not o' th' best, I’ll tell you straight.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Didn’t I? Back in the old days I would’ve made him dance with my sword. But I’m old now, and suffering has weakened me. (to KENT) Who are you? My eyesight’s not the best, I’ll tell you straight.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$If Fortune brag of two she loved and hated,$NEWLINE$One of them we behold.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$We’re looking at the unluckiest man who ever lived.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$This a dull sight.$NEWLINE$Are you not Kent?
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$My vision is dull. Aren’t you Kent?

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$The same. Your servant Kent.$NEWLINE$Where is your servant Caius?
paragraphs.translated:
KENT$NEWLINE$That’s me. Your servant Kent. Where’s your servant
Caius?$NEWLINE$Caius$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$He’s a good fellow, I can tell you that.$NEWLINE$He’ll strike, and quickly too. He’s dead and rotten.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$He’s a good fellow, I can tell you that much. Not afraid to fight, he’s a feisty one. He’s dead and rotting in the dirt now.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$No, my good lord. I am the very man—
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$No, my lord, that was me. I’m the one who—

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$I’ll see that straight.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$I’ll get right on that.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$That from your first of difference and decay$NEWLINE$Have followed your sad steps.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$—followed you on your sad wanderings, ever since your bad luck began.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$You’re welcome hither.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Nice to see you.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Nor no man else. All’s cheerless, dark, and deadly.$NEWLINE$Your eldest daughters have fordone themselves,$NEWLINE$And desperately are dead.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$It was me, no one else. Everything is gloomy, dark, and dreadful. Your eldest daughters destroyed themselves and died in despair.

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$Ay, so I think.
paragraphs.translated: LEAR$NEWLINE$Yes, I think that’s true.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$He knows not what he says, and vain it is$NEWLINE$That we present us to him.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$He doesn’t know what he’s saying. It’s useless to try to talk to him.

paragraphs.original: Enter THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$THIRD MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The THIRD MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$THIRD MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Very bootless.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Yes, it’s pointless.

paragraphs.original: THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Edmund is dead, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Edmund is dead, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$That’s but a trifle here.—$NEWLINE$You lords and noble friends, know our intent.$NEWLINE$What comfort to this great decay may come$NEWLINE$Shall be applied. For us, we will resign$NEWLINE$During the life of this old majesty$NEWLINE$To him our absolute power.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$That doesn’t matter much with everything else that’s going on.—Gentlemen, I will announce my plans. I’ll do everything I can to ease the king’s suffering. As for me, I’m surrendering all my power over to him, giving him absolute authority for the rest of his life.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: (to EDGAR and KENT)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$You, to your rights$NEWLINE$With boot, and such addition as your honors$NEWLINE$Have more than merited.—All friends shall taste$NEWLINE$The wages of their virtue, and all foes$NEWLINE$The cup of their deservings. O, see, see!
paragraphs.translated: (to EDGAR and KENT) You will get back your rightful property and titles, along with new honors that you have more than deserved.—My friends and allies will be rewarded for their support, and my enemies will get what they deserve. Look, look!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEAR$NEWLINE$And my poor fool is hanged.—No, no, no life?$NEWLINE$Why should a dog, a horse, a rat have life,$NEWLINE$And thou no breath at all? Oh, thou'lt come no more,$NEWLINE$Never, never, never, never, never.—$NEWLINE$Pray you, undo this button. Thank you, sir.$NEWLINE$Do you see this? Look on her. Look, her lips.$NEWLINE$Look there, look there. O, O, O, O.$NEWLINE$(dies)$NEWLINE$(dies)
paragraphs.translated:
LEAR$NEWLINE$And my poor
fool was hanged.— No, no, no life left? Why should a dog or horse or rat have life, but not you? You’ll never come to me again, never, never, never, never, never.—Please help me undo this button. Thank you, sir. Do you see that? Look at her. Look, her lips. Look there, look there. Oh, oh, oh, oh. (he dies)$NEWLINE$fool$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(he dies)

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$He faints!—My lord, my lord!
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$He’s fainted.—My lord, my lord!

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Break, heart. I prithee, break!
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$My heart will break, break.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) Look up, my lord.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$(to LEAR) Look at me, my lord.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$Vex not his ghost. O, let him pass. He hates him$NEWLINE$That would upon the rack of this tough world$NEWLINE$Stretch him out longer.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$Don’t disturb his soul. Let it go up to heaven. His soul would be angry at anyone who tried to keep him in the torture chamber of this life any longer.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Oh, he is gone indeed.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$Oh, he’s really gone.

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$The wonder is he hath endured so long.$NEWLINE$He but usurped his life.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$What’s amazing is how long he lasted. He was living on borrowed time at the end.

paragraphs.original: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Bear them from hence. Our present business$NEWLINE$Is to general woe.$NEWLINE$(to KENT and EDGAR) Friends of my soul, you twain$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Rule in this realm, and the gored state sustain.
paragraphs.translated: ALBANY$NEWLINE$Carry them away. Our business now is mourning and grief. (to KENT and EDGAR) My friends and soulmates, you two will reign over this kingdom and keep the wounded country alive.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KENT$NEWLINE$I have a journey, sir, shortly to go.$NEWLINE$My master calls me. I must not say no.
paragraphs.translated: KENT$NEWLINE$I will have to go on a journey to death soon, sir. My master’s calling me. I can’t say no.

paragraphs.original: EDGAR$NEWLINE$The weight of this sad time we must obey.$NEWLINE$Speak what we feel, not what we ought to say.$NEWLINE$The oldest hath borne most. We that are young$NEWLINE$Shall never see so much, nor live so long.
paragraphs.translated: EDGAR$NEWLINE$We must remember the gravity of this sad day. We should speak what we feel, not what we ought to say. The oldest one suffered the most. We young ones will never see as much as he has seen, or live as long.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt with a dead march
paragraphs.translated: They exit in a funeral march.
